The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of community and tradition, as well as the need for vigilance in the face of terrorism. As one longtime producer of Christmas markets in Germany said, "Without the Christmas market, there is no Christmas."

Title: Trump Puts Off Decision on Firing Attorney General Sessions Until After Midterm Elections

Article:

In a recent interview with Bloomberg News, President Trump stated that he has delayed the decision on whether to fire Attorney General Jeff Sessions until at least after the November congressional elections. Trump expressed his desire for Sessions to "do a great job," but declined to comment on whether he would keep him in the position beyond November.

The president has been publicly critical of Sessions for months, and recently told a Republican lawmaker that he wanted to fire him before the midterm elections. However, top Republican lawmakers have urged Sessions to resist pressure to quit and have pushed Trump to stand down for now.

According to sources, Trump surveyed his advisors earlier this week about the potential political fallout from firing Sessions, and was told that there would be little blowback. However, senior officials within the White House provided Trump with legal and political reasons for not removing Sessions, but were unsure of what Trump would ultimately decide.

One factor contributing to Trump's decision to keep Sessions on for the coming months is the lack of an obvious replacement. White House officials and those Trump has spoken to about firing Sessions have said that the president has not inquired about potential successors.

Trump's anger towards Sessions stems from his view that the attorney general erred in recusing himself from the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 elections. The investigation is looking into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, as well as possible obstruction of justice. Trump has denied any wrongdoing and has called the probe a "witch hunt." Russia has also denied any involvement.

Last week, Trump launched another attack on Sessions, suggesting that the attorney general is allowing the special counsel's Russia investigation to proceed while permitting "real corruption" to go "untouched." In response, Sessions issued a rare public statement defending his leadership of the Justice Department, stating that the actions of the department will not be improperly influenced by political considerations.

As a result, Sessions is in a delicate position, both fending off attacks from Trump while carrying out the president's tough-on-crime policies.

Title: AP's Controversial Photo of Mitt Romney Raises Questions About Ethics in Journalism

Article:

A recent photograph published by the Associated Press (AP) has sparked a heated debate about the ethics of journalism. The image shows Mitt Romney, a presidential candidate, bending over, with a seemingly astonished schoolgirl standing behind him, mouth agape. The photo has quickly gone viral, with many interpreting it as a humorous moment. However, some critics argue that the AP's decision to publish the image was misguided and crossed the line into tabloid territory.

Media analysts and photojournalists have weighed in on the controversy, with some arguing that the AP knew exactly what viewers would think when they published the photo and that it was not legitimate news. Steve Manuel, a senior lecturer at Penn State's College of Communications and an award-winning photojournalist, stated that the AP must have anticipated the reaction and that it was not the purpose of photojournalism to place individuals in a position to be ridiculed.

Others have pointed out that the photo, while not altered or manipulated, may have been taken out of context. The National Press Photographers Association's code of ethics emphasizes the importance of treating subjects with respect and dignity, as well as providing context when photographing or recording subjects. The AP's decision to publish the photo coincided with a story about Romney's decision to skip a Nickelodeon-sponsored "Kids Pick the President" special, which some saw as a way to further criticize the Republican nominee.

Romney's campaign claimed that they did not have time to participate in the event, and that kids do not actually vote. The controversy surrounding the photo has sparked a larger discussion about the role of journalism in politics and the ethics of publishing certain types of images. While some see the photo as a harmless joke, others believe that it crossed the line and was not in line with the mission of a reputable news organization.

Title: Trump Shrugs Off Republican Leaders' Refusal to Endorse, Predicts Party Unity

Article:

Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump is downplaying the refusal of some Republican leaders to endorse him, saying that most of the party will ultimately back his candidacy. In an interview on NBC's Meet the Press, Trump stated that he will "get millions and millions of votes more than the Republicans would have gotten" and that new voters will compensate for any lack of support from traditional party members.

Trump's comments come as House Speaker Paul Ryan is scheduled to meet with the presumptive nominee on Thursday. Ryan has not yet endorsed Trump, citing concerns about his conservatism, while other party members, including 2012 nominee Mitt Romney and former 2016 hopefuls Jeb Bush and Lindsey Graham, have flatly rejected him. They have expressed concerns about Trump's language, comments about women and Hispanics, and his lack of respect for the Constitution.

Trump, however, believes that party unity is not as crucial as some may think. "I think it would be better if it were unified," he said, "but I don't think it actually has to be unified" in the traditional sense. He noted that the party is called the Republican Party, not the Conservative Party.

Ryan has expressed his reservations about Trump's candidacy, saying he lacks the "temperament or strength of character" to be president. Other party leaders, including Bush and Graham, have also spoken out against Trump, citing his lack of consistency and respect for the Constitution.

Trump, however, is confident that he will win over most Republicans and that new voters will make up for any lack of support from traditional party members. "You know, the party's come together," he said. "I have tremendous numbers of endorsements. I'm never going to get Romney's endorsement. He choked. He blew the last election."

Meanwhile, Democrats are enjoying the Republican infighting, particularly likely presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, who is targeting anti-Trump Republicans for the fall general election. "Obviously I'm reaching out to Democrats, Republicans, Independents – all voters who want a candidate who is running a campaign based on issues," Clinton told CBS's Face the Nation.

In the end, it remains to be seen whether Trump's confidence in his ability to win over most Republicans will be borne out, or if the party will remain divided come November.

**Intelligence Community to Brief President-elect Trump on Russian Hacking Report**

The United States intelligence community is set to brief President-elect Donald Trump on a report detailing Russian hacking activities during the 2016 presidential election. The report, prepared by the CIA, FBI, and NSA, is expected to be made public in an unclassified form early next week.

The briefing comes as Trump has continued to question the veracity of previous intelligence assessments, claiming that he has information that no one else has on Russian hacking and that he will reveal it publicly. However, he has yet to provide any evidence to support his claims.

The report's findings are expected to be presented to Trump by Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, along with CIA Director John Brennan, FBI Director James Comey, and National Security Agency Director Adm. Mike Rogers. The briefing is scheduled to take place at Trump Tower in New York.

The report is said to detail not only hacking activities but also classical propaganda, disinformation, and fake news tactics used by Russia to influence public opinion. The intelligence community has warned that Russia is a "full-scope cyber actor" and that its cyber operations will likely target the United States in the future.

Several lawmakers have expressed concern over Trump's skepticism towards the intelligence community, with Sen. John McCain, R-Arizona, warning that Russia must be held accountable for its actions. Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-South Carolina, urged Trump to take a strong stance against Russia's cyber attacks and to develop a clear cyber policy.

The Obama administration has already taken steps to punish Russia for its actions, imposing sanctions on Russian intelligence agents and entities responsible for the hacks into the Democratic National Committee and other servers. The administration also expelled 35 Russian operatives from the U.S.

The briefing comes as lawmakers are preparing to roll out legislation containing tougher sanctions against Russia. Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Maryland, plans to introduce legislation in the coming weeks.

The intelligence community's assessment is clear: Russia's cyber attacks were "nation-state-based" and were intended to influence the outcome of the election. The question remains whether Trump will take a strong stance against Russia's actions and develop a clear cyber policy to protect the United States from future attacks.

Title: White House Hosts Celebration of Faith and Freedom

Article:

The White House hosted a special celebration on Monday evening, honoring evangelical leaders and their contributions to American society. The event was attended by President Donald Trump, who expressed his gratitude to the faith leaders and emphasized the importance of protecting their rights.

The president highlighted his administration's efforts to combat religious persecution, citing the release of an American pastor from North Korea and the ongoing efforts to secure the release of Pastor Brunson from Turkey. He also emphasized the need for people of faith to vote in the upcoming midterm elections to ensure the progress made can continue.

Pastor Robert Jeffress, a staunch supporter of the president, echoed Trump's sentiments, stating that a Democrat-controlled Congress could potentially impeach or paralyze the president, and that evangelicals do not want either of those outcomes to happen.

The event was also attended by Rev. Franklin Graham and Pastor Paula White, among other faith leaders. The Faith & Freedom Coalition's Ralph Reed noted that the president's celebration was not just about honoring the faith leaders, but also about recognizing the daily work of churches and houses of worship in providing spiritual direction, healing, and salvation to those in need.

The president took a moment to publicly express his appreciation for the late Sen. John McCain's service to America, and his administration's efforts to protect religious freedom. The event was seen as a way for the president to show his appreciation for the support he received from Christians in the 2016 election and to pledge to continue protecting their rights.

Overall, the celebration was seen as a way to recognize the important role that faith plays in American society and to emphasize the importance of protecting religious freedom.

Title: The Elusive Quest for Identity: Understanding the Motivations of White Supremacists

Article:

The recent "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville has sparked a national conversation about the motivations and implications of white supremacist ideologies. While some have argued that these groups are driven by a desire for power and control, others believe that they are seeking a sense of identity and belonging. In this article, we will explore the complexities of white supremacy and examine the motivations of those who identify with these ideologies.

According to Kevin Williamson, a writer at National Review, white supremacists are not driven by a clear ideology or set of demands, but rather by a desire to be someone other than who they are. This theory suggests that these individuals are seeking a sense of purpose and identity that they feel is lacking in their own lives. Williamson argues that this desire for identity is rooted in a sense of failure and inadequacy, which can be attributed to a variety of factors, including economic and social circumstances.

The author of the article, who grew up in a town with a strong Confederate heritage, shares a personal anecdote about a high school classmate who identified as a neo-Nazi. The author notes that this individual was unable to provide a cogent explanation for their beliefs, and that their motivations seemed to be rooted in a sense of personal failure and inadequacy.

The article also touches on the idea that white supremacists are not necessarily driven by a desire for power or control, but rather by a desire to belong and be part of a group. The author notes that many of the individuals who marched in Charlottesville appear to have come from working-class backgrounds and may be struggling to make ends meet. This could be a factor in their desire to identify with a group that offers a sense of belonging and purpose.

The article concludes by noting that most people who fail to achieve their goals still honor the social contract and work alongside people from diverse backgrounds. The author argues that white supremacists are no exception, and that their desire for identity and belonging can be satisfied through positive interactions with others, rather than through hate and intolerance.

Overall, this article provides a nuanced and thought-provoking examination of the motivations and implications of white supremacist ideologies. While it does not condone or promote these ideologies, it seeks to understand the complex and often deeply personal factors that drive individuals to identify with them.

Title: Greece's Finance Minister Resigns as EU Leaders Meet to Address Crisis

Article:

Greece and its European Union partners are facing a critical moment in the country's debt crisis after the Greek people voted overwhelmingly against a German-led bailout plan. The vote has set off a chain reaction, with the Greek government seeking to renegotiate the terms of its bailout and the EU preparing for a potential exit from the union.

Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis resigned on Monday, citing a desire to help Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras negotiate better terms for his country. Varoufakis, known for his outspoken views on the crisis, called the vote "splendid" and a "historic" moment in which Greece "rose up against debt bondage."

The resignation has been seen as a significant change in style, but not necessarily substance, as Euclid Tsakalotos, a key negotiator in the drawn-out talks between the Greek government and creditors, has taken over as the new finance minister. Tsakalotos is expected to continue pushing for debt relief, a key issue in the negotiations.

EU leaders are set to meet on Tuesday to discuss the crisis, with Eurogroup President Jeroen Dijsselbloem calling the vote "regrettable for the future of Greece." European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis emphasized that while the EU respects the democratic choice of the Greek people, the no vote "widens the gap between Greece and Eurozone countries."

Dombrovskis also stressed that the European Commission cannot negotiate new terms with Greece without a mandate from eurogroup countries and that the eurozone is not in danger, regardless of what happens with Greece. He concluded that all sides need to work together responsibly for the sake of the Greek people.

The crisis is far from over, and the coming days will be crucial in determining the future of Greece and its place in the EU.

Title: Mississippi Senator's Past Attendance at Segregation Academy Raises Questions Ahead of Election

Article:

Mississippi Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith's past attendance at a segregation academy and her praise for a Confederate soldier's efforts to "defend his homeland" have raised questions about her views on racial issues ahead of a highly anticipated runoff election. The revelations, reported by the Jackson Free Press and CNN, have sparked controversy and drawn national attention to the election.

Hyde-Smith, a Republican, attended Lawrence County Academy, a school founded in 1970, the same year many Mississippi public high schools integrated. The school was created for parents who did not want to send their children to schools with black students. The school's yearbook photos, obtained by the Jackson Free Press, show a cheerleading squad, of which Hyde-Smith was a member, with the school's mascot dressed in what appears to be a Confederate uniform holding a Confederate flag.

Hyde-Smith's campaign has responded to the reports, calling them an "attack" and "an attempt to help her opponent, Democrat Mike Espy, who is vying to become the state's first African-American in the Senate since the Reconstruction. The campaign has also pointed out that Hyde-Smith apologized for her comments during a debate earlier this week and dubbed the voting suppression comments a "joke."

However, the reports have garnered national attention, and the election is expected to see a higher-than-average turnout. President Donald Trump is planning multiple rallies next week to help lock another Republican seat in the Senate after large losses in the House allowed Democrats to gain control.

The reports also highlight Hyde-Smith's past legislative work, which has been scrutinized for its ties to Confederate symbols and ideals. In 2007, she co-sponsored a resolution that honored Effie Lucille Nicholson Pharr, whose father was a soldier in Robert E. Lee's army. The resolution praised Pharr's father for his efforts to "defend his homeland and contribute to the rebuilding of the country."

The controversy surrounding Hyde-Smith's past has sparked concerns about her views on racial issues and her commitment to promoting equality and justice. The election is seen as a crucial test of the state's progress on racial issues, and the outcome is expected to have significant implications for the country.

Title: Trump's First Month in Office: A Rocky Start Amidst Self-Inflicted Wounds

Article:

President Donald Trump's first month in office has been marked by a series of challenges and setbacks, testing the limits of his ability to navigate the complexities of Washington politics. Despite his campaign promises of being a non-politician who can "fix" the system, Trump's early stumbles have raised questions about his ability to govern effectively.

The new administration has faced opposition from rival power centers in the courts, bureaucracy, and Congress, which has led to a series of executive orders being halted or delayed. Trump's attempts to exert control over his administration have been met with resistance from the judiciary, the intelligence community, and even his own staff.

The President's legislative agenda has also been slow to take shape, with congressional Republicans struggling to unify behind policy measures and Democrats forming a solid bloc of opposition. Trump's Cabinet nominees have faced scrutiny, with one withdrawing from consideration and another being fired.

Despite these challenges, Trump has shown resilience and determination, using his Twitter account to push back against critics and rally his base. He has also taken to the road, delivering speeches and rallies to connect with the American people.

However, Trump's early stumbles have overshadowed some of the areas where he could claim success, such as his well-choreographed visits from foreign leaders and his executive orders to dismantle Obamacare and federal regulations. His nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court was also a highlight of his presidency.

Experts say that every administration faces challenges in its early days, but Trump's self-inflicted wounds have made his transition more difficult. His idiosyncratic character and political style, which were an asset during his campaign, have not yet proven effective in governing.

As Trump navigates the complexities of Washington politics, he will need to find a way to work with Congress and the judiciary to advance his agenda. His ability to do so will be crucial in determining the success of his presidency.

Title: House GOP Blocks Immigration Proposals from Being Considered in Defense Policy Bill

Article:

The House Republican leadership has blocked two immigration-related amendments from being included in the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), a critical defense policy bill. The move deals a blow to the prospects of legislation aimed at rewriting the immigration system this year.

The first amendment, known as the ENLIST Act, was written by Representative Jeff Denham (R-Calif.) and would provide a pathway to green cards for immigrants who came to the US as children if they serve in the military. Representative Denham expressed disappointment at the decision, stating that he will continue to push for a standalone bill to allow undocumented young people to earn legal status through their military service.

The second amendment, introduced by Representative Joaquin Castro (D-Texas), would allow young immigrants who have been granted a reprieve from deportation by the Obama administration to enroll in US military academies. Representative Castro also expressed disappointment, stating that he plans to introduce the measure as a standalone bill with Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.).

Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) stated that including the ENLIST Act on the NDAA was "inappropriate," although he noted that Republican leaders have supported the measure in the past. There are ongoing discussions about allowing the bill to receive a standalone vote on the House floor.

The NDAA is a sweeping annual measure that sets policy for the Pentagon, and over 300 amendments were filed for consideration. Of those, 162 will be debated and voted on. The move is seen as a setback for immigration reform advocates, who had hoped to see progress on the issue this year.

Title: The Evolution of the US Mission in Syria: A Case of Mission Creep

Article:

The US military presence in Syria has been a topic of much debate and confusion in recent years. The initial goal of defeating the Islamic State (ISIS) has shifted to a focus on fighting Iran and establishing regime change in Damascus. The withdrawal of US troops from Syria has sparked a mix of reactions, with some viewing it as a necessary step towards a more focused approach and others seeing it as a retreat from a crucial mission.

The US military presence in Syria began in 2012, with the aim of supporting moderate Syrian rebels in their fight against the Assad regime. However, the mission quickly evolved to focus on defeating ISIS, with the US providing military aid and training to Kurdish forces. The public was initially supportive of this mission, with many viewing it as a necessary step to prevent the spread of terrorism.

However, as the mission progressed, it became clear that the US was not only fighting ISIS but also seeking to topple the Assad regime and weaken Iran's influence in the region. This shift in objectives has led to a sense of mission creep, with the US military presence becoming increasingly entangled in a complex web of alliances and rivalries.

The US has been accused of "handing a victory to Iran" with its withdrawal from Syria, but this claim is misleading. The US was never solely focused on defeating ISIS, and its presence in Syria was always tied to a broader strategy of regime change and anti-Iranian military action.

The US military presence in Syria has been marked by a series of failed plans and shifting objectives. In 2015, the US considered inserting 40,000 to 50,000 troops to create a safe zone in Syria, but this plan was never implemented. Last year, then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson outlined a plan to reduce Iran's influence in Syria, create conditions for refugees to return, and prevent the return of ISIS and al-Qaeda. However, this plan was never fully implemented, and the US military presence in Syria has remained mired in a complex and confusing situation.

The withdrawal of US troops from Syria is a recognition that the mission has become too complex and unwieldy. The US has achieved its goal of defeating ISIS, and it is time to reassess its role in the region. The US military presence in Syria has been marked by a series of failed plans and shifting objectives, and it is time to acknowledge that the mission has been a case of mission creep.

Title: The Complexity of Abortion Laws: A Nuanced Look at the Debate

Article:

The recent passage of abortion laws in New York and Alabama has sparked intense debate and controversy, with both sides of the political spectrum claiming the other is extreme. However, a closer examination of the issue reveals a more complex and nuanced reality.

The Alabama law, which bans abortion in nearly all cases, has been widely criticized as an attack on women's reproductive rights. Meanwhile, the New York law, which allows abortion up to the 40th week of pregnancy, has been hailed as a victory for reproductive freedom. But what's often lost in the debate is the fact that both laws are extreme and do not reflect the attitudes of most Americans.

According to a Gallup poll, 60% of Americans support abortion rights in the first trimester, but only 13% do in the third trimester. This suggests that most Americans support early-stage abortions, but opposition grows as the fetus develops. The media's reaction to the two laws also highlights the political polarization of the issue, with some outlets focusing on the "extremism" of one side or the other.

The debate is further complicated by the fact that the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe v. Wade decision, which legalized abortion nationwide, has been criticized by some as a "heavy-handed judicial intervention" that foreclosed state-level compromise. This has led to a political landscape in which both sides are more responsive to activists and donors than to the public's nuanced views on the issue.

The Alabama law is clearly unconstitutional under current precedent, but it was passed in the hope that the court's new conservative majority would overturn Roe and Casey. New York's law, on the other hand, was passed to create a "post-Roe" abortion sanctuary in case the court does reverse Roe. This highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of the issue and the need for compromise.

Ultimately, the debate over abortion is complex and multifaceted, and neither side has a monopoly on the truth. As the country moves forward, it's essential to recognize the complexity of the issue and work towards finding common ground.

**Title:** A Call to Unity in the Face of Crisis: Putting Country Over Party

**Article:**

As we observe Memorial Day, a time to reflect on the sacrifices made by our nation's heroes, it is crucial to acknowledge that we are facing a crisis of a different kind. The COVID-19 pandemic has brought unprecedented challenges, affecting millions of Americans, regardless of political affiliation. It is time for our leaders to put aside partisan differences and work together to address this national emergency.

The statistics are staggering: over 35 million people have filed for unemployment benefits, with many more struggling to make ends meet. Small businesses have closed, and major industries are on the brink of collapse. The virus has taken a devastating toll on our economy, with far-reaching consequences for individuals, families, and communities.

It is essential that our leaders recognize the gravity of the situation and take bold action to mitigate its impact. This means organizing a collective response, distributing medical and protective gear, and developing testing and tracing strategies. It also means limiting the damage by keeping families in their homes, small businesses open, and workers employed.

Unfortunately, recent actions by some lawmakers have fallen short of this mark. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has expressed a lack of urgency to aid states and localities, while Senator Lindsey Graham has opposed extending supplemental unemployment benefits. These partisan posturing and obstructionism only exacerbate the crisis.

However, there are glimmers of hope. Conservative and progressive lawmakers have come together to champion a paycheck guarantee program, supporting small business owners to pay their employees during the pandemic. This is a common-sense solution that transcends party lines.

Similarly, most Americans agree that everyone should have access to treatment and testing without worrying about the cost. It is not a partisan issue, but a matter of public health and safety. Similarly, ensuring voting is safe in the fall is not a partisan agenda, but a necessary step to protect our democracy.

As we move forward, it is crucial that our leaders remember the sacrifices made by those who have come before us and put the needs of the nation above their own political interests. This is a time for patriotism, solidarity, and action. Let us hope that Memorial Day celebrations will inspire our leaders to put aside their differences and work together to overcome this crisis.

Title: Iraq's Military Faces Setback in Anbar Province as Islamic State Gains Ground

Article:

Iraq's military has faced a significant setback in the Anbar province, with Islamic State militants gaining ground in the region. The extremist group launched a fierce attack on the city of Ramadi, 70 miles west of Baghdad, dealing a blow to the newly launched Iraqi military offensive in the Sunni-dominated region.

According to reports, Sunni tribal leaders who have been holding out in the city are struggling to hold off the extremists, who are under intense pressure and are in dire need of weapons and ammunition. The situation is critical, with the Iraqi Defense Ministry acknowledging that the militants have gained a foothold in some areas of Anbar Province.

Despite the setback, the Iraqi government remains confident that the situation is under control and that the standoff will be resolved in the coming hours. The U.S. Central Command has also weighed in, stating that the Iraqi government remains in control of Ramadi, the provincial capital.

The fighting in Anbar is a key test for Iraq's military as it seeks to push the Islamic State out of the country. The region is strategically important, as it is located along the main roads linking Baghdad to the Syrian border. The militants entered Iraq from Syria, where they have been fighting to overthrow the regime of Bashar Assad.

Some residents of Anbar have sided with the Islamic State militants due to their shared Sunni identity and feelings of alienation from the Iraqi government. Other tribes have fought against the militants, complaining that the central government has not provided them with sufficient support.

The U.S. has encouraged the Iraqi government to provide the Sunni tribes with arms and other support to carry out the fight against the extremists. However, the Iraqi Prime Minister, Haider al-Abadi, has expressed concerns about the conflict in Yemen, stating that his government is "uneasy" about U.S. military support for Saudi Arabia, which is carrying out airstrikes against Shiite rebels there. Al-Abadi warned that the conflict has the potential to become a sectarian war.

The situation in Anbar highlights the complexities of the conflict in Iraq, where sectarian divisions and political rivalries have contributed to the rise of the Islamic State. The international community will be watching closely as the situation develops, with the U.S. and other countries providing military support to the Iraqi government in its fight against the extremist group.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Raises Questions About Trump's Alleged Ties to Putin Amid Roger Stone's Indictment

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) has sparked controversy with her recent social media posts, where she accused President Donald Trump of being beholden to Russian President Vladimir Putin. The Democratic leader's comments come in the wake of the indictment and arrest of Roger Stone, a former Trump campaign aide, who was charged with lying to Congress about his interactions with WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange and the Trump campaign.

Pelosi's tweets suggested that Stone's indictment revealed a deliberate and coordinated effort by top Trump campaign officials to subvert the will of the American people during the 2016 election. She also asked a rhetorical question about what Putin might have on Trump, implying that the president may be beholden to the Russian leader due to some compromising information.

The House Speaker also raised concerns about the Trump administration's efforts to weaken NATO, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which she believes would be a significant victory for Putin's foreign policy goals. Trump has denied all allegations of wrongdoing and has not publicly confirmed any compromising information.

Pelosi's comments have sparked a heated debate, with some critics accusing her of spreading conspiracy theories and others praising her for raising important questions about the Trump administration's ties to Russia. The House Speaker has emphasized the importance of holding those who commit illegal acts accountable, including witness tampering and lying to Congress.

The controversy surrounding Stone's indictment and Pelosi's comments highlights the ongoing tensions between the Democratic and Republican parties over the Mueller investigation and the Trump administration's relationships with foreign leaders. As the investigation continues, it remains to be seen whether any further evidence will emerge to support or refute Pelosi's claims.

Title: Senate Hearing Highlights Debate on Women's Role in Combat and Self-Defense

Article:

A recent Senate hearing on gun violence brought to the forefront the ongoing debate on women's role in combat and self-defense. Gayle Trotter, a tax attorney and the only woman on the five-member panel, argued that women need guns to physically defend themselves from larger and stronger male criminals. She emphasized that the ability to arm oneself is crucial for women's protection, citing the Second Amendment.

However, critics of women in combat have long argued that women are inherently less fit and less capable of handling the physical demands of combat. Trotter's testimony echoed this sentiment, stating that women are not used to violent confrontations and lack the physical strength to defend themselves in a hand-to-hand struggle.

Trotter also touched on the idea that women's roles as mothers are more important than their roles in the military. She questioned whether the principles of women's liberation truly embrace the idea of jailing mothers for refusing to leave their children behind with strangers. This perspective sparked criticism from those who argue that women should be able to serve in combat without being limited by their gender.

The debate surrounding women in combat is complex and multifaceted, with proponents arguing that women should have the same opportunities as men to serve in the military and critics citing concerns about physical and emotional limitations. While Gayle Trotter's testimony highlighted the importance of self-defense for women, it also raised questions about the broader implications of women's roles in society.

Ultimately, the debate will continue to rage on, with proponents and critics of women in combat presenting their arguments and counterarguments. As the discussion unfolds, it is essential to consider the complexities and nuances of this issue, weighing the benefits and drawbacks of women's participation in combat against the potential risks and challenges.

Title: Assaults on US Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agents Reach Decade High

Article:

A recent report by the Homeland Security inspector general has revealed a surge in assaults on US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents and Border Patrol agents, with 2017 seeing the highest number of incidents in a decade. The report highlights the growing trend of migrants resorting to violence in their interactions with law enforcement.

According to the report, assaults on ICE agents and Border Patrol agents reached 1,089 in 2010, dropping to 381 in 2014, but then increasing to 856 in 2017. The most frequent method of attack was projectiles, such as large rocks, which accounted for half of the assaults. Other methods used included bombs, clubs, knives, guns, and even laser pointers to blind agents.

The report also found that most of the injuries were minor and did not require treatment. However, the incidents highlight the growing danger faced by agents on the southwest border, where a surge in illegal immigration in recent years has correlated with growing violence.

In the interior, ICE agents and officers saw 48 assaults in 2017, tying 2010 as the highest in records going back to the beginning of the decade. ICE officers and Border Patrol agents have reported an increasing willingness on the part of migrants to resort to violence in recent years.

The report highlights two specific incidents in 2017, one involving Lester Sadict Cruz-Garcia, an immigrant from Honduras who was arrested by police in New York on a domestic assault charge. When ICE officers tried to apprehend him, he struggled and kicked, attempting to get away. He was eventually sentenced to 364 days in jail.

Another incident involved Mohammed Kenneh, who was being deported to Liberia. When ICE officers took him to Logan International Airport in Boston, he knocked one officer to the ground and used his handcuffs to ensnare the officer's hand, refusing to let go. The officer had to be taken to the emergency room.

The report notes that prosecutors often refuse to bring charges or win cases against the perpetrators, and that the government does not do a good job of tracking incidents, which may be underselling the problem. The report highlights the need for increased awareness and measures to address the growing trend of violence against ICE agents and Border Patrol agents.

Title: Tech Giants Apple and Google Join Forces to Develop Contact Tracing Software to Combat COVID-19

Article:

In an effort to help contain the spread of the coronavirus, tech giants Apple and Google have announced a joint project to develop software that assists in contact tracing. The technology aims to alert individuals who have come into contact with someone who has contracted COVID-19, helping to prevent further transmission of the virus.

Public health officials have identified contact tracing as a crucial tool in containing the spread of the virus, which can be transmitted through close proximity to affected individuals. To achieve this, Apple and Google will release application programming interfaces (APIs) and operating system-level technology to enable contact tracing.

The plan is to implement the solution in two stages. First, in May, the companies will release APIs that enable interoperability between Android and iOS devices using apps from public health authorities. These official apps will be available for users to download via their respective app stores. In the coming months, Apple and Google will work to enable a broader Bluetooth-based contact tracing platform by building this functionality into the underlying platforms.

While the technology has the potential to be a valuable tool in the fight against COVID-19, some experts have raised concerns about user privacy. Allahpundit, a writer for Hot Air, has expressed skepticism about the ability for users to truly "opt out" of the data collection process.

"If I understand that correctly, they're going to roll this out quickly by first providing it as an app available for download – called Contact Tracing, neatly enough," Allahpundit wrote. "Then, in stage two, they're going to build it right into the iOS and Android operating systems while providing some sort of option to opt out. That'll deliver the software to three billion people or so. An obvious early question: How thorough will the 'opt out' be, exactly? Given how much personal information is collected surreptitiously by tech companies already, it's impossible to believe that the movements of opt-outs won't be quietly tracked too."

The technology works by broadcasting different IDs every 30 minutes as someone goes about their day. If a person tests positive for COVID-19, the system would trace which IDs came into contact with the temporary IDs of the coronavirus-positive person and send them an alert that they may have interacted with someone who had COVID-19.

While the technology has the potential to be a valuable tool in the fight against COVID-19, widespread testing for the virus is still a major challenge.

**Senate Passes Sweeping Tax Overhaul, But Differences Remain**

The United States Senate has passed a comprehensive tax overhaul, a major step towards the Trump administration's first significant legislative victory. The bill, worth approximately $1.4 trillion, aims to provide tax cuts for working families across America. The vote was 51-49, with Republican Bob Corker of Tennessee being the only GOP member to side with Democrats in opposition.

The bill is not yet finalized, as the Senate and House must agree on a single piece of legislation before it reaches the president's desk. Negotiators from both chambers will start meeting on Monday to iron out differences.

The Senate bill eliminates federal deductions for state and local income and sales taxes, but allows deductions of up to $10,000 in local property taxes. It also nearly doubles the standard deduction level to $12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for couples. The bill retains the current limit for the home mortgage interest deduction to interest paid on the first $1 million of the loan.

The Senate bill also repeals the individual mandate under ObamaCare, which could lead to thousands of people dropping their health insurance, increasing costs for those who decide to keep it. The bill eliminates the $4,050 personal tax exemption and reduces the number of tax brackets from seven to ten.

For small business owners, the bill allows owners of "pass-through" businesses to deduct 23% of their earnings, and then pay at their personal income tax rate on the remainder. The bill also cuts the current 35% rate to 20%, with a one-year delay.

While the bill has been passed, differences between the Senate and House versions will need to be resolved. The House will vote on a motion to go to conference on the tax bills on Monday evening, with the Senate expected to follow suit soon after. If passed, the bill would come into effect on January 1.

The changes will not affect taxes for 2017, which are due to the IRS by April 17, 2018. The House is scheduled to adjourn for its Christmas break on December 15, but Speaker Paul Ryan has said he will keep the House in session beyond that date if necessary to get tax reform passed.

Title: Congressional Pressure Mounts for HHS Secretary to Testify on ObamaCare Website Issues

Article:

The controversy surrounding the ObamaCare website's troubled launch has led to a growing call for Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius to testify before Congress. Senator Dick Durbin, the chamber's second-highest-ranking Democrat, has stated that Sebelius will ultimately testify, but the exact date and details remain unclear.

The House Energy and Commerce Committee sent a letter to Sebelius last week, requesting her testimony on the matter, but she has yet to respond publicly. Her absence has sparked criticism from both sides of the aisle, with some lawmakers calling for her resignation. Florida Republican Senator Marco Rubio expressed reluctance to demand her immediate dismissal but emphasized that her refusal to testify has undermined her credibility.

House investigators want to know whether officials involved in the website's development knew about the problems or failed to disclose them, despite repeated assurances that the site was "on track" to launch. The White House has reported that 476,000 people have applied online for health insurance, but officials have yet to provide information on how many people have actually purchased a policy.

Missouri Republican Senator Roy Blunt believes Sebelius' position is "unsustainable" and that she will eventually have to testify. Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton has also pressed Sebelius to appear before Congress, citing her recent appearance on Comedy Central's "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart" as an example of her availability.

The controversy surrounding the ObamaCare website's launch has sparked a heated debate about accountability and transparency within the administration. As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen whether Sebelius will ultimately testify and provide answers to the many questions surrounding the website's troubled launch.

**Judge Criticizes Flynn for Lying to FBI, Delays Sentencing**

A U.S. judge has criticized former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn for lying to FBI agents about his conversations with Russia's ambassador, Sergei Kislyak, in 2016. The judge, Emmet Sullivan, delayed Flynn's sentencing, giving him the option to continue cooperating with investigators and potentially bolster his case for leniency.

Flynn, a retired U.S. Army lieutenant general and former director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his conversations with Kislyak, which took place between Trump's election victory and his inauguration in January 2017. The conversations were about U.S. sanctions imposed on Moscow by the Obama administration.

Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who led the investigation into possible collusion between Trump's campaign and Russia, had asked the judge not to sentence Flynn to prison, citing his cooperation with investigators. Flynn's plea agreement stated that he was eligible for a sentence of between zero and six months.

Sullivan sternly criticized Flynn's actions, saying he had "arguably betrayed his country" and noting that he had also lied to senior White House officials, who in turn misled the public. The judge said he had read additional facts about Flynn's behavior that have not been made public.

Flynn's attorney said he is cooperating with federal prosecutors in a case against his former business partner, Bijan Rafiekian, who has been charged with unregistered lobbying for Turkey. Rafiekian pleaded not guilty to the charges and is scheduled to go to trial in February.

The case has raised questions about Flynn's role in the Trump administration and his potential connections to Russia. Trump has denied any wrongdoing and has voiced support for Flynn, sparking speculation that he may pardon him.

The judge's decision to delay Flynn's sentencing gives him the opportunity to continue cooperating with investigators and potentially reduce his sentence. However, Sullivan did not set a new date for sentencing and asked Mueller's team and Flynn's attorney to provide a status report by March 13.

Title: California Wildfires: Death Toll Rises to 42, Thousands Flee as Fires Continue to Rage

Article:

California is reeling from the devastating impact of the state's deadliest wildfire, which has claimed 42 lives and left at least 228 people missing. The Camp Fire, which started in the north of the state, has destroyed nearly 7,200 structures and put another 15,500 at risk. The fire has surpassed the 1933 Griffith Park disaster that killed 31 people.

The remains of 13 more victims were found in and around the largely incinerated town of Paradise, with forensic experts working to identify the dead. The search efforts are expected to take weeks, with cadaver dogs and mobile army morgues being brought in to aid in the process.

The Woolsey Fire, which started in the south of the state, has killed two people and damaged beach resorts, including Malibu. The fire has forced more than 300,000 locals to flee their homes across California.

President Donald Trump has declared a "major disaster" in the state, making federal aid available to affected residents. The California Public Utilities Commission is investigating what sparked the latest blazes, with reports suggesting electrical companies may have suffered malfunctions near the sources shortly before the fires began.

The state's 40 million-strong population, which has doubled since the 1970s, has contributed to the fires' deadliness. People are living closer to at-risk forest areas, making evacuation more difficult for those with mobility issues.

Governor Jerry Brown has declared that the recent fires are not the new normal, but the new abnormal, citing the role of climate change. Recent years have produced record-breaking temperatures, earlier springs, and less reliable rainfall, creating a prime fire-spreading environment.

Thousands of firefighters, some from across the US, have been brought in to help battle the blazes. The fire has burned more than 111,000 acres and is nearly 25% contained, with the Woolsey Fire consuming at least 85,500 acres and the Hill Fire scorching 4,530 acres.

Title: Lawmakers Weigh In on Impeachment Proceedings and Congressional Accountability

Article:

In a recent discussion, lawmakers weighed in on the ongoing investigation and potential impeachment proceedings against the current administration. The conversation centered around the Mueller report and its findings, which some believe indicate obstruction of justice by the president and his administration.

Some lawmakers emphasized the importance of Congress taking action, citing the need for accountability and the use of the impeachment process as a tool to achieve it. They argued that if any other individual had engaged in similar behavior, they would face consequences, and it is the responsibility of Congress to hold the president accountable.

Others, however, believe that the investigation should continue and that the Mueller report should be thoroughly examined before any impeachment proceedings are considered. They emphasized the need for a comprehensive investigation and the subpoenaing of individuals mentioned in the report to get to the truth.

The discussion also touched on the upcoming elections in November 2020, with some suggesting that the American people will have the opportunity to decide the fate of the current administration through the ballot box.

In conclusion, the lawmakers acknowledged that the impeachment proceedings are ultimately up to the House, but emphasized the importance of a thorough investigation and the need for accountability.

Title: The Visceral Appeal of Destruction: Understanding the Root of Unruliness

Article:

The recent riots in Minneapolis have sparked a national conversation about the role of police reform and the need for accountability. As a society, we must acknowledge that destruction, whether it's smashing glass or setting fires, is a primal urge that can be difficult to resist. This visceral appeal to destruction is not unique to any particular group or demographic; it's a fundamental human instinct that can be triggered by a variety of factors.

However, the destruction of property and the harm it causes is never justified, regardless of the underlying motivations. The real issue is not the destruction itself, but the systemic problems that lead to it. The Minneapolis police department's failure to discipline its own officers and address systemic issues of racism and bias is a prime example of this.

The recent video of a police officer kneeling on the neck of a handcuffed and unarmed George Floyd, leading to his death, is a stark reminder of the need for police reform. While the officer's actions were egregious, it's also important to recognize that the failure of his colleagues to intervene and the department's lack of accountability are equally problematic.

The Minneapolis police union's decision to stand behind the fired officers and hire expensive lawyers to defend them is a clear indication that job protection is prioritized over character. The community has a right to expect more from its police department, and the department must take responsibility for its failures.

The spread of protests across the country is a sign that police reform remains a pressing issue that requires sustained attention and commitment. The public must demand accountability from their police departments, and the departments must take concrete steps to address systemic issues and root out bad apples.

Ultimately, the key to preventing future riots is not to suppress the urge to destruction, but to address the underlying issues that lead to it. By working together to create a more just and equitable society, we can reduce the likelihood of destructive behavior and build a brighter future for all.

Title: Sen. Feinstein Engages in Heated Exchange with Children Over Climate Change Policy

Article:

Senator Dianne Feinstein, a moderate Democrat, faced off with a group of children on Friday over the Green New Deal, a 10-year plan to mitigate climate change. The exchange was marked by a clash of opinions and a display of frustration from both sides.

Feinstein criticized the children for presenting an ultimatum and accused them of not understanding the complexities of the issue. She emphasized that she has three decades of experience in office and knows what it takes to pass legislation. The senator expressed her concerns about the Green New Deal, citing its lack of a clear plan for funding and the fact that it does not have a single Republican supporter.

The children, who were passionate about the issue, urged Feinstein to support the deal, despite her reservations. One young woman pointed out that the consequences of climate change will be felt by future generations, to which Feinstein responded that she has been working on the issue for 30 years and knows what she is doing.

The conversation grew heated at times, with Feinstein dismissing the children's requests and telling them to consider running for office themselves. The senator also emphasized that she has been elected by a significant margin and knows what it takes to pass legislation.

Despite the tension, the meeting ended with some of the children staying behind to chat with Feinstein, including a 16-year-old who expressed interest in internship opportunities in the senator's office. Feinstein acknowledged that she welcomes the opportunity to hear from Californians who are passionate about the issue and remains committed to enacting meaningful climate change legislation.

The exchange highlights the ongoing debate within the Democratic Party over the Green New Deal and the best approach to addressing climate change. While some lawmakers, like Feinstein, are skeptical of the plan's feasibility, others see it as a necessary step towards a more sustainable future.

**Charlotte, NC - A Recap of the 2012 DNC's Second Night**

The second night of the 2012 Democratic National Convention saw a mix of speeches from various politicians and activists, with some notable highlights and low points. Former President Bill Clinton's address was a major highlight, but the evening was also marked by some underwhelming performances.

The evening's lineup was unremarkable until Bill Clinton took the stage, delivering a stemwinder that kept viewers engaged. However, the hours leading up to his speech were filled with retreads from Nancy Pelosi and Steny Hoyer, as well as speeches from abortion proponents, union bosses, and unremarkable politicians.

One notable speaker was Sandra Fluke, a recent law graduate who spoke about birth control and abortion. While some may see her as a hero, her speech was criticized for being surly and self-pitying. Her claims of being a courageous victim and her demagoguery about women "dying" under the Romney/Ryan plan were seen as unseemly and crass.

Jim Sinegal, the former CEO of Costco, spoke about the benefits of Democrats for business, but his speech was dull and unmemorable. Elizabeth Warren, a Harvard Law professor, led the class warfare fight, calling for higher levels of government "investment" in various sectors. While her delivery was slightly improved, her message was characteristic and reprehensible.

Bill Clinton's speech was a highlight of the evening, making the best case available to Obama backers. He argued that things were really bad when Obama took office, but he's done as well as anyone possibly could have, and things are starting to get better. However, his 48-minute speech was criticized for being too long and meandering, with some parts feeling like a fact-checker-in-chief.

The evening's speakers were not without controversy, with some criticizing Clinton's Republican blaming and lack of acknowledgment of Democratic majorities in the past. Despite this, the partisan crowd lapped up every last word, and Obama's team is counting on Clinton's decade-old legacy to save him from his own challenges.

Overall, the second night of the DNC saw a mix of highs and lows, with some speakers shining brighter than others. While Clinton's speech was a highlight, the evening was marked by some underwhelming performances and controversy.

Title: FBI Investigation into Hillary Clinton's Handling of State Secrets Raises Concerns

Article:

The FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's handling of state secrets has raised concerns about her potential criminal liability. The latest revelations suggest that Clinton received a top-secret email, denominated as a Special Access Program (SAP), on her husband's non-secure server. This raises questions about her compliance with her legal obligations to safeguard state secrets.

The SAP designation is the highest level of classification, and the FBI has strict protocols in place to ensure its secrecy. The fact that Clinton received this information on her non-secure server, without proper clearance or authorization, is a serious breach of protocol.

Clinton's defenders argue that she may not have known what she was doing, citing her lack of technical expertise. However, this is not a viable defense. As a former Secretary of State, Clinton was required to undergo an FBI briefing on the lawfully required care and keeping of state secrets. She signed an oath under penalty of perjury, acknowledging her responsibility to safeguard these secrets.

The FBI is investigating not only Clinton's handling of state secrets but also her potential use of her position to advance her husband's charitable foundation. The presence of SAP-denominated emails on her husband's server, whether opened or not, suggests a lack of regard for her legal obligations.

The FBI's investigation has uncovered other concerning evidence, including an email instructing subordinates to cut and paste and summarize state secrets, which is a felony. Additionally, a former aide revealed that Clinton and her staff regularly discussed state secrets on their BlackBerries, which were not government-issued and not secured.

The FBI's investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen what conclusions they will draw. However, the evidence suggests that Clinton may have failed to safeguard state secrets, which could have serious consequences. The rule of law in America demands accountability, and the FBI's investigation will help determine whether Clinton's actions meet the standards of the law.

Title: Romney Embarks on Six-State Bus Tour, Focuses on Connecting with Middle-Class Voters

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, kicked off his six-state bus tour in Pennsylvania on Saturday, aiming to connect with middle-class voters and restore the American Dream. The tour, which will take him to battleground states Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa, is his first traditional campaign bus tour.

Romney's first stop was the Weatherly Casting and Machine Company, where he shared a story about a local entrepreneur who took out a second mortgage to start a business that now employs about 110 people. "Let's put America back to work again with those kinds of dreams," he said, emphasizing his optimism about the future.

The candidate's tour will continue to other battleground states, with stops in Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa. Romney's second stop in Pennsylvania was moved to a nearby Agway convenience store after a counter rally was held by former Democratic Gov. Ed Rendell.

Romney was forced to respond to President Obama's announcement to suspend deportation for hundreds of thousands of young, illegal immigrants, saying that an executive order makes reaching a long-term solution more difficult. "If I'm elected president, we'll do our best to have the long-term solution," he said.

The bus tour is a departure from Romney's previous campaign, which focused on social media and online advertising. This time, he is taking a more traditional approach, meeting voters in person and shaking hands. He will be joined by former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, both considered potential running mates.

Pennsylvania has not been a Republican stronghold since 1988, but Romney is hoping to change that. He will visit counties that were won by Republican nominee John McCain in 2008. However, he faces pressure to appeal to Hispanic voters, who will be crucial in battleground states like Nevada and Colorado, without alienating his conservative base.

Overall, Romney's bus tour aims to connect with middle-class voters and restore the American Dream, while also addressing the concerns of illegal immigration and the economy.

Title: Walmart Enters the Healthcare Market with Transparent Pricing

Article:

Walmart, the retail giant, has opened its first in-store clinic in Dallas, Georgia, offering primary medical, dental, vision, and mental health care services. The new clinic, Walmart Health, is a pilot project that aims to provide basic healthcare services to Americans at an affordable price. What sets Walmart apart is its transparent pricing model, where customers can know exactly what each service costs.

The pricing list shows that basic check-ups will cost $30 (or $20 for kids), while getting tested for the flu will cost $20, and having a routine vision exam will be $40. The clinic will be staffed with medical professionals capable of handling everything from immunizations to counseling sessions to lab testing to X-rays.

Walmart's entry into the healthcare market is a significant development, as it joins CVS and Walgreens in offering small-scale clinics in some retail locations. The new clinic is a big step forward for Walmart, which has already opened smaller clinics in 19 stores to offer flu shots and other basic healthcare services. The new clinic is over 10,000 square feet, a significant increase from the average 1,500 square feet of the smaller clinics.

The move is also a sign of how private-sector healthcare is innovating to reach Americans where they live and shop. With Walmart's entry into the market, it could be a huge victory for competition and convenience.

Elise Amez-Droz, a healthcare policy associate at the Mercatus Center, a think tank based at George Mason University, says, "Walmart Health is proof that the private sector can deliver high-quality, transparently priced healthcare services without government intervention. The best way to cater to our varying needs is to let patients have the final say in their healthcare decisions, shopping for better value and reaping the benefits in the form of better care and savings."

Access to healthcare is an often-overlooked part of the national debate over healthcare, which tends to focus on providing insurance rather than healthcare itself. Insurance is important, of course, but the best insurance in the world is useless if there are no providers nearby. Walmart and other retailers are helping to solve part of the access issue with these new clinics. About 90 percent of the U.S. population lives within 10 miles of a Walmart store.

The pricing model Walmart is rolling out could also smash convention. Though the retail chain says it will accept most major insurance plans, the low, transparent prices will allow many customers to pay out-of-pocket for basic care. This is a potentially huge change, as the lack of transparency in healthcare prices, largely the result of third parties, like insurance companies, serving as intermediaries between consumer and provider, encourages the inflation of healthcare costs and the overconsumption of healthcare. Insurance may always be necessary to cover big expenses, but there's no good reason for Americans not to understand how much a simple visit to the doctor's office will cost before they arrive.

While a single Walmart health clinic may not fix all the problems with the American healthcare system, it's a significant step in the right direction. With its efficient and successful business model, Walmart is likely to come up with innovative solutions to improve healthcare access and affordability.

**Attorney General Sessions to Testify Before Senate Intelligence Committee Amid Controversy**

Attorney General Jeff Sessions is set to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday, amidst growing controversy surrounding his potential contacts with Russian officials during the 2016 presidential campaign. The hearing comes just days after former FBI Director James Comey's bombshell testimony, which raised questions about Sessions' involvement in the Russia investigation.

Sessions' testimony is expected to focus on his meetings with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, which Comey revealed in his testimony. The former FBI director claimed that Sessions may have had a third, undisclosed meeting with Kislyak, which would contradict Sessions' previous statements about his interactions with the Russian official.

The White House has sent mixed signals about Sessions' willingness to cooperate with lawmakers. While White House counselor Kellyanne Conway said Sessions is "willing to cooperate and share what he knows," Press Secretary Sean Spicer declined to rule out the possibility of Sessions invoking executive privilege during his testimony.

Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the Russia investigation has also come under scrutiny. Comey testified that the FBI had expected Sessions to step back from the investigation even before his recusal on March 2. The Justice Department has denied that Sessions had any private conversations with Russian officials, including Kislyak, during the Mayflower Hotel meeting in April 2016.

The hearing is expected to delve into Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the investigation, as well as reports that he offered to resign. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein told lawmakers that Sessions was involved in discussions about replacing Comey, which could raise questions about Sessions' involvement in the Russia investigation.

Democrats are likely to press Sessions on reports that he knew about Trump's plan to fire Comey, which could have implications for his recusal decision. Sessions' testimony is expected to be closely watched, as it could shed light on the extent of his involvement in the Russia investigation and his relationship with Trump.

Title: Obama Reflects on Political Polarization and the 2016 Election

In a joint press conference with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, President Barack Obama addressed the 2016 election and the unprecedented political polarization that has characterized the current political climate. When asked about his role in the rise of provocative candidates like Donald Trump, Obama emphasized that he does not believe he is responsible for the Republican Party's primary process and the selection of its candidates.

"I've been blamed by the Republicans for a lot of things, but to be blamed for their primaries and who they are selecting is... novel," Obama said. "I don't think I was the one to prompt questions about my birth certificate, for example. I don't recall saying, 'Hey, why don't you ask me about that.'"

Obama acknowledged that he has expressed regret over the increasing polarization and nasty tone of politics during his presidency, but he also emphasized that the Republican Party's political elites, information outlets, social media, television stations, and talk radio have contributed to this environment. "There's a notion that everything I do is to be opposed, that cooperation or compromise somehow is a betrayal, that maximalist absolutist positions on issues are politically advantageous," he said.

Obama noted that this environment has created a space for candidates like Trump to thrive. "He's just doing more of what has been done for the last seven and a half years, and, in fact, in terms of his positions on a whole range of issues, they're not very different from any of the other candidates," he said.

When asked about his own role in the rise of Trump, Obama emphasized that he does not believe he is responsible for the Republican Party's primary process and the selection of its candidates. "I don't think I was the one to prompt questions about my birth certificate, for example. I don't recall saying, 'Hey, why don't you ask me about that.' Why don't you question whether I'm American or whether I'm loyal or whether I have America's best interests at heart," he said.

Overall, Obama's comments highlighted the complex and multifaceted nature of political polarization, emphasizing that it is not solely the responsibility of one individual or party.

Title: Acting Attorney General Whitaker Testifies Before House Committee Amid Tensions Over Russia Probe Oversight

Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker faced intense questioning from lawmakers during a contentious House hearing on Friday, as Democrats pressed him on his oversight of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. The hearing was marked by a series of tense exchanges and disagreements between Whitaker and Democratic lawmakers, with some Republicans criticizing the proceedings as a "dog and pony show."

Whitaker's testimony was the first major oversight hearing on the Justice Department by the House Judiciary Committee this Congress. The acting attorney general was asked whether he had been asked to approve any requests or actions related to the Mueller probe, and he responded that he had not interfered in any way with the investigation.

However, the hearing was marked by Whitaker's refusal to answer several questions, including whether he had shared information about the investigation with President Trump or any White House officials. He also declined to provide direct answers to questions about his conversations with the president and other officials.

The hearing was the culmination of a dramatic political prelude, with the Justice Department threatening to boycott the hearing and Democrats warning that they would subpoena Whitaker if he did not cooperate. The committee chairman, Jerrold Nadler, repeatedly pressed Whitaker to provide more information about his oversight of the Mueller probe, but the acting attorney general refused to budge.

The hearing comes as the Senate is close to confirming President Trump's nominee for attorney general, William Barr, and as the Russia investigation is reportedly nearing its conclusion. Whitaker's testimony was closely watched by lawmakers and the public alike, with many seeking answers about the status of the investigation and the role of the Justice Department in overseeing it.

In the end, the hearing ended with Nadler requesting that Whitaker return to the committee at a later date, saying that he did not believe issuing a subpoena would correct the problem. The committee will attempt to reach an accommodation with the department to receive answers from Whitaker, who will be required to testify under oath.

**Supreme Court Rules Bladensburg Peace Cross Can Remain, But Leaves Hundreds of Other Memorials in Limbo**

In a closely watched decision, the Supreme Court ruled that the Bladensburg Peace Cross, a 40-foot Latin cross standing on public park land in Prince George's County, Maryland, can remain, citing its special significance as a war memorial and expression of community grief. The ruling was a test of religious freedom, with the court ultimately deciding that the cross has earned "special significance" over the years and removing it would be an affront to the community and the First Amendment.

The court's 7-2 decision was written by Justice Samuel A. Alito, who emphasized that the cross has been consecrated by nearly 100 years of public devotion and is an important reminder of honor, bravery, and sacrifice. Justice Stephen G. Breyer agreed with the main ruling, stating that the case would have been different if there had been evidence that the American Legion erected the cross in an attempt to disparage or disrespect people in faiths other than Christianity.

However, the ruling did not provide clarity on hundreds of other religion-themed memorials across the country, leaving them to be fought over one by one. Justice Breyer noted that each memorial must be taken on its own facts and that Thursday's opinion does not guarantee they are all permissible.

The ruling was a blow to the "Lemon test," the Supreme Court's 1971 framework for deciding religion-state entanglements, which required courts to look at whether a government action advanced or endorsed religion. Justice Alito suggested that there should be a "presumption of constitutionality for long-standing monuments" on public grounds, but this was not universally accepted by the court.

The decision was met with mixed reactions from religious liberty advocates and those who advocate for the separation of church and state. Religious liberty advocates hailed the decision as a landmark, while those who advocate for the separation of church and state called it "misguided" and a threat to the First Amendment's neutrality principle.

The American Humanist Association, which challenged the cross, took solace in the court's limited ruling, saying it feared the justices would overturn the Lemon test and pave the way for even broader religious displays by government. Americans United for Separation of Church and State called the decision "misguided," saying it gives the government permission to play favorites when it comes to religion.

The ruling has left many questions unanswered, including what the effect will be on hundreds of other cross-style memorials on public lands across the country.

Title: Supreme Court's End-of-Term Crunch: A Study Reveals the Truth Behind the Trend

Article:

A recent study published in The Duke Law Journal has shed light on the long-standing phenomenon of the Supreme Court's end-of-term crunch, where the most significant cases tend to be decided in the final days of the term. The study, which analyzed 7,219 cases from 1946 to 2013, aimed to determine whether big cases are disproportionately likely to come late.

The study's findings confirmed what many have observed anecdotally: big cases are indeed more likely to be decided in late June. The researchers used several measures to define significance, including front-page coverage, the number of friend-of-the-court briefs filed, and how often the decision was cited in later Supreme Court opinions. Each of these measures supported the conclusion that big decisions are more likely to come in late June.

The study's results may seem surprising, given that more than 30% of the court's decisions are issued in June, with over half of those coming in the last week of the month. However, the question is not whether any particular case is more likely to be decided late in the term, but rather whether big cases are disproportionately likely to come late.

According to Geoffrey R. Stone, a law professor at the University of Chicago who served as a clerk to Justice William J. Brennan Jr., the court's tendency to decide big cases at the end of the term is "inconceivable." Deanne E. Maynard, a lawyer with Morrison & Foerster who served as a law clerk to Justices Lewis F. Powell Jr. and Stephen G. Breyer, attributes the phenomenon to human nature, stating that the court uses as much time as it has to decide the really important cases.

The study's findings provide valuable insights into the Supreme Court's decision-making process, highlighting the importance of considering multiple measures of significance when evaluating the court's decisions. The results also underscore the significance of the court's end-of-term crunch, which may be driven by a combination of factors, including human nature and the court's desire to address the most pressing issues.

**US-Iran Tensions Escalate as Trump and Rouhani Exchange Blows**

In a dramatic escalation of tensions between the United States and Iran, President Donald Trump and Iranian President Hassan Rouhani exchanged heated words over the weekend. Trump issued a late-night tweet, warning Iran to "NEVER, EVER THREATEN THE UNITED STATES AGAIN," while Rouhani responded by urging Trump to "not play with the lion's tail, this would only lead to regret."

The exchange comes as the US prepares to reimpose economic sanctions on Iran, which were lifted as part of the 2015 nuclear deal. The sanctions, set to take effect on August 4, are expected to have a significant impact on Iran's economy.

Trump's tweet was met with support from his administration, with White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders saying the president was not inciting a confrontation, but rather standing up to Iran's "demented words of violence and death." National Security Adviser John Bolton echoed Trump's sentiments, stating that Iran would "pay a price like few countries have ever paid before" if it takes any negative action against the US.

In Iran, government officials downplayed Trump's tweet, with the head of the Basij paramilitary force, Gholamhossein Gharibpour, calling it "merely psychological warfare." Foaz Izadi, a prominent commentator close to the establishment, suggested that Trump's tweet was designed to appeal to his base in the US, ahead of the November elections.

The exchange is the latest development in a long-standing feud between the two countries. Trump withdrew the US from the Iran nuclear deal in May, and the US has since reimposed sanctions on Iran. The US Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, has been vocal in his criticism of Iran, calling its ruling elite a "mafia" and accusing them of amassing vast sums of wealth while allowing their people to suffer.

Pompeo's remarks were aimed in part at Iranian-Americans and Iranians living in the US, assuring them that the Trump administration shares their dreams for the people of Iran. He also expressed support for those Iranians who have protested against their government's actions and called its response "brutal."

As the situation continues to escalate, it remains to be seen how the international community will respond to the growing tensions between the US and Iran.

Title: Millennials' Incomes Stagnate Amidst Economic Uncertainty

Article:

The job market has been challenging for millennials, who entered the workforce during a period of economic downturn.
