"The biggest difference with Perry was, he was kind of like a Roman emperor coming into town with horns blowing in front of his arrival, his parade," said Doug Whitley, the president and CEO of the Illinois Chamber of Commerce.

As Perry looks to announce his next political move after the Texas legislative session concludes, his jobs recruitment efforts have become a hot topic of discussion. With his current gubernatorial term up in 2014, some speculate that he may be eyeing a 2016 presidential run. Whatever his plans may be, one thing is certain: Perry's aggressive approach to job recruitment has sparked a national conversation about the best way to create jobs and grow the economy.

**Tsarnaev's Condition Improves, New Details Emerge on Brothers' Plans**

The medical condition of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the 19-year-old suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, has improved, according to hospital officials. The update came on Tuesday, when his condition was upgraded from serious to fair. Tsarnaev has been held at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center under heavy guard since his capture on Thursday night.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for Massachusetts confirmed the change in Tsarnaev's condition, citing information from the hospital. The news comes as new details emerge about the brothers' plans had they not been captured or killed by authorities.

According to a carjacking victim, the brothers were planning to head to New York City. The victim, who was carjacked by the brothers, told authorities that most of their conversation was conducted in Russian, with the only recognizable word being "Manhattan."

Tsarnaev's condition has been a topic of interest since his capture, with the criminal complaint against him indicating that he suffered wounds to his head, neck, leg, and hand. He was arraigned on two terrorism-related charges on Monday, during which he nodded his head in answering questions and responded "no" when asked if he had enough money to hire an attorney.

Tsarnaev's next court hearing is scheduled for May 30.

Title: US Employment Sees First Decline in Seven Years Amid Hurricane-Related Job Losses

Article:

The US labor market experienced a rare decline in September, with 33,000 jobs lost, according to the Labor Department. This marks the first time employment has fallen since 2010. The decline was largely attributed to the impact of hurricanes Harvey and Irma, which struck Texas and Florida in late August and early September.

The leisure and hospitality sector was particularly affected, with a significant drop in employment. However, the unemployment rate slipped to 4.2%, the lowest since February 2001, despite the job losses. Economists had expected a rise of 90,000 jobs last month.

The discrepancy between the payrolls data and the unemployment rate suggests that the job decline may not indicate a long-term trend. Gus Faucher, chief economist at PNC Financial Services, noted that "although the headline number for September is a loss of jobs, the labor market remains in good shape."

The strongest job gains were seen in the health care and transportation and warehousing industries. Employment in construction and government sectors remained largely unchanged. The US has been experiencing a prolonged period of job creation, with an average of over 170,000 jobs added per month over the past year. However, economists have predicted that this pace is unsustainable and has been slow to translate into wage gains.

The September report showed a 0.5% increase in average hourly earnings from August, and a 2.9% rise over the past 12 months. While some economists believe this figure suggests job market slack is fading, others attribute it to the unusual hurricane-related job decline in the low-wage food industry.

Despite the job losses, economists do not see anything in the September report that would dissuade the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates before the end of the year, as expected. Ian Shepherdson of Pantheon Macroeconomics noted that "unemployment is what matters, and this report makes a December rate hike even more likely." Revised jobs estimates for July and August showed that employers added 38,000 fewer jobs than previously reported, but Shepherdson expects a rebound to begin in October, with a bigger rebound in November.

**House Republicans Gear Up for Final Push on Healthcare Reform**

Washington D.C. - House Republicans are preparing for a crucial three-day push to pass a bill repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. President Trump will personally urge House Republicans to rally behind the legislation, which has been met with criticism from both sides of the aisle.

The bill, which has been amended to set aside $75 billion to help individuals buying insurance on their own, is expected to be voted on Thursday. However, the House Freedom Caucus, a group of over 30 Republicans, remains a significant obstacle to the bill's passage.

President Trump will meet with House Republicans to lobby for support, particularly from conservatives who feel the bill does not go far enough and centrists who are concerned about the impact on older Americans whose premiums would rise under the GOP plan.

The bill, which would repeal most of Obamacare's taxes and replace its subsidies with refundable, age-based tax credits, has been criticized by Democrats and some Republicans alike. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the plan would save more than $300 billion but result in 24 million fewer people being insured a decade from now.

Despite the challenges, House Speaker Paul Ryan and his chief aides are counting on President Trump's role as the ultimate "closer" to fulfill their seven-year pledge to kill Obamacare and maintain momentum to overhaul the tax code before the summer recess.

The bill's passage is crucial for Republicans, who cannot lose more than 21 GOP votes. The House Rules Committee will meet early Wednesday to vet final changes to the bill and set the terms of debate for floor votes on Thursday.

As the debate continues, Democrats are rallying against the bill, with former Vice President Joe Biden set to visit the Capitol on Wednesday to defend Obamacare. The bill's implementation is expected to be a complex process, with the House likely to revisit the plan down the road.

The stakes are high, with the bill's passage seen as a test of President Trump's ability to deliver on his campaign promises and the Republican Party's ability to govern.

Title: Thousands of Students and Community Members Flock to Charlotte for Obama's Democratic Nomination Speech

Article:

As the Democratic National Convention comes to a close, thousands of students and community members from across North Carolina and neighboring South Carolina are converging on Charlotte to witness President Obama's acceptance speech on Thursday night. The event is expected to draw a capacity crowd to the 74,000-seat Bank of America Stadium, with many more tickets still available for the public.

College students from across the state, including 100 students from Duke University, will be arriving in Charlotte by the busload to attend the speech. Additionally, members of predominantly black churches in South Carolina are also planning to send busloads of members to the event. The NAACP's South Carolina chapter president, Lonnie Randolph, expressed excitement about the opportunity for his members to attend the speech, stating, "There are plenty of people who wouldn't miss it for the world. How often does this happen this close to South Carolina?"

The Obama campaign has been working to fill the remaining seats, with thousands of tickets given to new campaign volunteers in North Carolina. The volunteer ticketing program not only helps Obama boost his grassroots network in the state but also provides an opportunity for people to be a part of this historic event.

While some have expressed concerns about voter enthusiasm and attendance, Obama's campaign insists that the stadium will be filled on Thursday night. Vice President Joe Biden and Massachusetts Senator John Kerry will also be speaking at the event, which is expected to bring the election into focus for the American people.

The event is not without its challenges, with heavy rain and thunderstorms forecasted for Thursday. However, convention organizers are prepared to host the event rain or shine, except in the case of severe weather.

Overall, the excitement and enthusiasm among attendees is palpable, with many seeing this as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to be a part of history. As Adam Fetcher, a campaign spokesman, noted, "The response we've seen from the community has been incredible, and it's obvious that people have a big interest in owning a piece of the most open and accessible convention in history."

Title: Governor Christie's Visit with President Obama: A Gesture of Leadership or Politics?

Article:

Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey's recent visit with President Barack Obama has sparked speculation about the political implications of their meeting. While some see it as a gesture of leadership and a demonstration of the governor's commitment to helping those affected by Hurricane Sandy, others believe it may be a calculated move to boost his own political profile.

Romney aides were quick to downplay the significance of the visit, saying that Governor Christie is focused on his job and not looking at it through a political lens. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney echoed this sentiment, stating that the visit was a time to focus on the devastating storm and its aftermath, rather than a political event.

However, Governor Christie's actions and statements suggest that he may be playing politics. He has been critical of the Democratic-controlled State Legislature for not allowing him to raise fines on utilities that do not respond quickly enough to power failures, and he has also picked a fight with the Democratic mayor of Atlantic City. Additionally, his approval ratings are high in New Jersey, but President Obama's are higher, which may have played a role in his decision to accept the president's invitation.

Despite these concerns, some Republicans close to Mitt Romney believe that Governor Christie would have been accused of playing politics if he had declined the president's invitation. They argue that he would have been seen as uncooperative and unwilling to put aside politics.

As the governor and the president flew over the devastated Jersey Shore, at least one resident seemed to be staying on message, with a sign reading "ROMNEY" etched in the sand. While Governor Christie's visit with President Obama may have been seen as a gesture of leadership, it also raises questions about his motivations and whether he is using the disaster to further his own political ambitions.

**Title:** Democratic Presidential Hopefuls to Make Their Mark at SXSW

**Article:**

The South by Southwest (SXSW) festival in Austin, Texas, is set to host a gathering of 2020 Democratic presidential hopefuls this weekend. The event, which combines music, film, and technology, provides an opportunity for the candidates to connect with young voters and showcase their policies.

Sens. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) will take the stage on Saturday, while former San Antonio Mayor Julian Castro, Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper, and Washington Gov. Jay Inslee will speak on Sunday. Former Rep. Beto O'Rourke, who has not yet announced his presidential bid, is expected to attend a film premiere about his 2018 Senate campaign against Sen. Ted Cruz.

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), a rising star within the party, will be interviewed onstage on Saturday night. Texas is an early primary state for Democrats, but it remains a red state in presidential elections. However, O'Rourke's close race against Cruz suggests that the state could be shifting towards being a purple state.

By attending SXSW, the 2020 contenders aim to not only share their messages on universal healthcare and deficit reduction but also to appear cool and connect with enthusiastic young voters who can help propel their campaigns forward. The event also provides an opportunity for the Democratic National Committee to showcase its efforts to win the 2020 election.

According to Democratic National Committee Chair Tom Perez, events like SXSW are crucial in the lead-up to the campaign. "It's become an iconic national event, and I wanted to make sure people understood what we're doing at the Democratic Party to win," Perez said. He also highlighted the 2018 Texas Senate race as a sign that Texas could be up for grabs for Democrats: "Texas is very much in play for Democrats. We made tremendous progress."

**Supreme Court Rules Wyoming Can't Abrogate 1868 Treaty with Crow Tribe**

In a landmark decision, the US Supreme Court has ruled that Wyoming cannot abrogate a 1868 treaty with the Crow Tribe, guaranteeing American Indians' hunting rights on some federal lands. The ruling, which contradicts a century-old high court precedent, could have significant implications for American Indian-U.S. relations and guarantee hunting rights on federal lands.

The case was brought by Clayvin Herrera, a member of the Crow Tribe, who was charged with offseason hunting in 2014 after state officials discovered him and other tribe members hunting bull elk on the Big Horn National Forest. Herrera argued that he was permitted to hunt on the land, citing the treaty that guaranteed American Indians the right to hunt on unoccupied lands of the United States so long as game may be found thereon.

The Crow Tribe signed the treaty in 1868, handing over roughly 30 million acres to settlers while retaining about 8 million acres. Wyoming argued that the treaty expired when it gained statehood in 1890, but the justices, in a 5-4 ruling, sided with Herrera, saying the treaty is good law.

Justice Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trump's replacement for the late Justice Antonin Scalia, sided with the court's four Democratic-appointed justices. "There simply is no evidence that Congress intended to abrogate the 1868 treaty right through the Wyoming Statehood Act," Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote in the court's 22-page opinion. "Nor is there any evidence in the treaty itself that Congress intended the hunting right to expire at statehood, or that the Crow Tribe would have understood it to do so."

Advocates for Herrera said the ruling is significant because other tribes have similar treaties with the U.S., and the decision gives them broader access to national forests. Forrest Tahdooahnippah, a lawyer who specializes in tribal issues, said the decision gives "life" to the rights of American Indians by overruling the prior precedent.

The high court rejected Wyoming's arguments that the language of the treaty, which said it applied to "unoccupied lands," was no longer applicable once the land was designated as a national forest. The court also rejected the state's argument that statehood was a critical element in determining the treaty's expiration.

The four dissenting justices, led by Justice Samuel A. Alito, argued that the majority was ignoring a clear precedent - a similar case in 1895 involving the same treaty language and the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes. The court then ruled that the tribes' right to hunt was terminated when Wyoming gained statehood.

Title: US Automakers Face New Rules, But Investment Uncertainty Remains

Article:

The United States has introduced new rules for automakers, requiring them to produce at least 75% of a vehicle's content in North America to qualify for zero tariffs. This change is part of the successor to the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which still awaits congressional ratification. While the new rules may encourage some investment in the US, experts believe that most vehicles will still be able to meet the new thresholds easily.

According to Kristin Dziczek, vice president for industry, labor, and economics at the Center for Automotive Research, the changes will not significantly encourage investment in the US. "Most vehicles are going to be able to get over those new thresholds pretty easily," she said. Even if the administration were to raise tariffs on foreign car imports, spurring investment in the US, automakers would still be cautious due to the volatility of President Trump's trade policies.

The auto industry has seen some growth under President Trump's watch, with employment increasing to around one million in November 2018 from 955,800 in January 2017. However, the number of vehicles manufactured in the US has continued to decline, despite a slight uptick last summer. The Reshoring Initiative reports that announcements to increase investment or move companies back to the US peaked in 2016.

In other news, President Trump has renegotiated the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) and a bilateral trade deal with South Korea. The revised USMCA strengthens intellectual property rights in Canada, while the deal with South Korea was modest. The Trump administration has also imposed tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese products due to Beijing's alleged unfair trade practices, including violations of American intellectual property rights. The two sides are currently in talks over a trade deal to resolve the dispute.

In a separate development, President Trump signed the "Right to Try" legislation into law in May, allowing terminally ill patients to seek access to experimental medicine that is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). This law allows patients, with the approval of their doctor, to ask drug companies directly for access to experimental treatments, rather than waiting for FDA approval. The FDA notes that it authorizes 99% of compassionate use requests, also known as expanded access, which has been in place since the 1970s.

**Defense Policy Bill Clears Senate Hurdle, Heads to President's Desk**

The Senate has overcome a filibuster and passed the annual defense policy bill, sending it to the White House for consideration. The bill, known as the National Defense Authorization Act, authorizes defense spending and sets policy for the Pentagon for the fiscal year. It includes provisions to raise troops' pay, set rules for Guantanamo Bay detainees, and authorize funding for various military programs.

The bill's passage marks a significant victory for Republicans, who are pushing for increased defense spending. However, the bill is not without controversy, as it includes provisions that would allow the Pentagon to arm personnel at military recruitment centers and restore authority for a next-generation missile defense program.

The bill's passage also sets up a potential showdown with President Obama, who has threatened to veto the bill if it does not include additional funding for domestic programs. The White House has expressed concerns about the bill's restrictions on transferring Guantanamo Bay detainees to other countries and its failure to address the sequester caps.

The bill's passage in the Senate was achieved through a 73-26 vote, with 21 Democrats siding with Republicans to overcome a filibuster. The House of Representatives passed the bill last week, but fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to override a potential presidential veto.

The bill's passage sets the stage for a battle over government spending for fiscal year 2016. Republicans are pushing for increased defense spending, while Democrats are insisting that any increases be matched by equivalent increases in domestic spending. The White House has expressed concerns about the bill's impact on the national debt and has threatened to veto it if it does not include additional funding for domestic programs.

The bill's passage is a significant development in the ongoing debate over government spending and national security. As the bill heads to the President's desk, lawmakers will continue to negotiate over the details of the bill and the broader issues surrounding government spending and national security.

**Title:** President Trump Honors 9/11 Victims, First Responders, and Military on 16th Anniversary

**Article:**

President Donald Trump marked the 16th anniversary of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on Monday, paying tribute to the victims, first responders, and military personnel who were affected by the tragic events. The president delivered remarks at the Pentagon, emphasizing the nation's resolve to keep the United States safe from future attacks.

Trump acknowledged the resilience of the American people, stating that the attacks did not weaken the country's spirit. He warned that those who attempt to harm the nation will "soon join the long list of vanquished enemies who dared to test our mettle." The president also highlighted the bravery of a Pentagon police officer who risked his life to save as many as 20 people during the 36-hour response effort.

The ceremony was preceded by remarks from General Joseph Dunford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Defense Secretary James Mattis, who emphasized the nation's unwavering determination and unbreakable spirit. Vice President Mike Pence also paid tribute to the passengers of United Airlines Flight 93, who fought against hijackers on 9/11.

Earlier in the day, the president and First Lady Melania Trump observed a moment of silence on the South Lawn of the White House, accompanied by other administration officials. The brief ceremony included a bell tolling and a Marine bugler playing "Taps."

The 16th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks serves as a poignant reminder of the devastating consequences of terrorism and the importance of continued vigilance and cooperation in the fight against terrorism.

Title: Trump Claims Sondland's Testimony Clears Him of Wrongdoing, But Experts Disagree

Article:

President Donald Trump has claimed that Ambassador Gordon Sondland's testimony before the House Intelligence Committee has exonerated him of any wrongdoing in the ongoing impeachment inquiry. Trump stated that Sondland's testimony means "it's all over" for the proceedings and that the House inquiry into him should come to a halt.

However, experts and lawmakers have disputed Trump's claims, saying that Sondland's testimony actually raises more questions and provides new evidence of the president's involvement in the scandal. Sondland testified that he never heard directly from Trump on a quid pro quo linking military aid for Ukraine to politically advantageous investigations. However, he confirmed that "we all understood" that a meeting at the White House for Ukraine's president and a phone call with Trump would happen only if President Volodymyr Zelensky agreed to an investigation into the 2016 U.S. election and the Bidens.

Sondland also testified that he worked with Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, on Ukraine at Trump's "express direction" and pushed a "quid pro quo" with Kiev because it was what Trump wanted. This revelation has sparked concerns about the extent of Trump's involvement in the scandal and whether he was aware of the quid pro quo arrangement.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., called Sondland's testimony "a very important moment in the history of this investigation" and said it showed "for the first time that knowledge of this scheme was pervasive." The committee will continue to investigate the matter and gather more evidence to determine the extent of Trump's involvement.

In conclusion, while Trump claims that Sondland's testimony clears him of wrongdoing, experts and lawmakers disagree, saying that the testimony raises more questions and provides new evidence of the president's involvement in the scandal. The investigation will continue to unfold, and the public will have to wait and see what other evidence emerges.

**Austin Explosion: Two People Injured, Police Investigate Possible Link to Previous Bombings**

A fourth explosion rocked Austin, Texas, on Sunday night, injuring two people on bicycles in a suburban neighborhood. The blast occurred around 8:30 p.m. in Travis Country, leaving authorities scrambling to determine if it is linked to a trio of previous package bombings that have gripped the city in fear.

Austin Police Chief Brian Manley told ABC's "Good Morning America" that the explosion may have been triggered by a trip wire, adding that it was "activated by someone either handling, kicking, or coming into contact with a trip wire that activated the device" as they walked or rode their bikes through the area.

The blast has left two men in their 20s with non-life-threatening injuries, including one who had nails in his leg, according to KVUE-TV. South Austin Medical Center officials said the men were in good condition.

The latest explosion has prompted authorities to urge people within a half-mile radius to stay in their homes as the scene is processed and cleared of any hazards. Police are working to determine if the blast is connected to the previous three explosions, which occurred on the east side of the city.

The first explosion occurred on March 2, killing 39-year-old Anthony Stephen House, while the second and third explosions on March 12 killed 17-year-old Draylen Mason and injured his mother and a 75-year-old woman. All three previous blasts involved packages that had not been mailed or delivered by private carriers but were left overnight on doorsteps.

Austin Police have issued an emergency alert on cellular phones and are working to process the scene and determine the cause of the blast. The reward for information leading to an arrest in the deadly explosions has risen by $50,000 to a new total of $115,000.

The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are urging the public to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity.

Title: Roger Stone Denies Charges, Claims Indictment is a "Nothingburger"

Article:

Roger Stone, a veteran political consultant and longtime adviser to President Donald Trump, has been indicted on charges of lying about his role in Russian meddling during the 2016 election. Stone took to his Instagram account to respond to the news, posting a doctored image of special counsel Robert Mueller dressed as a waiter holding an empty bun on a silver platter, accompanied by the caption "Here's what Mueller has on me #nothingburger."

Stone's post is just the latest in a series of controversial social media posts that have become a hallmark of his online presence. After being arrested on Friday, Stone posted a photo of himself with the words "Who framed Roger Stone?", a play on the 1988 movie "Who Framed Roger Rabbit".

The indictment alleges that Stone lied about his contacts with WikiLeaks and the Trump campaign, including dealings with website founder Julian Assange, as well as interactions with members of the Trump campaign about stolen emails. According to the indictment, Stone spoke to senior Trump campaign officials about Organization 1 (believed to be WikiLeaks) and information it might have had that would be damaging to the Clinton campaign.

Stone has repeatedly denied the allegations, claiming that Mueller is conducting a vendetta against him and the president. After being released on bail, Stone spoke outside a federal courthouse in Florida and made appearances on CNN and Fox News to denounce the charges and boast that he would never testify against the president.

The indictment marks a significant development in the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election, and the extent to which the Trump campaign was aware of and involved in those efforts. While Stone's claims of innocence and claims of a "nothingburger" may be seen as defiant, the allegations against him are serious and could have significant implications for the Trump administration.

Title: Fiorina Defends Campaign Strategy Amid Sliding Poll Numbers

Article:

Carly Fiorina, a Republican presidential candidate, addressed concerns about her campaign's momentum and spending habits during a press conference in Bluffton, South Carolina. Fiorina sought to reassure reporters that her campaign is on track, despite recent dips in her poll numbers.

Fiorina emphasized the importance of "fave and unfave ratings," citing her strong favorability and unfavorability numbers. She attributed the recent decline in her poll numbers to the fact that many voters are still getting to know her and her platform. "You don't make a sale in one impression," she said.

Fiorina also defended her decision not to spend money on advertising, stating that her campaign is focusing on building a strong grassroots presence and utilizing earned media opportunities, such as debates. She noted that other candidates have spent millions on ads without seeing significant results.

The former Hewlett-Packard CEO acknowledged that her campaign has been off national television for a few weeks, but emphasized that this is a strategic decision to focus on regional media and town hall events. Fiorina believes that her campaign's trajectory is more important than short-term poll numbers.

Fiorina's comments come as her campaign faces increased scrutiny over her business record and her decision not to spend money on advertising. While some critics argue that her strategy is too focused on debates and not enough on building a broad coalition of supporters, Fiorina remains confident in her approach.

Ultimately, Fiorina's decision to prioritize grassroots organizing and earned media opportunities may pay off in the long run, as she continues to build a loyal base of supporters and gain exposure through her debate performances.

Title: Gun Control Debate: Understanding the Stakes and the Numbers

Article:

The recent CNN town hall on gun control, held in Sunrise, Florida, brought the issue back into the spotlight. The event saw Senator Marco Rubio and NRA spokesperson Dana Loesch facing a passionate crowd, with some critics labeling it an "Orwellian two minutes of hate" against gun owners and conservatives. The discussion highlighted the deep divisions on the issue, with some calling for stricter gun control measures, while others argue that the Second Amendment is under attack.

A recent YouGov poll revealed that 82% of Democrats want to ban semiautomatic firearms, with 55% supporting a total handgun ban. While some may see this as a silver lining, others argue that the media's lack of basic gun knowledge may be contributing to the high support for these measures. The poll also showed that 57% of respondents support banning "rifles capable of semi-automatic fire," such as the AR-15.

However, it's worth noting that the poll's findings may be influenced by the media's portrayal of gun ownership and the lack of understanding of basic firearm terminology. As journalist Lois Beckett pointed out, many respondents may not fully comprehend the terms "assault weapon" and "full semi-automatic," which can lead to misconceptions about the issue.

The article also highlights the concerns about the Democratic Party's stance on gun control, with some critics arguing that the party wants to "destroy the Second Amendment." While some may see this as an exaggeration, the poll's findings suggest that the party's members are overwhelmingly in favor of stricter gun control measures.

The article concludes by noting that the media's role in shaping public opinion on gun control is crucial, and that pollsters should consider surveying Americans on their understanding of basic gun terminology to better understand the issue. Ultimately, the debate on gun control remains complex and contentious, with both sides presenting valid arguments and concerns.

Title: White House Leaves Door Open to Alternative Explanations of Libya Attack

Article:

The White House has opened the door to the possibility of alternative explanations for the deadly attack on the US Consulate in Libya, which killed four Americans. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said on Tuesday that the FBI is investigating the incident and will follow the facts wherever they lead.

Carney emphasized that the administration does not have any indication of premeditation or pre-planned attacks, but acknowledged that the investigation is ongoing and that the facts may lead to a different version of events. This is a departure from the account provided by US Ambassador Susan Rice, who said on Sunday that the attack was a "spontaneous" reaction to protests in Egypt over an anti-Islam film, and that extremist elements "joined the fray" before it "spun out of control."

However, Libyan President Mohamed Yousef el-Magariaf has claimed that the attack was premeditated, and an intelligence source in Libya told Fox News that there was no major protest in Benghazi before the attack. A US official did not dispute this claim.

The conflicting accounts have raised questions about the nature of the attack, which involved RPGs and mortar fire. Carney suggested that the weapons used in the attack are readily available in post-revolution Libya, where there are "vast numbers of weapons and certainly a number of violent groups in the country."

The investigation is ongoing, and the White House is examining what role the anti-Islam film played in the attack, among other things. The FBI is working to determine the motivations behind the attack and what role any foreign fighters may have played.

The conflicting accounts of the attack have sparked debate and questions about the security situation in Libya, which has been deteriorating in recent months. The CIA had previously determined that the security situation in eastern Libya was deteriorating based on four attacks on diplomatic and Western targets in Benghazi, including the US Consulate, starting in June. However, US officials insist that there was no specific warning of an armed assault like the one that killed the four Americans.

Title: Virginia University and Schools Take Steps to Distance Themselves from Confederate Heritage

Article:

The faculty of Washington and Lee University in Virginia has voted overwhelmingly to remove the name of Confederate General Robert E. Lee from the institution. The decision, which passed with 188 votes in favor and 51 against, comes after a petition signed by over 200 faculty members and a formal request from the student government to reconsider the name.

The move is part of a broader trend in Virginia, where Confederate names are being stripped from public K-12 schools at a rapid pace. Stonewall Middle School and Robert E. Lee High School are among the schools that will be getting new names, while Loudon County High School has dropped its mascot, the Raiders, which was a reference to Confederate Col. John S. Mosby's guerrilla troops.

Historians note that the wholesale rejection of Confederate iconography by Virginia schools is unprecedented, but it is a long-overdue recognition of the harm caused by the naming of schools after Confederate figures. "It was trying to make black students feel unwelcome, while white students and white communities were emboldened to resist desegregation," said historian Adam Domby.

The decision to remove Lee's name from Washington and Lee University is seen as a step towards a more inclusive and diverse institution. "Lee, who had served as the college's president after the Civil War, was a symbol of who that faculty wanted to be, and who they were," said Alison Bell, head of the Faculty Affairs Committee. "The faculty is back 150 years later, asking the university for a name change because Lee does not represent who we are and who we want to be."

The university's board of trustees will now have to approve the name change, and a spokeswoman said they are "carefully monitoring developments regarding issues of race, monuments, and symbols of the Confederacy and their implications" for the university.

The move is a significant step towards acknowledging the harm caused by Confederate symbols and a recognition that they do not represent the values of inclusivity and diversity that many institutions strive to uphold.

Title: Mueller's Testimony Raises Questions on Investigation's Legitimacy

Article:

The recent testimony of former special counsel Robert Mueller on Capitol Hill has sparked a heated debate about the legitimacy of the investigation that bore his name. Jay Sekulow, one of President Donald Trump's attorneys, described Mueller's testimony as "incoherent" and "worse as played out on live TV." Sekulow, who appeared on Fox News' "Fox and Friends," called the investigation a "terrible, terrible waste of taxpayer money."

Sekulow's comments were echoed by many commentators across various networks, who described Mueller's testimony as a "disaster," "train wreck," and "horrible." However, Sekulow noted that even some Democratic Party members were acknowledging the investigation's shortcomings.

The attorney pointed out that 12-13 prosecutors were involved in the investigation, which he claimed was marked by "twisting and turning" to create a narrative of collusion, conspiracy, and obstruction. Despite their efforts, Sekulow said, they were unable to produce any concrete evidence.

One of the most telling moments of the testimony, according to Sekulow, was when Mueller was asked about the concept of "exoneration." Mueller acknowledged that there is no historical precedent for the policy he employed, which Sekulow argued means the president is being treated differently than any other citizen in the context of a burden of proof.

Sekulow also touched on the topic of potential pardons for those arrested during the investigation, stating that there has been no discussion on the matter. However, he emphasized that there has been "a lot of injustice" in the investigation.

While opinions on the investigation's legitimacy may vary, Sekulow's comments highlight the ongoing debate surrounding the Mueller investigation and its implications for the president and the country.

**Nepal Earthquake: Devastation and Aftermath**

A powerful 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal over the weekend, causing widespread destruction and loss of life. According to reports, at least 4,400 people have been killed and over 8,000 injured, with many more still trapped under the rubble. The earthquake triggered avalanches on Mount Everest, resulting in the deaths of at least 18 people and injuring 61 more.

The earthquake's impact was felt across the region, with reports of casualties in India, Bangladesh, and Tibet, as well as along the Nepal-China border. The historic Dharahara Tower, a UNESCO-recognized landmark in Kathmandu, collapsed, and hundreds of people who had bought tickets to ascend to the top of the watchtower on weekends were caught in the disaster.

Rescue efforts are ongoing, with rescue workers facing challenges due to the sheer scale of the destruction and the difficulty in accessing affected areas. The earthquake's aftermath has also led to concerns about the country's infrastructure, with many buildings in the heavily populated Kathmandu Valley being poorly constructed to withstand earthquakes.

Experts had warned of the possibility of a major earthquake in Nepal, with a team of 50 earthquake and social scientists visiting the country just a week prior to the disaster. They had warned of the need for better preparedness and infrastructure to mitigate the impact of such an event.

The earthquake has also had a significant impact on Nepal's economy, which relies heavily on tourism from trekkers and mountain climbers. The country's tourism industry is expected to take a significant hit, with many trekkers and climbers cancelling their trips due to the disaster.

The full extent of the damage and the number of casualties is still being assessed, with officials warning that the death toll is likely to rise.

Title: Thousands of Young Illegal Immigrants Line Up to Apply for Obama's Deportation Reprieve

Article:

The Obama administration's new program allowing young illegal immigrants to apply for a two-year reprieve from deportation has sparked a surge of interest, with thousands lining up at consulates across the country. The program, which kicked off on Wednesday, aims to provide a pathway to legal status for up to 1.8 million undocumented immigrants who arrived in the United States as minors.

To qualify, applicants must fill out a six-page form, pay a $465 fee, and provide documents proving their identity, age, and eligibility. Immigration officials stress that the documents will be thoroughly scrutinized to prevent fraud, but there is no uniform standard for verifying applicants' claims.

The lines began forming on Tuesday, with many seeking to get a head start on the application process. "We are waiting for our passports. We want to get our passport because Obama might be asking for them," said Kristi Alarcon, an applicant waiting outside the Mexican consulate in Houston.

Advocates held workshops in Los Angeles on Wednesday to help guide applicants through the process. The crowds are the most visible demonstration yet of the interest in the program, which is effectively a version of the DREAM Act that failed to pass Congress.

The requirements for the program are less stringent than those in the original DREAM Act. Applicants must be in school, have a high school diploma or GED, or be a military veteran. They cannot have a felony record, but a record with fewer than three minor misdemeanors is not disqualifying.

Republican lawmakers have criticized the program, accusing the Obama administration of circumventing Congress and favoring illegal immigrants over unemployed U.S. citizens. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Lamar Smith, R-Texas, called the policy "backdoor amnesty" and expressed concerns about fraud.

While some have praised the program as a step towards immigration reform, others have raised concerns about the potential for fraud and the impact on the job market. The program's timing is also seen as strategic, with the presidential election just months away and the Hispanic vote playing a crucial role.

The Obama administration has announced the details of the program, including the required documents and application process. The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services will begin accepting applications on Wednesday.

**Title:** Parties Prepare for Potential Runoff Scenarios in Louisiana and Georgia

**Article:**

As the midterm elections approach, operatives on both sides are strategizing for potential runoff scenarios in Louisiana and Georgia, which could determine control of the Senate. Republicans are reserving millions of dollars' worth of ad time and booking hotel rooms in Louisiana, while Democrats are quietly plotting an aggressive ground and aerial attack to keep the seat in their hands.

In Louisiana, Senator Mary Landrieu's campaign is focusing on winning outright in the general election, while her opponents, including Representative Bill Cassidy, are preparing for a potential runoff. Republicans have reserved $3.4 million in TV time and $1.5 million more from conservative outside groups, while Democrats have yet to reserve airtime.

In Georgia, both parties are building an infrastructure to sustain their get-out-the-vote efforts in the event of a runoff. The National Republican Senatorial Committee has reserved $3.4 million in TV time, while the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee is mum on its plans.

Senator Johnny Isakson, a Georgia Republican, notes that the runoff period is "very intense" and requires a rapid response to get voters to the polls. Democrats, on the other hand, believe their best shot at victory is to win outright in November, taking advantage of a split between Cassidy and his main conservative foe, Rob Maness.

While both parties are preparing for a potential runoff, they are keeping their plans under wraps. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee is focused on winning both races on Election Day, while Senator Landrieu is confident in her ability to win with 50% of the vote.

The runoff scenario in Louisiana and Georgia highlights the importance of get-out-the-vote efforts and strategic planning in the final stretch of the election. As operatives on both sides continue to strategize, the outcome of these races remains uncertain, with the potential for a photo finish.

Title: President Obama to Deliver Economic Speech at Knox College, Highlighting Progress and Challenges

Article:

President Barack Obama will deliver a speech at Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois, on Wednesday, marking the beginning of a new series of economic speeches aimed at building public pressure on lawmakers ahead of key budget deadlines in the fall. The speech is expected to focus on the progress made in the economy since Obama took office and the challenges that remain.

The speech is part of a broader effort by the White House to engage the public in the ongoing debate over the economy and the need for a balanced approach to budgeting. The speech will also touch on the importance of investing in green energy, the middle class, and ensuring that the wealthy pay their fair share.

Obama's speech comes as his approval ratings continue to decline, and the economy remains a top concern for many Americans. The speech is also seen as an opportunity for the president to remind the public of the progress made in the economy since he took office, including the creation of millions of new jobs and the recovery of the automotive industry.

The speech will also likely address the ongoing debate over the debt ceiling and the need for a balanced approach to budgeting. The president will likely emphasize the importance of making responsible decisions about spending and revenue, and the need for both parties to work together to address the nation's fiscal challenges.

The speech will be streamed live at WhiteHouse.gov and is expected to be a key part of the president's efforts to engage the public in the ongoing debate over the economy and the need for a balanced approach to budgeting.

**TikTok's Global Reach Raises Concerns Over Censorship and National Security**

A former Chinese internet censor has come forward with allegations that TikTok, a popular short-video app owned by Beijing-based ByteDance Technology Co., is hiring internet police to monitor and police videos posted by international users. The claims have sparked concerns over the app's ties to the Chinese regime and its potential to censor American users.

Liu Lipeng, a former online censor in China, was interviewed for a content manager position at TikTok in 2018. He claims that during the interview, he was asked to monitor and police videos posted by international users, including those in the United States. Liu expressed concerns that the app's content moderation policies would stifle freedom of speech, but was ultimately rejected for the job.

Liu's claims coincide with growing concerns over TikTok's ties to the Chinese regime and its potential to spy on and censor American users. The Trump administration is considering banning the app over national security risks, and U.S. officials and experts have sounded the alarm that the app could be used to monitor and censor American users.

TikTok has denied using Chinese moderators to handle content on its platform, but Liu's allegations have raised questions about the app's content moderation practices. The app has previously been accused of censoring certain topics, such as the Tiananmen Square Massacre and Falun Gong, a spiritual practice that has been severely persecuted in China.

The controversy has led to a review of ByteDance's $1 billion acquisition of Musical.ly, a U.S. social media app, in 2017, and the Pentagon has ordered U.S. military personnel to delete TikTok from their work phones. The Democratic and Republican National Committees have also warned staff members about using the app.

As the debate over TikTok's national security risks continues, Liu's allegations have raised concerns about the app's potential to stifle freedom of speech and censor American users.

Title: The State of the Economy: A Call for Systemic Reforms

The current state of the economy has left many workers struggling to make ends meet, with wages failing to keep pace with the rising costs of living. According to recent statistics, a significant portion of the workforce is unable to support themselves and their families, even with multiple workers in the household. This has sparked concerns about the effectiveness of the current economic and social policies.

One presidential candidate has called for a re-examination of the fundamentals of the economy, citing the need for systemic reforms to ensure that the benefits of economic growth are shared by all. The candidate proposes rewriting the tax code to ensure that big corporations pay their fair share, and investing in programs that support workers, such as the Freedom Dividend, which would provide $1,000 a month to every American adult over 18.

Another presidential candidate has emphasized the need to address the growing wealth gap, pointing out that half of Americans do not own stocks and that the share of national income going to workers is near an all-time low. The candidate suggests investing in community colleges to prepare students for employment and providing federal student aid to quality short-term certificate programs.

The current state of the economy has also raised concerns about the impact of globalization and technological advancements on job markets. While low unemployment rates are often seen as a positive indicator, some argue that it is not enough to simply focus on job creation, but rather to address the underlying issues of poverty, inequality, and social injustice.

In other news, the recent strike against Iranian military leader Qasem Soleimani has sparked concerns about the potential for a wider conflict in the Middle East. Some have questioned the strategic implications of the strike, pointing out that it may not have decapitated the Iranian regime and that the US may not have a clear plan for what comes next.

In conclusion, the current state of the economy and the recent events in the Middle East highlight the need for systemic reforms and a re-examination of our economic and social policies. It is crucial that policymakers and leaders take a comprehensive approach to addressing the complex issues facing our nation and work towards creating a more equitable and prosperous society for all.

Title: US National Debt Reaches Record $22 Trillion, Contrasting with Trump's Pre-Election Promises

Article:

The United States' national debt has reached a record $22.012 trillion, according to the Treasury Department's latest fiscal statement. This milestone marks a significant increase from the $19.947 trillion debt when President Donald Trump took office in 2017. The growth in debt is attributed to various factors, including the rising costs of Medicare and Social Security, as well as the trillion-dollar deficit resulting from the 2017 tax cuts, which primarily benefited corporations and the wealthy.

This development stands in stark contrast to Trump's campaign promises to reduce the national debt. During his 2015 campaign launch address, Trump vowed to "reduce our $18 trillion in debt" and "freeze the budget." He also claimed that he could eliminate the debt "fairly quickly" over an eight-year period. However, since taking office, Trump has not presented a comprehensive plan to reduce the debt, and his administration's budget proposals have actually projected adding $7.2 trillion more to the debt over the next 10 years.

Trump's campaign promises were met with skepticism by many, and his administration's actions have failed to deliver on his promises. The ongoing trade war, which was sparked by Trump's tariffs, has instead had a negative impact on American farmers and the agricultural industry. The administration's lack of a plan to reduce the debt has also been criticized, with some experts warning that it will be much harder to reduce the debt now that it has surpassed $22 trillion.

The Trump administration's silence on the debt is notable, as Trump himself had previously attacked his predecessors, including President Barack Obama, for increasing the debt. Trump's own tweets on the subject have been infrequent, with most of his comments on the debt being made in the early days of his presidency. The administration's budget director, Mick Mulvaney, has even dismissed Trump's budget promises as "hyperbole."

The growth in the national debt has significant implications for the country's fiscal health and the economy. It is essential for policymakers to develop a comprehensive plan to address the debt and ensure a sustainable fiscal future for the United States.

Title: Wisconsin Recall Election Results: A Mixed Bag for Both Parties

The recent recall election in Wisconsin has left both parties with mixed emotions. Governor Scott Walker, a Republican, won the election, defeating his Democratic challenger, Tom Barrett, by a 7-point margin. However, the outcome was not without controversy, with President Obama blaming the Republican's outspending and use of corporate and out-of-state money for their victory.

The election was seen as a test of the public's sentiment towards union power and collective bargaining rights. Republicans argued that Walker's victory was a sign that voters are fed up with the influence of unions, while Democrats claimed that the outcome was a result of the Republicans' unfair advantage in terms of funding.

The results of the election were also seen as a mixed bag for both parties. While Walker's victory was a significant win for the Republicans, the fact that a union-backed Democrat unseated a state senator in another recall election suggests that the tide may not be entirely in their favor.

The election also had implications for the upcoming presidential election. Some Republicans are urging presumptive nominee Mitt Romney to make a play for Wisconsin, which has not voted for a Republican presidential candidate since 1984. However, others are skeptical, citing the state's close presidential election results and the fact that Obama won the state in 2008.

In the end, the outcome of the election serves as a reminder that the political landscape is complex and multifaceted, with no clear winners or losers. Both parties will have to regroup and reassess their strategies as they head into the general election.

Title: FBI Pursues Leads in Boston Marathon Bombing Investigation

Article:

The FBI is following up on a new lead in the Boston Marathon bombing investigation, which involves a man seen acting suspiciously on video footage from a Lord & Taylor department store across the street from the second explosion site. The video shows the man dropping a bag and then walking away, sparking concerns among investigators.

According to CBS News, the man is described as a young white male wearing a black jacket, gray hooded sweatshirt, and a white or off-white baseball cap worn backwards. Investigators are reviewing logs of cellphone calls to determine who made calls from the area around the time of the bombing.

The FBI has released images from the Lord & Taylor video, but has since pulled them back, citing concerns that the suspect may flee if he knows he's being sought. However, the agency is still assessing whether to enlist the public's help in identifying the individual.

The investigation is also exploring a second lead, which involves a second person seen carrying a backpack and behaving suspiciously in the vicinity of the first person of interest. The Los Angeles Times reported that this new lead suggests more than one bomber may have been involved in the attacks.

While the investigation is ongoing, the nation remains on edge following the Boston Marathon tragedy. The FBI has made an arrest in a separate case involving ricin-laced letters sent to President Obama and a US senator, but the Boston bombing case remains unsolved.

Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick expressed frustration that no one has been caught yet, but emphasized that the investigation will not be rushed. "It's going to happen by doing the careful work that must be done in a thorough investigation," he said. "That means going through the couple of blocks at the blast scene inch by square inch and picking up pieces of evidence and following those trails, and that's going to take some time."

**White House and Congress Weigh In on New Coronavirus Relief Package**

As the COVID-19 pandemic continues to spread and wreak havoc on the global economy, the White House and Congress are working to pass a third coronavirus spending package, worth hundreds of billions of dollars. The proposed package, which is still in its early stages, aims to provide relief to individuals and businesses affected by the pandemic.

According to reports, the White House is pushing for a $850 billion stimulus package, with roughly $500 billion tied to payroll tax cuts, $250 billion in Small Business Administration loans, and $58 billion for the airline industry. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will meet with Senate Republicans to discuss the details of the proposal.

Meanwhile, Senate Democrats are pushing for a $750 billion proposal, which would include expanded unemployment insurance, Medicaid funding, and assistance for small businesses, schools, and hospitals. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has announced that he will present his proposal to Congressional appropriators, which would provide an immediate infusion of at least $750 billion to combat the pandemic and its economic effects.

Other lawmakers have also weighed in with their own ideas for combating the pandemic and its economic impact. Senator Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., has backed Schumer's call for a $750 billion arsenal to battle the coronavirus, while Senator Mitt Romney, R-Utah, has proposed providing every American with a $1,000 check to cover expenses incurred due to layoffs, forced leave, or other coronavirus-related expenses.

Representative Tulsi Gabbard, D-Hawaii, has also proposed a similar plan, introducing a nonbinding House resolution to provide each American with a monthly $1,000 payment until the coronavirus threat is over. While these proposals are similar to the universal basic income (UBI) idea, they are distinguished from it mainly because they are temporary, stopgap measures.

The exact details of the White House's proposal are still unclear, but it is possible that there could be significant overlap with Schumer's ideas. Mnuchin has been the White House's point person in negotiating with congressional Democrats and has spoken with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi over 20 times to hash out the chamber's initial version of the second coronavirus deal.

As the pandemic continues to spread and the economic toll mounts, it remains to be seen what the final package will look like and how it will be received by lawmakers and the public.

Title: Flynn's Lawyers Halt Communication with Trump's Team, Raising Questions About Cooperation in Russia Probe

Article:

In a significant development in the ongoing investigation into alleged Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, lawyers for former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn have stopped communicating with President Donald Trump's legal team. According to sources familiar with the investigation, Flynn's lawyer, Robert Kelner, called Trump's private lawyer, John Dowd, on Wednesday to inform him that the two could no longer discuss the matter.

The move raises questions about whether Flynn is cooperating with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into whether Trump's campaign colluded with Russia. Flynn, a retired Army general, is a central figure in the probe, and his cooperation could be a major asset for Mueller.

It is unclear why Kelner made the call, but some speculate that Flynn may have negotiated a plea agreement with Mueller or decided to engage with the investigation. Jay Sekulow, another attorney for Trump, downplayed the significance of the move, saying, "No one should draw the conclusion that this means anything about General Flynn cooperating against the president."

Flynn's cooperation could provide insight into three major areas of inquiry: any collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, money laundering and other possible financial crimes by Trump aides, and whether Trump sought to obstruct justice when he fired former FBI Director James Comey in May.

Two congressional officials involved in separate probes into the Trump campaign's contacts with Russia said one key area of investigation is whether Flynn or other advisers to Trump ever suggested lifting U.S. economic sanctions on Russia in exchange for favorable business deals. Possible deals include a proposed commercial nuclear power project involving Russian firms that Flynn worked to promote to potential clients in the Middle East.

Flynn has been under scrutiny for his contacts with Russian officials, including his conversations with then-Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak in December 2016, and his work on behalf of Russian clients. Mueller has been investigating Flynn's son, Michael Flynn Jr., for his involvement in some of his father's business dealings in Russia, Turkey, and elsewhere.

The cooperation of Flynn, who was a top campaign adviser before becoming Trump's national security adviser in the White House, would be a major asset in Mueller's investigation. In March, Kelner said, "Mr. Flynn certainly has a story to tell, and he certainly wants to tell it, should the circumstances permit."

Title: Trump's Words Spark Concerns for Whistleblower's Safety

Article:

The lawyers representing the whistleblower whose complaint triggered a US presidential impeachment inquiry have expressed concerns that Donald Trump's words are putting their client in danger. The whistleblower's identity remains anonymous, and the lawyers are urging steps to protect their client's safety.

The whistleblower's complaint, which was filed last month, alleged that Trump had used his office to "solicit interference from a foreign country" in the 2020 US election. The impeachment inquiry, launched on Tuesday, focuses specifically on Trump's call to the Ukrainian president about the Biden allegations.

Trump has called for the whistleblower to be unmasked, and has even suggested that his opponents could be arrested for treason. The whistleblower's lawyers have sent a letter to Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire, expressing their concerns that Trump's language is putting their client in harm's way.

The letter specifically mentions Trump's call for the whistleblower to be identified, as well as the person who supplied the whistleblower with information about the call. It quotes Trump as saying, "I want to know who's the person that gave the whistleblower, who's the person that gave the whistleblower the information, because that's close to a spy. You know what we used to do in the old days when we were smart? Right? With spies and treason, right? We used to handle them a little differently than we do now."

The letter also references a $50,000 "bounty" offered by two conservative Trump supporters as a "reward" for information about the whistleblower. The lawyers warn that the situation is likely to worsen and become even more dangerous for the whistleblower and any other whistleblowers.

Meanwhile, Trump has taken to Twitter to lash out at his critics, including the whistleblower and Democratic House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff. He has also retweeted a Fox News guest who warned that if Trump is removed from office, it will spark a "Civil War-like fracture in this Nation from which our Country will never heal."

The impeachment inquiry is the first part of a two-stage political process by which Congress can remove a president from office. If the House of Representatives votes to pass articles of impeachment, the Senate is forced to hold a trial. A Senate vote requires a two-thirds majority to convict, which is unlikely given that Trump's party controls the chamber.

The whistleblower's complaint has sparked a massive Twitter volley from Trump, who has called for the whistleblower to be identified and has even suggested that his opponents could be arrested for treason. The whistleblower's lawyers have expressed concerns that Trump's language is putting their client in harm's way, and have urged steps to protect their client's safety.

**Gilead Sciences Unveils Cost of Five-Day Coronavirus Treatment Remdesivir**

Gilead Sciences, the pharmaceutical company behind the investigational antiviral treatment remdesivir, has announced the cost of the medication, which will be $2,340 per COVID-19 patient for Medicare and governments of developed countries, equivalent to approximately $390 per vial. For patients with private health insurance in the United States, the cost will be $3,120, with a minimum of $520 per vial or up to $5,720 per patient for a longer duration.

In an open letter, Gilead Chairman and CEO Daniel O'Day emphasized that the company is pricing remdesivir below market value to ensure broad and equitable access to the treatment. "As the world continues to reel from the human, social, and economic impact of this pandemic, we believe that pricing remdesivir well below value is the right and responsible thing to do," O'Day wrote.

The company has also entered into agreements with drug manufacturers capable of producing generic forms of the drug in developing countries, with plans to begin charging in July. However, some medical experts and doctors have expressed concerns about the cost of the treatment, citing the lack of clear mortality benefits and the potential for the drug to be inferior to other treatments.

Dr. Eugene Gu, a medical expert, tweeted that the cost of remdesivir is "Big Pharma's greed and opportunism during this pandemic," while Dr. James Todaro, another medical expert, noted that the drug has no mortality benefit and is likely inferior to the cheaper treatment dexamethasone.

Gilead Sciences received a $37.5 million grant from the US government to develop and test remdesivir, and the company projects $1 billion in revenue from the drug in 2020. The announcement comes as doctors and medical experts continue to scrutinize the drug and its potential benefits.

While some have expressed concerns about the cost and effectiveness of remdesivir, others, like Dr. Anthony Fauci, have touted the drug as showing promise in treating COVID-19. The debate highlights the ongoing challenges and complexities of developing and pricing treatments for the pandemic.

**Tariffs' Unintended Consequences: Study Reveals Manufacturing Sector's Employment and Prices Affected**

A recent study by Federal Reserve economists has shed light on the unintended consequences of tariffs on the US manufacturing sector. The research, which analyzed the effects of the trade war on employment and prices, found that the tariffs have reduced US manufacturing employment and increased the prices that American manufacturers pay for the materials they need.

The study, which compared trends across different industries, found that while some industries benefited from being protected from foreign competition, this benefit was largely offset by the negative effects of rising input costs and retaliatory tariffs. The research also found that foreign retaliation decreased employment, while import protection increased it, although the effect was not statistically significant.

The study's findings are summarized in a series of charts, which show that rising input costs decreased employment and increased producer prices, while foreign retaliation decreased employment. The research also found that industries more exposed to the effects of tariffs suffered a reduction in employment and an increase in producer prices.

The study's authors conclude that the tariffs have had a net negative impact on the US manufacturing sector, with a reduction in employment and an increase in prices. This is in contrast to the intended goal of the tariffs, which was to promote American manufacturing and protect domestic industries.

The study's findings must be seen in the context of overall trends, with American manufacturing employment stalling in 2017 and 2018, and then declining. The research highlights the need for policymakers to carefully consider the potential unintended consequences of tariffs and to weigh the benefits against the costs.

While the study's findings are clear, some limitations and caveats are worth noting. The research is based on short-term data and does not account for the potential long-term effects of tariffs. Additionally, the study does not consider the effects of increased uncertainty about future trade policy, which may persist even if tariffs are eventually lifted.

Overall, the study provides valuable insights into the complex and nuanced effects of tariffs on the US manufacturing sector, highlighting the need for policymakers to carefully consider the potential consequences of their actions.

**Senate's Filibuster Rules: A Complex Game of Parliamentary Maneuvering**

The nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court has sparked a heated debate in the Senate, with at least 41 Democrats planning to block the nomination on the Senate floor. This could potentially lead to the "nuclear option" being triggered, allowing Republicans to eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees. The 60-vote threshold in the Senate is a unique aspect of parliamentary bodies worldwide, making the U.S. Senate "the world's most deliberative body."

The filibuster has survived for so long due to a bipartisan, institutional belief in its importance. However, it has been weakened in the past, with Democrats rewriting the rules in 2013 to exclude the 60-vote threshold for federal court appointments, except for Supreme Court appointments.

If Republicans fail to get 60 votes to close debate on Gorsuch's nomination, Democrats can filibuster and grind the Senate to a halt until the nomination is withdrawn from the confirmation process. Republicans, led by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, are likely to trigger the "nuclear option" and abolish the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees.

The process would involve several steps, including invoking cloture, reconsideration, and a point of order. If the nuclear option is triggered, it would set a new precedent, allowing Supreme Court nominees to be approved with a simple majority vote.

The debate surrounding the filibuster is reminiscent of the game of Calvinball, a fictional sport from the comic strip Calvin and Hobbes, where rules can be changed at any time, often arbitrarily. The Senate's rules are complex and arcane, evolving over time and determined by the players themselves.

The outcome of this debate will have significant implications for the future of the Supreme Court and the balance of power in the Senate.

Title: The Amazon Rainforest Fires: Separating Fact from Fiction

Article:

The Amazon rainforest has been a topic of concern in recent months, with reports of unprecedented fires spreading rapidly across the region. The news has sparked widespread alarm, with many attributing the blazes to man-made global warming. However, a closer examination of the data reveals a more nuanced picture.

The Brazilian National Institute for Space Research (INPE) reported that the Amazon was burning at an unprecedented rate, citing satellite data that showed a significant increase in fires. However, a closer look at the data reveals some significant flaws. Firstly, the satellite data only began in 2013, making it difficult to make definitive statements about "record-breaking" fires. Secondly, the data was not intended to be used as a counting tool, but rather as a readiness alert system to identify fires before they spread.

According to NASA's Global Fire Emissions Database, fire activity is above average in some states, but below average in others. The overall numbers are in line with historic data, which goes back to 2003. This raises questions about the accuracy of the reports and the motivations behind them.

It's also important to understand the context of the fires. The Amazon fire season typically begins in late July and peaks in mid-September, with most fires being intentionally set by ranchers to clear land for agriculture. In fact, it's estimated that up to 15% of the original forest has been cleared in this way, mostly in the 1990s and 2000s.

The Amazonian rainforest is a vital ecological niche, and conservation efforts have been effective in slowing deforestation. However, the promotion of alarmist and false information can undermine trust in media and public institutions, and distract from the real issues.

In conclusion, while the Amazon rainforest is an important topic, it's essential to separate fact from fiction and consider the complexities of the issue. Rather than promoting fear and misinformation, we should focus on promoting accurate information and effective conservation efforts.

Title: Boy Scouts of America Renames Program, Embracing Inclusivity and Gender Neutrality

Article:

The Boy Scouts of America (BSA) has announced a significant change, dropping the "Boy" from its signature program's name, effective February. The decision aims to promote inclusivity and gender neutrality, allowing both boys and girls to participate. The umbrella organization, Boy Scouts of America, will retain its name, while the term "Cub Scouts" for children aged 7-10 will remain unchanged.

The BSA's "Scout Me In" marketing campaign aims to promote inclusiveness and encourage more youth to join the organization. Chief Scout Executive Mike Surbaugh emphasized the importance of inclusivity, stating, "As we enter a new era for our organization, it is important that all youth can see themselves in Scouting in every way possible."

The change comes as both the BSA and Girl Scouts of the USA face declining membership numbers. The BSA has been struggling to attract new members, with a current membership of almost 2.3 million, down from 2.6 million five years ago. The Girl Scouts, on the other hand, have a membership of about 1.8 million.

The BSA's decision to admit girls has been met with skepticism by the Girl Scouts, who argue that it does not provide any new, girl-specific programming. Sylvia Acevedo, CEO of Girl Scouts of the USA, stated, "Girl Scouts is the premier leadership development organization for girls. We are, and will remain, the first choice for girls and parents."

The BSA's decision to admit girls has also led to a decline in membership for the Girl Scouts, with one regional leader reporting a loss of over 500 girls in her council this year. The tension between the two organizations is palpable, with some regional leaders describing relations as "very chilly."

Despite the challenges, the BSA is optimistic about its new direction. Stephen Medlicott, BSA marketing director, emphasized the excitement around the new Cub Scouts program, stating, "Cub Scouts is a lot of fun, and now it's available to all kids. That's why we love 'Scout Me In' – because it speaks to girls and boys and tells them, 'This is for you. We want you to join!'"

The impact of the BSA's decision remains to be seen, but one thing is clear: the world of scouting is undergoing significant changes, and both organizations will need to adapt to stay relevant in the future.

Title: Clinton's Ties to For-Profit University Raise Questions About Her Critique

Article:

Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton has been vocal about her criticism of for-profit universities, accusing them of charging high prices and delivering degrees of questionable value. However, her own family's connections to Laureate Education, a major for-profit university, have raised questions about her motives and trustworthiness.

Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, served as the honorary chancellor of Laureate from 2010 to 2015, earning $17.6 million in the process. During that time, Laureate's owners, including Goldman Sachs, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., SAC Capital, and CitiGroup Private Equity, donated millions to the Clinton Foundation, Clinton's presidential campaigns, and related organizations. The Clinton family has also received speaking fees from Laureate, with Hillary Clinton earning $900,000 from Goldman and KKR for four appearances in 2013 alone.

Laureate, which has accumulated $9.8 billion in loans from students, including $2.8 billion from Walden University in Minnesota, has been criticized for its business practices. The company has been accused of paying recruiters commissions for enrolling students, a practice banned in the US. Additionally, Walden University's loan default rates are higher than the national average, with 56% of graduates failing to repay their loans three years after graduation.

Clinton's ties to Laureate have raised concerns about her ability to effectively regulate the for-profit education industry. Her administration has promised to crack down on for-profit colleges and loan servicers who have taken advantage of borrowers, but her own family's financial ties to Laureate have raised questions about her commitment to this goal.

While Clinton's Republican opponent, Donald Trump, has faced criticism for his role in the Trump University scandal, Clinton's connections to Laureate have not received the same level of scrutiny. However, as the presidential election heats up, her ties to the for-profit education industry are likely to come under closer examination.

Title: Millennials' Low Turnout Rate: A Growing Concern for Political Engagement

Article:

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996, are often touted as a generation of tech-savvy, socially conscious, and engaged citizens. However, their participation in the electoral process has been steadily declining. According to the Harvard Institute of Politics, only 23% of voters under 30 are expected to vote in the upcoming midterm elections, a significant drop from the 52% who voted in 2008.

The reasons behind this decline are multifaceted. Some attribute it to the lack of political engagement among millennials, who are often characterized as apathetic and disinterested in politics. However, data from the Pew Research Center suggests that young voters are actually better informed than previous generations, with 50% of millennials saying they are registered to vote, a number that has been steadily decreasing since 2008.

Rock the Vote, a non-partisan organization founded in 1989, has been working to increase political engagement among young voters. The organization has seen a decline in participation among millennials, but remains optimistic about their potential to make a difference. "They do care very passionately about issues that matter to them," says Ashley Spillane, president of Rock the Vote. "They are getting involved at a local level, creating startups, volunteering with local organizations, and looking to take problems on in real time and fix them."

Despite the challenges, experts like Eva Guidarini of the Harvard Institute of Politics remain hopeful that millennials will become more engaged in the political process. "I think that if politics starts to change in a direction that I think all of America wants to see it change – not just young people – then you'll see young people get back in the game," she says.

The question remains whether politics will improve unless a new generation gets more involved and pushes for change.
