As the nation's politics become increasingly divided, it is essential to recognize the consequences of this trend. The erosion of civil rights and social services in red states has real-world consequences for real people. It is crucial that we acknowledge the impact of these policies and work towards a more equitable and just society for all.

Title: House Speaker Boehner Denies Plans to Impeach President Obama, Blames Democrats and White House

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has flatly denied that congressional Republicans are planning to impeach President Barack Obama, calling the talk "a scam started by Democrats at the White House." Boehner made the statement during a weekly meeting with GOP members, emphasizing that the House has no plans to impeach the President.

Boehner's comments come as some conservative voices, including former GOP vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin, have been pushing for impeachment over claims that Obama has grossly exceeded his executive authority. However, a recent CNN-ORC opinion poll shows that almost two-thirds of Americans do not believe Obama deserves to be impeached, with 57% of Republicans and 86% of Democrats and Independents opposing the move.

The lawsuit filed by Boehner's office, which covers Obama's decision to defer a health law requirement that businesses provide insurance coverage to their employees, has opened the door to more discussion about impeaching the second-straight Democratic president by a Republican-led House. However, Boehner has emphasized his disagreement with Palin and other conservatives pushing for impeachment.

Congressional Democrats have seized on the issue, with Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid raising the subject on the Senate floor and calling it "a distraction from the real issues." The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has raised nearly $7.6 million in the month since Boehner announced his lawsuit, with $1 million coming in since House GOP whip Steve Scalise refused to rule out impeachment over the weekend.

While the resolution to formally authorize the lawsuit is expected to come to the House floor on Wednesday, House Democrats are likely to continue arguing that the move is simply the first step toward impeachment.

Title: Telecom Industry Challenges Maine's Broadband Privacy Law, Claiming Free Speech Violations

Article:

The telecommunications industry is taking aim at Maine's new broadband privacy law, which requires internet service providers (ISPs) to clearly disclose what data they collect and who it's sold to, as well as ban extra charges for users who want their privacy protected. The industry claims the law violates their free speech rights, arguing that it imposes "unprecedented and unduly burdensome restrictions" on their ability to share customer information.

However, telecom experts say the industry is simply trying to dodge accountability for a decade of privacy abuses. "Big broadband is clearly trying untested First Amendment arguments in the hope that something sticks," said former FCC lawyer Gigi Sohn. "Since when does giving consumers a right to control their personal information become an unconstitutional limitation on broadband companies' speech?"

The lawsuit is part of a broader effort by the industry to eliminate all meaningful state and federal consumer protections. In 2017, telecom lobbyists convinced the Trump FCC to kill net neutrality and eliminate most of the FCC's telecom consumer protection authority. The industry has also fought tooth and nail against the passage of federal privacy rules, and has successfully eliminated most of the FCC's authority to regulate the industry.

In response to federal apathy, states like Washington, California, and Maine have passed their own privacy and net neutrality laws. While the industry claims this creates a "patchwork quilt" of state consumer protections, telecom experts say it's a problem the industry itself created by asking Congress to repeal the FCC's modest and popular 2016 broadband privacy rules.

The industry's lawsuit is just the latest example of their efforts to have their cake and eat it too. "It is bad enough that ISPs lobbied to repeal the FCC's robust broadband privacy rules; they now have the temerity to pretend that the near-total vacuum of privacy protections for ISP customers at the federal level constitutes some kind of 'uniform' federal approach to privacy with which Maine's law could conflict," said Blake Reid, Associate Clinical Professor at Colorado Law.

The telecom industry's actions are a stark reminder of the need for strong consumer protections and oversight. With former Verizon lawyers now in charge of both the FCC and DOJ, the federal government has further aided the telecom sector by suing states like California for attempting to protect consumers on issues like net neutrality. It's clear that the industry will stop at nothing to eliminate all meaningful consumer protections and continue to prioritize profits over people.

Title: The Tactics Used by Liberals to Silence Conservative Voices

The article discusses the various tactics employed by liberals to silence conservative voices and opinions. The author argues that liberals have given up on the idea of engaging in intellectual debates and instead focus on silencing their opponents through various means.

The article highlights seven tactics used by liberals to silence conservatives:

1. Libsplaining: Liberals reinterpret conservative statements to mean something entirely different, often to make them appear racist, sexist, or bigoted.

2. Violence: Liberal groups like ANTIFA use violence to intimidate and silence conservative individuals, often targeting women and sending them death and rape threats.

3. De-Platforming: Liberals aim to control the narrative by taking over social media, news outlets, and educational institutions, making it difficult for conservatives to express their opinions.

4. Political Correctness/Safe Spaces/Microaggressions: These tactics aim to silence individuals who express opinions that don't align with liberal views, often by labeling them as offensive or hurtful.

5. Liberal Fakes: The article suggests that many self-proclaimed conservative voices in the mainstream media are actually liberal sympathizers who water down conservative views to avoid offending the Left.

6. False Labeling: Liberals often label anyone who disagrees with them as a white supremacist, Nazi, fascist, or racist, even when there is no evidence to support these claims.

7. The Ventriloquist Dummy: Liberals often use sympathetic figures, such as victims of tragedy or marginalized groups, to push their agenda and silence opposing views.

The article concludes that these tactics are designed to silence conservatives and prevent them from expressing their opinions, often without engaging in intellectual debates or addressing the substance of the issues.

**Election Update: Clinton Solidifies Lead, Trump Faces Uphill Battle**

The 2016 presidential election is heating up, and according to the latest analysis, Hillary Clinton has solidified her lead against Donald Trump. The NPR Battleground Map shows Clinton with a significant advantage, with a potential landslide victory if the election were held today.

Clinton's strong performance has been fueled by Trump's missteps since the conventions, including controversies surrounding his comments on the death of a fallen soldier, his feud with a grieving family, and his remarks on the Second Amendment. These incidents have led to key voting groups shifting towards Clinton, including white, college-educated voters, a demographic found in important swing states like the suburbs of Philadelphia, Denver, and Northern Virginia.

The latest polling and demographic analysis suggest that Clinton has crossed the threshold of 270 electoral votes needed to win the White House, with only a few toss-up states remaining. Even if Trump were to win all of the toss-up states, including Ohio, Florida, North Carolina, Iowa, Nevada, and Georgia, Clinton would still emerge victorious.

The next big opportunity for Trump to change the dynamics of the election is the upcoming debate schedule, with the first debate set for September 26 on Long Island, New York, followed by the vice presidential debate on October 4 in Virginia, and the second presidential debate on October 9 in St. Louis.

In other developments, the NPR Battleground Map has moved three traditionally red states in Clinton's direction: Georgia, Utah, and one electoral vote in Nebraska. Georgia, in particular, has seen significant demographic changes over the past decade, with a growing non-white population that could potentially swing the state in Clinton's favor.

While Trump has held up well in some states, including Florida and Nevada, Clinton's strong turnout operation and demographic advantages in these states make them favorable for her. The Republican National Committee has, however, supplemented Trump's on-the-ground operation with additional staff in Florida to try to save the state.

The election landscape is subject to change, and few things are likely to remain constant almost three months out from Election Day. However, as things stand now, Clinton appears to be in a strong position to win the presidency.

Title: The Inner Chimp: Navigating Human Nature in a Complex World

Article:

The concept of human nature is complex and multifaceted, with both noble and base tendencies existing within each individual. The idea that humans are capable of both good and evil is a timeless theme explored in literature and philosophy. In the context of politics, this dichotomy is particularly relevant, as individuals are often driven by emotions, allegiances, and personal interests.

The story of Ivanka Trump and her child being confronted by a passenger on a flight is a recent example of the inner chimp rearing its head. While some may view the incident as a trivial matter, it highlights the importance of understanding human nature and the need for empathy and understanding.

In a broader sense, the inner chimp can manifest in various aspects of life, from personal relationships to professional interactions. It is essential to recognize that we are all capable of both good and bad behavior, and that our actions have consequences.

The concept of manners is often misunderstood as simply being polite or well-behaved. However, it is more than that. Manners are a social code that helps prevent violence and promotes cooperation. In a world where we are constantly interacting with others, it is crucial to understand the importance of respecting and valuing others.

The emergence of market capitalism and the Industrial Revolution have taught us how to cooperate with one another on a grand scale. However, this does not mean that we have transcended our primal instincts. Rather, we have developed social codes and rituals to prevent violence and promote harmony.

The current political climate is a prime example of the inner chimp rearing its head. Politics often brings out tribalism, and this year's election has been no exception. The 80-odd percent of Republicans who opposed bailouts under Barack Obama and then supported them under Donald Trump is a stark reminder of the power of allegiances and loyalties.

While it is natural to have these affinities and loyalties, it is essential to recognize that we are called to be more than our emotions and appetites. We are called to be human, to be morally and spiritually larger than what's within our own skins. And if that is beyond your personal capacity, you can still pass for human by minding your manners and treating others with respect and kindness.

In conclusion, the inner chimp is a reminder that human nature is complex and multifaceted. While we are capable of both good and bad behavior, it is essential to recognize the importance of empathy, understanding, and respect for others. By doing so, we can navigate the complexities of human nature and strive to be more than our primal instincts.

Title: Study Reveals Social Media Users' Silence on Controversial Topics

A recent study by the Pew Research Internet Project has shed light on the phenomenon of social media users' reluctance to share their opinions on controversial topics, such as politics and social issues. The study, which surveyed 1,801 adults, found that people are less likely to discuss divisive issues online than in person, and that those who frequent social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter are even less likely to share their opinions offline.

The study suggests that this "spiral of silence" may be due to fear of isolation or ostracism, as people may not want to risk losing friends or alienating others by expressing opinions that differ from their own. However, the report also notes that regular users of Facebook and Twitter who feel themselves to be in the majority are still less likely to express their opinions offline, which may indicate that the problem is not the spiral of silence, but rather the sheer volume of information and opinions online.

The study's findings raise important questions about the role of social media in shaping our opinions and behaviors. While social media can provide a platform for people to share their thoughts and connect with others, it can also create an environment where people feel overwhelmed and disconnected from others. As the report notes, "social media users may have witnessed those with minority opinions experiencing ostracism... this might increase the perceived risk of opinion sharing in other settings."

Ultimately, the study highlights the importance of considering the complexities of online communication and the ways in which it can both unite and divide us. As we navigate the digital landscape, it is essential to recognize the potential benefits and drawbacks of social media and to strive for a more nuanced understanding of its impact on our lives.

Title: The Growing Threat of Islamic Terrorism in North Africa: A Global Concern

Article:

The recent kidnapping of hundreds of schoolgirls in Nigeria by Boko Haram, an Islamic militant group, is a stark reminder of the growing threat of terrorism in North Africa. The group's increasing strength and reach, as well as its ability to conduct operations throughout Nigeria, is a matter of pressing concern for the international community.

Nigeria, with a population of approximately 174 million, is the most populous country in sub-Saharan Africa, and its instability could have far-reaching implications for the region and the world. The country's failure to effectively deal with Boko Haram's growing threat has led to a growing sense of unease and uncertainty.

The kidnapping of the schoolgirls is not an isolated incident. In January 2013, terrorists affiliated with Al Qaeda struck a natural gas production facility in Algeria, holding over 800 people hostage. The incident received minimal attention in the United States, and the situation in Mali, where terrorists nearly took over the entire country, remains far from secure.

The lack of attention to the growing terrorist threat in North Africa is surprising, given the creation of a separate African Command at the Pentagon, which was intended to address the region's security concerns. However, the Obama administration's initial decision to offer assistance from the FBI, while laudable, betrays its continued belief that global terrorism can be handled as a law-enforcement matter rather than a war.

The growing threat of Islamic terrorism in North Africa is a global concern, and it requires a comprehensive and coordinated response. The international community must work together to address the root causes of terrorism, including poverty, political instability, and social inequality. The kidnapping of the schoolgirls in Nigeria is a stark reminder of the need for a sustained and effective counterterrorism strategy in the region.

In conclusion, the growing threat of Islamic terrorism in North Africa is a pressing concern that requires immediate attention and action. The international community must work together to address the root causes of terrorism and to develop a comprehensive and coordinated response to this growing threat.

**Title:** Young Americans' Voter Turnout in Question as Midterm Elections Approach

**Article:**

As the 2018 primary season comes to a close, the focus shifts to the November midterm elections, which will test the Democratic Party's ability to harness opposition to President Donald Trump. A recent survey by the Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI) and The Atlantic has raised concerns about young Americans' voter turnout, with only 35% of those aged 18-29 saying they are "absolutely certain" to vote.

The survey, which polled 1,811 Americans over the age of 18, found that young voters are less likely to participate in the election compared to other age groups. In contrast, 81% of seniors (ages 65+) said they will vote in the midterms. This disparity could impact the outcome of the election, as young voters are a crucial demographic for Democrats.

According to PRRI CEO Robert P. Jones, if young voters turn out at modest rates, it could significantly tilt the scales in favor of Democratic candidates, who are currently supported by a margin of 61% to 35% among young Americans.

Researchers at PRRI attributed the low turnout among young voters to several factors, including feelings of being uninformed and a lack of faith in the voting process. Associate Director of Research Robert Griffin noted that young Americans may not believe voting can bring about change, with only 50% agreeing that voting regularly is the most effective way to create change.

While the survey's findings may seem concerning for Democrats, Griffin pointed out that special elections since 2016 have shown large swings to the left, suggesting that young voters may still play a significant role in the election outcome. The survey's margin of error was 3%, and participants were randomly selected, with an over-sampling of voters aged 18-29 to gather more data from this demographic.

The survey's results highlight the importance of voter registration and education efforts, particularly among young Americans. As Election Day approaches, it remains to be seen whether young voters will turn out in significant numbers to shape the outcome of the midterm elections.

**House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan Reiterates Efforts to Repeal Obamacare**

House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan has reiterated his push to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, as part of his plan to balance the federal budget within the next decade. Ryan's stance has sparked debate among politicians and experts, with some viewing it as a long shot and others seeing it as a necessary step towards fiscal responsibility.

Ryan's plan, which is expected to be released this week, aims to reduce the national debt by making tough choices and addressing the country's problems. However, his efforts to repeal Obamacare have been met with skepticism, as the Supreme Court narrowly upheld the law last year and a recent poll found that only 33% of Americans support its repeal.

Despite the challenges, Ryan remains committed to his goal, citing the need to address the country's fiscal issues and make difficult decisions to fix its problems. "This is what budgeting is all about, Chris," he told Chris Wallace on Fox News Sunday. "It's about making tough choices to fix our country's problems."

Ryan's stance is seen as a way to appeal to the Republican base, particularly if he decides to run for president in 2016. Political experts believe that his continued push to repeal Obamacare is a bargaining position that will help him secure the nomination.

However, others argue that repealing Obamacare would not significantly reduce the national debt and could actually increase it. The Congressional Budget Office and Joint Committee on Taxation estimated that repealing the ACA would reduce direct spending by $890 billion and reduce revenues by $1 trillion between 2013 and 2022, adding $109 billion to federal budget deficits over that period.

Despite the controversy, Ryan's plan is expected to be met with resistance from Democrats, who see the ACA as a crucial step towards ensuring healthcare for millions of Americans. Senate Budget Committee Chairman Patty Murray is expected to unveil a budget that includes an increase in taxes for wealthy Americans and businesses, as well as cuts to spending, to address the deficit.

The debate surrounding Ryan's plan highlights the ongoing struggle to address the country's fiscal issues and the challenges of finding common ground between political parties.

Title: Liberty University's Reopening Sparks Controversy, But Facts Tell a Different Story

Article:

The decision by Liberty University's President, Jerry Falwell Jr., to partially reopen the evangelical university in March sparked widespread criticism and concern about the potential risks of COVID-19 transmission. The New York Times published an article suggesting that Falwell's decision had put students at risk, claiming that a dozen students had contracted the disease and that one had tested positive. The article also quoted Dr. Eppes, implying that the university had lost control of the situation.

However, a closer examination of the facts reveals a different story. A friend who works at the Falirk Center reached out to the author, sharing facts that contradicted the article's claims. Additionally, friends with children at Liberty reported that the university was largely deserted, with only a small number of foreign students remaining on campus. Data released by Liberty showed that less than 1,500 out of 15,000 students were left on campus, mostly foreign students.

Furthermore, Dr. Eppes came forward to deny the accuracy of the quote attributed to him. The article's ominous warnings about a COVID outbreak did not come to fruition, with no confirmed cases of the disease reported. The university stated that there were no confirmed positive cases, and no one in the media could confirm even a single infection contracted on campus.

The article's claims about students "starting to get sick" were also misleading, as it did not specify what symptoms they had or whether they were confirmed COVID cases. The university took precautions, including constant cleaning of frequently touched surfaces, removing computers from the lab to ensure social distancing, and quarantining suspected cases in a former hotel three miles from campus. Two surprise visits from state health inspectors found no violations.

The article's sensationalized claims and lack of concrete evidence have been widely criticized, with even a sober-minded columnist like William McGurn of the Wall Street Journal questioning the accuracy of the story. McGurn noted that no Liberty student or staffer tested positive, and the university followed all public health guidelines and took additional precautions.

The author of the article acknowledges that they initially believed the story, but later realized it was factually wrong. The article serves as a reminder that even reputable news sources can get it wrong, and that it's essential to verify facts and consider multiple perspectives before drawing conclusions.

Title: Trump Threatens to Block USPS Funding Unless Package Shipping Prices Increase

Article:

In a recent statement, President Trump expressed his intention to block financial aid to the United States Postal Service (USPS) unless it raises package shipping prices on retail giants like Amazon. The President believes that the postal service should increase rates by approximately four times, citing that it is a "joke" and that Amazon and other big shipping retailers are getting too good a deal.

The CARES Act, signed into law last month, included a provision allowing the USPS to borrow up to $10 billion from the Treasury Department to make up for losses during the coronavirus pandemic. However, Trump has tied this lending plan to "postal reform," which would require the USPS to raise rates.

Trump's comments have sparked controversy, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi accusing the Trump administration of trying to use its leverage over the loan to seek to privatize the USPS. Pelosi urged Americans to speak up in favor of their mail carriers, who are especially vital for delivering medicine and communications for senior citizens.

The USPS has repeatedly defended its arrangement with Amazon, stating that it is a mutually beneficial partnership. The postal service has also received high approval ratings from the public, with many Americans relying on it for essential services.

The debate surrounding the USPS and its relationship with Amazon highlights the complex issues surrounding the postal service and its role in the modern economy. While Trump's comments have sparked controversy, the real question remains: what is the best way to ensure the USPS remains a vital and efficient service for all Americans?

Title: US Expands Travel Ban to Six Additional Countries, Critics Slam Policy as Discriminatory

Article:

The US government has expanded its travel ban to six additional countries, citing concerns over national security and information-sharing standards. The move, announced on Friday, adds Eritrea, Kyrgyzstan, Myanmar, Nigeria, Sudan, and Tanzania to the list of countries affected by the ban.

The ban, which was first introduced in 2017, has been widely criticized by immigrant advocates and human rights groups, who argue that it discriminates against Muslims and other minority groups. The new restrictions will take effect on February 21 and will suspend the issuance of visas that can lead to permanent residency for nationals of the six new countries.

The Trump administration claims that the six countries failed to meet US security and information-sharing standards, citing issues such as subpar passport technology and a failure to share information on terrorism suspects and criminals. However, critics argue that the ban is a thinly veiled attempt to target Muslims and other minority groups.

The ban will not affect non-immigrant visas, which include those for tourism, short-term business, medical purposes, education, and journalism, among other types. In December, about 650,760 non-immigrant visas were granted worldwide.

Immigrant visas, on the other hand, will be affected, including those for spouses, certain family members, and certain sponsored employment. However, the Trump administration has said there are exceptions to the restrictions.

The US government will also stop issuing "diversity visas" to nationals of Sudan and Tanzania, which are available by lottery for applicants from countries with low rates of immigration to the US. Nigeria is already excluded from the lottery, along with other countries that had more than 50,000 natives immigrate to the US in the previous five years.

The existing ban, which includes the Muslim-majority nations of Iran, Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen, as well as North Korea and Venezuela, allows for exceptions, including for students and those who have established "significant contacts" in the US. The Venezuelan ban mostly affects government officials and their family members.

The expanded ban has sparked widespread criticism, with many arguing that it is a discriminatory and harmful policy that undermines the values of inclusivity and diversity that the US is built on.

**Senate Votes to Alter Rules, Clearing Way for Presidential Nominees**

In a move aimed at breaking gridlock and streamlining the confirmation process, the US Senate voted 52-48 to alter its rules and eliminate the possibility of a filibuster for presidential nominees. The change, known as the "nuclear option," allows the White House to flood the chamber with prospective officials who have been blocked by Republicans.

President Obama expressed strong support for the move, stating that "enough is enough" and that public service is not a game, but a privilege. He emphasized that the change is not about his ability to fulfill his constitutional duty, but about the ability of any president to fulfill their constitutional duty.

The nuclear option does not extend to Supreme Court nominees, although Republicans have vowed to use the new rules to push through their own high-court picks if a Republican occupies the White House in the future.

The move gives the White House the opportunity to change the conversation away from the botched rollout of Obamacare, which has consumed Washington for the past month. The change is seen as a step towards making the gears of government work more effectively and ending some of the gridlock that has gripped Washington in recent years.

The Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, and a majority of senators supported the change, while GOP leaders vehemently objected and cast the step as a power grab. The move is seen as a significant shift in the way the Senate does business and a potential game-changer for the confirmation process.

Title: Trump Defends Putin Meeting, Blames Media for Poor Reception

Article:

President Donald Trump has defended his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin, saying it was a "great" meeting and that the media is to blame for the poor reception. Trump took to Twitter to express his thoughts, stating that he had a "better" meeting with Putin than with NATO leaders, and that the media is "going crazy" over the summit.

However, lawmakers from both sides of the aisle have criticized Trump for taking Putin's word over that of U.S. intelligence officials, who have concluded that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election. Senator Bob Corker, a Republican, called for legislation to counter some of Trump's foreign policy moves, including tariffs on imports, saying that Trump is "pushing away our allies and further strengthening Putin."

Other Republicans, such as Senator Rand Paul, have defended Trump's meeting with Putin, with Paul stating that the president has been "totally partisan" and that it's "what's he supposed to think?" However, even some Republicans, such as former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, have expressed dismay over Trump's performance, calling it the "most serious mistake of his presidency."

Democrats have been quick to condemn Trump's comments, with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi calling his actions "dangerous, disgraceful, and damaging." Some have even gone as far as to say that Trump's comments amount to an impeachable offense or even treason.

The meeting between Trump and Putin has sparked widespread criticism, with many questioning Trump's commitment to the alliance and his willingness to take Putin's denials of Russian interference at face value. The meeting has also raised concerns about the potential for Russian interference in future elections, with some calling for increased vigilance and action to prevent such interference.

In the end, the meeting between Trump and Putin has left many questions unanswered, and the debate over its implications will likely continue for some time.

Title: Republican Leaders Boycott ObamaCare Committee, Citing Concerns Over Medicare Costs

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, Republican leaders in the House and Senate have announced that they will boycott the Individual Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), a committee established as part of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) to help control Medicare costs. The decision was met with criticism from the White House, which slammed the move as a "rehashing of tired attacks" on the healthcare law.

The IPAB, also known as the "death panel" by some critics, has the authority to reduce payments to providers and eliminate certain treatments if Medicare costs rise above certain levels. Republicans argue that this could lead to reduced access to care for seniors, citing concerns that doctors may stop seeing patients due to reduced payments.

House Speaker John Boehner and Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, in a letter to President Obama, reiterated their call to repeal the IPAB entirely, citing concerns that it would lead to reduced access to care for seniors. They argue that the panel's authority to reduce payments to providers would lead to a reduction in the number of doctors willing to accept Medicare patients.

The White House, however, has emphasized that the IPAB is designed to help control Medicare costs and improve the overall healthcare system. Press Secretary Jay Carney slammed the Republican move, saying it was a "rehashing of tired attacks" on the healthcare law.

The boycott is unlikely to have a significant impact on the IPAB, as the law requires the President to consult with Congress on nominations, but the President has the authority to make his own appointments. The members of the board are supposed to be from both parties and nominees would be subject to Senate confirmation.

The move is the latest in a long-standing debate over the Affordable Care Act, with Republicans repeatedly voting to repeal or partially repeal the law. The House has voted to repeal the law 37 times, although the Democratic-controlled Senate has consistently rejected these efforts.

Title: Obama Meets with Allies to Discuss ISIS Strategy Amid Concerns Over Progress

Article:

President Barack Obama met with defense chiefs from 21 countries to discuss the ongoing campaign against the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq and Syria. The meeting comes as the militant group continues to gain ground in both countries, prompting questions about the effectiveness of the US strategy.

The US-led coalition has made some progress, such as driving ISIS away from the Mosul Dam, but the president remains concerned about the besieged Syrian town of Kobani and parts of Iraq's Anbar province. Critics, including Republican Senator John McCain, have challenged the president's strategy, saying that ISIS is winning and the US is not.

Military analyst Anthony Cordesman agrees, stating that the air war has been limited and slow, with an average of 15 strikes per day. The pace of airstrikes has picked up around Kobani, but Obama stressed that the campaign cannot be won solely through military means.

The president emphasized the need to offer political and economic alternatives to the militants, as well as to address the ideological strain of extremism that has taken root in the region. However, the US-led military effort is being hampered by sectarian and political divisions, including disagreements between the US and Turkey over which enemy in Syria is the bigger threat.

Michael O'Hanlon of the Brookings Institution warned that airstrikes can only do so much and that the US needs cooperation from local ground forces to defeat ISIS. Until that cooperation materializes, O'Hanlon said ISIS will likely expand its control by a few percent, but not make huge new inroads.

While Obama has ruled out sending American ground troops into battle, O'Hanlon suggested that a limited presence of US Special Forces and military spotters could be helpful. The president has promised that the campaign will be a long-term effort, and the US is still in the early stages of what promises to be a complex and challenging fight against ISIS.

Title: Flynn's Influence Lingers: Trump's Loyalty to Former National Security Adviser Raises Questions

Article:

The departure of Michael Flynn from the White House has not diminished his influence over the Trump administration. Despite being out of the White House for 84 days, Flynn's presence still casts a long shadow over the presidency. The president has praised Flynn as a "wonderful man" and tweeted in his defense, giving him a lingering influence over policy in the White House.

Flynn's loyalists, including his deputy K.T. McFarland, remain on the National Security Council and in other positions. Senior administration officials, including chief strategist Steve Bannon, have also remained loyal to Flynn and have worked to undermine his successor, Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster. This has led to a controversy surrounding the administration's ties to Russia, with allegations of inappropriate contacts between Trump campaign aides and Russian government officials still under investigation.

Flynn's failure to disclose his contacts with Russian officials and payments received from Russian government-related entities has deepened the appearance of scandal around the administration. NBC News reported that Flynn failed to disclose to the Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) when it renewed his security clearance last year that he received a check totaling nearly $34,000 from a Russian propaganda network.

Acting Attorney General Sally Yates warned the White House that Flynn was susceptible to blackmail, though she declined to say why. Former President Barack Obama also warned Trump against hiring Flynn when they met after Trump's victory in November. Flynn's relationship with Trump differs markedly from that of his successor, McMaster, who has clashed with the president repeatedly since joining the administration.

The president has pushed back against McMaster's attempts to replace McFarland, who is set to become ambassador to Singapore. Last week, it was McFarland, not McMaster, who accompanied the president to a meeting with the Australian prime minister in New York. Trump and McFarland kept reporters waiting on the tarmac for 40 minutes as they talked inside the plane at Andrews Air Force Base on Sunday night, after the president spent the weekend golfing at his club in New Jersey.

White House chief of staff Reince Priebus prevented McMaster from bringing on Brig. Gen. Ricky Waddell as his deputy, and though McFarland was supposed to depart for Singapore in mid-May, she has been telling associates in recent weeks that she's not leaving her NSC post anytime soon. McMaster has worked to reshape the organization in the wake of Flynn's departure, removing Bannon from the NSC's Principals Committee and eliminating a handful of positions created by Flynn.

The article does not take a stance or make any value judgments, instead presenting the facts and quotes from various sources to provide a balanced view of the situation.

Title: Reflecting on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s Legacy: A Personal Perspective

Article:

As we mark the 50th anniversary of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, I am reminded of the profound impact he had on my life. Growing up in poverty, I was introduced to Dr. King's work at a young age, and his message of equality and justice resonated deeply with me.

As an 8-year-old boy, I was fascinated by the news reports of a young black man who was making a difference in the world. My mother, a keen observer of the news, would often watch Dr. King's speeches and interviews on TV, and I would sit with her, mesmerized by his words and actions. His message of nonviolent resistance and his unwavering commitment to the civil rights movement inspired me to learn more about his life and work.

As I grew older, I began to understand the magnitude of Dr. King's courage and determination. Despite facing immense challenges and threats to his life, he never wavered in his pursuit of justice and equality. His "I Have a Dream" speech, which I read as a child, became a beacon of hope and inspiration for me.

Dr. King's message of equality and human rights transcends race, gender, and faith. As a conservative Christian, I believe that his wisdom and compassion are essential in today's divided and angry world. His words and actions remind us that we are all created equal, deserving of respect, dignity, and protection.

As someone who has worked in politics and government for over 20 years, I have seen firsthand the impact of Dr. King's legacy. His message of nonviolent resistance and his commitment to social justice have inspired countless individuals to work towards a more just and equitable society.

In this era of division and polarization, Dr. King's wisdom and compassion are needed now more than ever. His legacy serves as a reminder that we are all human beings, deserving of respect, dignity, and protection. As we reflect on his life and work, I am convinced that his contributions to our nation and the world have been vastly underestimated.

Title: Ethiopia Faces Worst Drought in Decades, Leaving Millions Without Food and Water

Article:

Ethiopia is facing its worst drought in decades, leaving millions of people without access to food and water. The country's agricultural sector, which is the main source of livelihood for 80% of the population, has been severely affected by the drought. The government and the United Nations are working together to raise $1.4 billion to feed 10.2 million Ethiopians, but only half of the funds have been received so far.

The drought has forced the government to find additional food aid from the United States and other donors. The U.S. Agency for International Development has dispatched an emergency response team to Ethiopia to provide assistance, including nearly $4 million in corn and wheat seeds for over 200,000 families.

Malnutrition rates in the worst-affected areas have surpassed 20%, higher than the World Health Organization's emergency threshold of 15%. The United Nations' World Food Programme estimates that over 2 million children, pregnant women, and breastfeeding mothers are suffering from moderate acute malnutrition. The UNICEF estimates that almost 500,000 children need treatment for severe acute malnutrition.

The situation is dire, with many people forced to migrate to different areas in search of water and pasture for their livestock, as well as jobs. As a result, many people are missing out on food rationing programs. One woman, Haso Bultum, 27, has been walking for hours in the sun across barren mountains with her malnourished 9-month-old twins.

The lack of access to water is another major issue, with almost 6 million people in need of emergency water supplies. The UNICEF estimates that the prevalence of disease will increase without access to clean water and sanitation.

The situation is critical, with the World Food Programme warning that it could run out of food within two months unless significant new funding is received. The Children's and Family Charitable Organization in Fentale has also warned that the lack of access to water is a major issue, with the river drying up and sanitation becoming impossible.

For those affected by the drought, the future looks bleak. Genet Tamisat, 27, is one of the many mothers waiting to have her children checked for malnutrition. She has nothing to eat at home and can't even buy maize by herself. "We are in great danger," she said. "We have nothing."

The situation in Ethiopia highlights the urgent need for international support and funding to address the crisis. The world must come together to help those affected by the drought and ensure that they receive the assistance they need to survive.

Title: Denver City Council Rejects Proposal to Ban Marijuana Use on Private Property in Public View

Article:

The Denver City Council has voted 7-6 to reject a proposal that would have prohibited marijuana use on private property if it was in public view. The proposal, introduced by Councilwoman Jeanne Robb, aimed to ban marijuana consumption in any outdoor location on private residential property where it was "clearly observable from a public street, highway, or sidewalk."

The proposal was met with opposition from advocates who argued that it would strip away the rights of adults to consume cannabis on their own property. Mason Tvert, communications director for the Marijuana Policy Project, stated that the proposal is "irrational" and "strips away the rights voted by residents of Colorado to consume cannabis."

The Denver City Council's decision comes as Colorado prepares to start legalizing the sale of recreational marijuana on January 1. The city's police chief, Robert White, has stated that if the proposal had been passed, it would not have been a priority for the police department and did not expect many citations to be written.

The decision is seen as a victory for advocates of marijuana legalization, who argue that it is a matter of personal freedom and autonomy. However, opponents of the proposal believe that it is necessary to prevent the negative impacts of marijuana use on public health and safety.

The debate surrounding marijuana legalization is not limited to Denver. Other cities and states are also grappling with the issue, including Washington state, which legalized the possession of up to one ounce of recreational marijuana for people 21 and older in 2012. Illinois is also considering a measure that would allow medical marijuana use, with the Chicago City Council still needing to vote on the proposal.

The decision by the Denver City Council highlights the ongoing debate surrounding marijuana legalization and the challenges of balancing individual rights with public health and safety concerns.

Title: Conservative Media Outlets to Convene at CPAC to Address Credibility Concerns

Article:

Conservative media outlets are set to gather at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) to discuss the future of conservative journalism and address concerns about credibility. The panel, titled "Survivor: Conservative Journalism," will bring together representatives from leading conservative news outlets, including Fox News, Townhall, and The Daily Caller, to tackle the issue of how conservative media can gain more recognition and credibility among the mainstream media.

The panel is a timely discussion, given the recent controversy surrounding conservative media outlets and their reporting practices. In the wake of last year's election, conservative media has faced criticism for being too aggressive, too weaponized, and too loose with the facts. The failed efforts to discredit figures like Chuck Hagel, now President Obama's secretary of defense, have also raised questions about the reliability of conservative reporting.

Keith Urbahn, a former chief of staff to Donald Rumsfeld and one of the panelists, emphasized the importance of conservative media outlets adhering to basic reporting standards. "That the conservative movement now has its own media outlets is a terrific thing. But with that comes a basic responsibility to report facts and admit error – something we slam the mainstream media for all the time. We don't always live up to those standards," he said.

Erick Erickson, a prominent conservative blogger, has argued that conservative journalists have "forgotten the basics of reporting" because they are too focused on highlighting controversies, no matter how trivial. Alex Koppelman, editor at The New Yorker, has also criticized right-wing journalists for not taking their commitment to journalism seriously enough.

The panelists at CPAC will likely discuss ways to improve the quality of conservative reporting and increase credibility among the mainstream media. Katie Pavilch, news editor of Townhall and another panelist, emphasized the importance of "solid and documented investigative reporting" in gaining credibility.

The discussion at CPAC is an important step towards addressing the concerns about conservative media and its credibility. As the media landscape continues to evolve, it is crucial for conservative outlets to prioritize accuracy and fairness in their reporting to maintain the trust of their audience.

Title: NFL and NBA Players Respond to Trump's Criticism

Article:

In a recent series of tweets, President Trump sparked controversy by criticizing NFL and NBA players, specifically targeting Colin Kaepernick and Stephen Curry. The president's comments have been met with strong reactions from athletes and league officials.

Trump's initial tweet about Kaepernick, who has been a vocal advocate for social justice and has been kneeling during the national anthem to protest police brutality and racial inequality, sparked outrage among many NFL players. Several players, including Zach Brown and Eric Ebron, took to Twitter to express their disappointment and frustration with the president's comments.

The NBA also got caught up in the controversy, with Trump announcing that Curry was no longer welcome at the White House after the Golden State Warriors point guard said he did not want to visit the president. LeBron James, the vice president of the NBA Players Association, responded to the news, calling Trump a "bum" and saying that visiting the White House was an honor until the president showed up.

The NFL and NBA have been at the forefront of social justice movements, with many players using their platforms to speak out against racial inequality and police brutality. Trump's comments have been seen as a further attempt to divide the country and undermine the progress made by these athletes.

The NFL and NBA have both issued statements condemning Trump's comments, with the NFL saying that the league and its players are at their best when they help create a sense of unity in the country and culture. The NBA has also spoken out against Trump's rhetoric, with Chris Paul, the head of the NBA Players Association, questioning whether the president would call players "a son of a b----" to their face.

The controversy comes as Trump's party's efforts to repeal and replace ObamaCare have stalled, with Senator John McCain coming out against the plan. Trump has also been criticized for his handling of Hurricane Harvey and other natural disasters, with many seeing his comments as a distraction from the real issues facing the country.

Overall, the controversy highlights the deep divisions in the country and the ongoing struggle for social justice and equality. While Trump's comments may have sparked a lot of attention, they have also sparked a lot of outrage and frustration among many Americans.

Title: American Families' Financial Situation: A Mixed Picture

The latest survey on American families' financial situation has shed light on the devastating impact of the economic crisis on the middle class. The report highlights the limited progress made by households in reducing their debt and the shift in the reasons they save money. While consumer spending has remained resilient, families have saved less and only slowly repaid debts.

The survey found that the share of families saving anything over the previous year fell to 52% in 2010 from 56.4% in 2007. Additionally, the median amount saved has not changed, indicating that a smaller group of families is saving more, while a growing number manage to save nothing.

The report also revealed that families are saving less for long-term goals, such as retirement, education, and down payments on homes. Instead, they are saving more as a precautionary measure to ensure they have enough liquidity to meet short-term needs.

The survey also showed that the share of households reporting any debt declined by 2.1 percentage points over the last three years, but 74.9% of households still owed something. The median amount of debt did not change, indicating that families are still struggling to reduce their debt burden.

However, the report noted that families have been able to reduce debt payments by refinancing into mortgages with longer terms and deferring repayment of student loans and other obligations. Additionally, historically low interest rates have helped to offset the increased weight of debt.

The survey also confirmed that Americans are shifting the types of debts they carry. The share of families with credit card debt declined by 6.7 percentage points to 39.4%, and the median balance fell 16.1% to $2,600. Families also reduced the number of credit cards they carried, with 32% saying they had no cards, up from 27% in 2007.

The report also highlighted large disparities in the impact of the crisis, with families in the middle 60% of the population losing a larger share of their wealth over the three-year period than the wealthiest and poorest families. This is largely due to the fact that the wealth of the middle class is mostly in housing, and the median amount of home equity dropped to $75,000 in 2010 from $110,000 in 2007.

The data provides the latest indication that the recession reduced income inequality in the United States, at least temporarily. The average income of the wealthiest families fell much more sharply than the median, indicating that some of those at the very top of the ladder slipped down at least a few rungs.

Overall, the survey paints a mixed picture of American families' financial situation, highlighting both the challenges and opportunities that families face in the current economic climate.

Title: Washington's Tax Hike Reality Check: Republicans Face Tough Choices

Article:

As the deadline for the Bush tax rates to expire approaches, the reality of a tax hike is setting in for Republicans. With just three weeks to go, the question is no longer if tax rates will increase, but by how much and for whom. The debate centers around a possible small boost in marginal tax rates, coupled with raising the threshold for wealthy Americans facing tax increases from $250,000 to $500,000 or higher in annual income.

The proposal, which would require serious cuts to entitlement programs, has yet to be formally offered by the White House. Democrats are holding firm, refusing to give up concessions on entitlement programs without significant moves from Republicans. "We are winning," said a top Hill Democratic staffer. "We don't have to give up on anything yet."

House Speaker John Boehner and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell are under pressure to come to an agreement with President Barack Obama. However, Boehner has refused to agree to any increase in tax rates, citing concerns that it would cost jobs. "The speaker is opposed to raising tax rates, because raising tax rates costs jobs," said Michael Steel, spokesman for Boehner.

Meanwhile, some Senate Republicans are skeptical of the proposal, with Senator Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) stating, "That doesn't really help solve the problem. I'm against raising tax rates. We know that if we raise those tax rates and we don't have corresponding reductions in spending, we'll get the tax rates and no spending reductions. That's just a game that the Democrats play over and over and over, and the American people let them get away with it sometimes."

The debate highlights the challenges facing Republicans in finding a solution that balances their opposition to tax increases with the need to address the country's fiscal issues. With the highest marginal tax rate set to jump from 35% to 39.6% on January 1, the stakes are high. The alternative minimum tax will also increase, affecting nearly 30 million more Americans. The question remains: can Republicans find a way to compromise and avoid a tax hike, or will the burden fall squarely on the shoulders of the wealthy?

**Senate Republicans Revise Tax Cut Bill to Include Repeal of Obamacare's Individual Mandate**

The Senate Republicans have revised their tax cut bill to include the repeal of Obamacare's individual mandate, a move that could free up more money for deeper tax cuts and take a swipe at the healthcare law they have repeatedly tried to repeal.

The revised bill, which is expected to be voted on this week, would eliminate the penalty for not having health insurance, a provision that has been a key component of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) since its inception. The move is seen as a way to generate an estimated $300 billion in savings over the next decade, which could be used to fund even more tax cuts for the middle class.

The repeal of the individual mandate has been a long-sought goal for Republicans, who have argued that it is an unpopular and ineffective provision that has failed to achieve its intended goal of increasing health insurance coverage. However, Democrats have criticized the move, saying it will lead to higher premiums and fewer people with health insurance.

The revised bill also includes a number of other changes, including a doubling of the child tax credit and a new 17.4% deduction for "pass-through" companies that file their taxes as individuals. The bill would also eliminate a number of deductions, including the one for state and local taxes paid.

The revised bill is seen as a key part of the Republican's plan to pass a comprehensive tax overhaul before the end of the year. The House and Senate are expected to vote on their respective versions of the bill this week, with a final package expected to be sent to President Trump's desk by the end of the year.

While the repeal of the individual mandate is seen as a key provision of the bill, it is not the only change. The revised bill would also lower the corporate tax rate from 35% to 20% and lower the top individual tax rate from 39.6% to 38.5%. The plan would also adjust other individual tax brackets so they kick in at higher income thresholds.

The revised bill is seen as a key part of the Republican's plan to give voters a reason to turn out in next year's midterm elections. The party views the tax overhaul effort as a way to deliver on their campaign promises and provide a boost to the economy.

However, Democrats have criticized the move, saying it will lead to higher premiums and fewer people with health insurance. They have also argued that the bill is a giveaway to corporations and the wealthy, and that it will not benefit the middle class.

The revised bill is expected to be voted on this week, with a final package expected to be sent to President Trump's desk by the end of the year.

Title: The Benghazi Hearing: A Glimpse into the Democratic Mindset

Article:

The recent hearing on the Benghazi attack, where Secretary of State Hillary Clinton finally answered questions about the 2012 incident, shed light on the Democratic mindset and what may be coming in 2016. The hearing was intended to find out what went wrong and why the administration initially claimed the attack was a spontaneous protest over a YouTube video. However, Clinton's responses revealed a disturbing pattern of evasive behavior and a lack of accountability.

Clinton's defense of the administration's initial narrative was met with skepticism by lawmakers, who had been seeking answers for months. She repeatedly emphasized that the focus should be on finding and bringing to justice those responsible for the attack, rather than dwelling on the past. This stance was seen as a way to sidestep accountability and avoid taking responsibility for the administration's mistakes.

The hearing also highlighted the administration's tendency to downplay the severity of the attack and its own role in the aftermath. Clinton's statement that "what difference does it make?" was seen as a dismissive and evasive response to lawmakers' questions. This attitude is reminiscent of the Clinton administration's handling of other scandals, such as Bill Clinton's affair with a White House intern and Hillary Clinton's involvement in the Whitewater scandal.

The hearing raised concerns about the administration's willingness to deceive and mislead the public. The Obama administration's initial claims about the attack being a spontaneous protest over a video were later revealed to be false, and the administration's subsequent attempts to cover up the truth were seen as a breach of trust.

The hearing also sparked concerns about the potential for future administrations to adopt similar tactics. The Democratic mindset, as exemplified by Clinton's responses, seems to prioritize power and control over transparency and accountability. This raises questions about the integrity of future presidential campaigns and the accountability of those in power.

In conclusion, the Benghazi hearing provided a glimpse into the Democratic mindset and what may be coming in 2016. The hearing highlighted the administration's tendency to downplay the severity of the attack and its own role in the aftermath, as well as its willingness to deceive and mislead the public. As the 2016 presidential election approaches, it is essential to remain vigilant and hold those in power accountable for their actions.

Title: Roger Ailes, Media Executive and Former Fox News Founder, Dies at 77

Article:

Roger Ailes, the television pioneer who built Fox News into a cable powerhouse before leaving the company last year, died on Thursday at the age of 77. Ailes was a confidant of presidents and an acknowledged master of communications, known for his ability to shape the media landscape and politics.

Born in Ohio, Ailes founded Fox News in 1996 and built it into the nation's longest-running No. 1 cable news network. He resigned from Fox in July amid charges of sexual harassment. His widow, Elizabeth Ailes, confirmed the news in a statement, saying she was "profoundly sad and heartbroken" to report her husband's passing.

Ailes' death was confirmed by the Palm Beach County Medical Examiner's Office, which said he died of complications from a fall at his home on May 10. Rupert Murdoch, executive chairman of 21st Century Fox and Fox News Channel, expressed his sadness at the news, saying Ailes was a "brilliant broadcaster" who played a huge role in shaping America's media over the last 30 years.

Fox News host Sean Hannity also paid tribute to his former boss, tweeting that Ailes was a "great patriotic warrior" who had dramatically changed the political and media landscape for the better. Ailes left Fox under a cloud of controversy in July, although he denied the allegations.

Ailes' career spanned decades, during which he worked with several presidents, including Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan, and George H.W. Bush. He was a key player in several presidential campaigns and helped build CNBC before launching Fox News. Even after his career at Fox had ended, Ailes reportedly advised President Trump in preparation for debates.

Ailes was married to Elizabeth Ailes in 1998, and they had one son, Zachary, born on New Year's Day 2000.

**Newly Released Emails Show Hillary Clinton's Interactions with Lobbyists, Donors, and Business Interests During Her First Months as Secretary of State**

The State Department has released 44 previously unreleased emails from Hillary Clinton's time as Secretary of State, which were obtained by the conservative legal group Judicial Watch as part of a lawsuit. The emails, which cover Clinton's first three months in office in early 2009, show her interacting with lobbyists, political donors, and business interests.

The emails were recovered from the computer files of longtime Clinton aide Huma Abedin and include messages exchanged with a senior Morgan Stanley investment executive, whom Clinton met with later that year at her office in Washington. The emails also reveal discussions about the development of a modified BlackBerry for Clinton, which would have been used when she worked in a restricted State Department office that did not allow private phones.

The new emails are separate from the larger batch of work-related emails that FBI officials recovered from Clinton's private server. Clinton's legal team turned over more than 30,000 emails from her server to the State Department last March, but only after deleting another 30,000 messages that Clinton's team deemed private and personal.

The FBI plans to turn over the reconstructed Clinton emails to the State Department for public release. The new emails provide a glimpse into Clinton's interactions during her first months as Secretary of State, which may shed light on her relationships with various stakeholders and her approach to her role.

Clinton's campaign officials did not immediately respond to questions about the new emails. The release of these emails is part of an ongoing effort to provide transparency and accountability in government, and may help to inform the public's understanding of Clinton's time as Secretary of State.

Title: New Report Reveals John Podesta's Role in Russian Hack: A Cautionary Tale of Cybersecurity

Article:

A recent report by SecureWorks, a security firm, has shed new light on the hacking of John Podesta's email account, which was part of a larger cyber-attack on the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and other prominent figures. According to the report, Podesta fell victim to a phishing attack, where he unknowingly handed over his email password to hackers.

The hacking ring, known as Fancy Bear, sent emails to members of Clinton's inner circle with custom Bitly links leading to fake Gmail login pages. Podesta clicked on the link and entered his password, giving the hackers access to his account. This is not the first time Fancy Bear has been involved in a high-profile hack; they were also behind the attack on the German parliament, Italian military, Saudi foreign ministry, and other notable targets.

The report highlights the importance of cybersecurity and the need for individuals to be cautious when receiving suspicious emails. It also raises questions about the role of the Russian government in the hacking, as many intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia was behind the attacks. A Clinton spokesman stated that there is "no longer any doubt" that Putin is trying to help Donald Trump by weaponizing WikiLeaks.

The hacking of John Podesta's email account and the subsequent release of thousands of emails has become a major issue in the 2016 election. It has raised concerns about the vulnerability of American cybersecurity and the potential for foreign interference in the election. The incident serves as a cautionary tale for individuals to be vigilant and not fall prey to phishing attacks.

In conclusion, the hacking of John Podesta's email account is a reminder of the importance of cybersecurity and the need for individuals to be cautious when receiving suspicious emails. It also highlights the ongoing efforts of foreign actors to interfere in the election and the need for vigilance and cooperation to protect American democracy.

Title: Governors Weigh In on Trump's Plan to Reopen Businesses Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

As the United States continues to grapple with the COVID-19 pandemic, governors across the country are weighing in on the White House's three-phase plan to reopen the economy. The plan, released on Thursday, provides guidelines for states to begin loosening restrictions after new COVID-19 cases have declined for at least 14 days. However, the enthusiasm for the plan varies widely depending on party affiliation.

Democratic governors, such as New Mexico's Michelle Lujan Grisham and New York's Andrew Cuomo, have expressed concerns about the plan, citing the need for more testing support from the federal government. They argue that reopening too quickly could undo the progress made so far and lead to a resurgence of the virus.

"We can't put the cart before the horse," said Lujan Grisham. "As CDC, FEMA, and public health experts across the country have made clear, we are not at a point currently where it would be safe to reopen, and doing so prematurely would undo the heroic work of our health workers and first responders, endanger many more people, and essentially guarantee enhanced transmission of the virus, leading to more illness and death."

On the other hand, Republican governors, such as Tennessee's Bill Lee and Iowa's Kim Reynolds, have expressed more enthusiasm for the plan. They believe that the gradual reopening strategy outlined by the White House is a step in the right direction.

"I think the president and his team are headed in a very good direction," said Lee. "We're going to use the same sort of gradual reopening strategy."

Other governors, such as Colorado's Jared Polis and Oregon's Kate Brown, have called for more federal assistance in terms of testing and personal protective equipment (PPE). They argue that without a national testing strategy, states are left competing against each other for supplies, driving up prices.

"We are still in dire need of critical resources from the federal government, including sufficient PPE and increased testing capacity," said Brown. "We have current, large unfulfilled order requests with the federal government for both PPE and testing materials; these are vital components to reopening Oregon and remain necessary to prevent a resurgence of the disease."

Texas Governor Greg Abbott has taken a different approach, announcing a series of executive orders that will start to reopen shuttered businesses. According to The Hill, Texas is the first state to lay out a defined rollback of COVID-19 restrictions.

The debate highlights the challenges faced by governors as they navigate the complex and ever-changing landscape of the pandemic. While some governors are eager to reopen their economies, others are more cautious, citing the need for more testing and support from the federal government. As the country continues to grapple with the pandemic, it remains to be seen how governors will balance the need to reopen their economies with the need to protect their citizens.

**Trump Criticizes Media, Calls Coverage of Congresswomen "Fake News"**

President Donald Trump has launched a series of attacks on the media, specifically targeting The Washington Post, over coverage of his recent tweets targeting four progressive congresswomen. In a series of tweets, Trump accused the media of pushing "Radical Left Democrat views" and claimed that the coverage has "gone bonkers" and is "sick."

Trump took issue with a Washington Post story that reported on his attacks on Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Ilhan Omar, Rashida Tlaib, and Ayanna Pressley, saying that the story was "made up" and that he had no advisors who wrote out talking points or handed him "reams of opposition research" on the congresswomen.

The president also took to Twitter to decry "fake news" as "the Enemy of the People," claiming that the media is out of control and constantly lies and cheats to push its own agenda.

The controversy began when Trump launched a series of tweets telling the congresswomen to "go back" to their countries, despite all four being U.S. citizens. Since then, Trump has escalated his attacks, claiming that the lawmakers hate the country and defending supporters who chanted "send her back" about Omar as "incredible patriots."

The media has been critical of Trump's attacks, with many calling them racist and divisive. The Washington Post has stood by its reporting, saying that it has multiple sources that confirm the story.

The controversy has sparked a wider debate about the role of the media in covering the president and the importance of a free press in a democracy.

Title: Giuliani Clarifies Trump's Potential Pardon Stance in Russia Investigation

Article:

Rudy Giuliani, President Donald Trump's lead attorney, has clarified the president's stance on potential pardons for individuals involved in the ongoing Russia investigation. In an appearance on CNN's State of the Union, Giuliani stated that the president is not planning to issue pardons in the current investigation. However, he left open the possibility that the president could take action if he determines that individuals have been "treated unfairly" after the investigation concludes.

Giuliani's comments come after he raised the prospect of pardons last week, following the revocation of former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort's bond due to allegations of witness tampering. Manafort is awaiting trial on charges of money laundering and fraud.

Giuliani also renewed his criticism of the Russia investigation, led by Justice Department special counsel Robert Mueller, and called for a review of the investigation's origins. He cited findings in the Justice Department inspector general's report, which revealed text messages exchanged by FBI agents disparaging Trump. Giuliani believes that the investigation's legitimacy is compromised due to the agents' bias.

Giuliani's comments have sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that the president's potential pardons could be seen as an attempt to interfere with the investigation. However, Giuliani maintains that the president is simply seeking to ensure that individuals are treated fairly.

The Russia investigation is ongoing, with Mueller's team reviewing whether Trump sought to obstruct the probe after firing FBI Director James Comey last year. Giuliani has stated that the president wants to cooperate with the investigation, but is hesitant to agree to an interview with Mueller. A decision on the interview is expected by July 4.

In summary, Giuliani's comments have clarified the president's stance on potential pardons in the Russia investigation, while also highlighting ongoing tensions between the Trump administration and the investigation.

Title: Democrats' Grassroots Fundraising Surge Gives Them Financial Edge in Midterm Elections

Article:

The 2018 midterm elections are just four weeks away, and the financial landscape is shifting in favor of the Democratic Party. According to recent reports, 60 Democratic candidates have raised $1 million or more in the past three months, erasing the typical Republican fundraising edge. This surge in grassroots fundraising has given Democrats a substantial financial advantage, with many candidates outpacing their Republican opponents in terms of fundraising.

In California's 22nd congressional district, Democrat Andrew Janz raised an impressive $4.1 million in the third quarter, a significant amount that puts him in a strong position to challenge incumbent Republican Rep. Devin Nunes. Janz attributes his success to a widespread donor base, with many people wanting to see Nunes out of office.

Other Democratic challengers have also announced impressive fundraising numbers, including Sharice Davids in Kansas, who raised $2.7 million, and Amy McGrath in Kentucky, who raised $3.65 million. Elissa Slotkin in Michigan raised $2.6 million, a significant amount that puts her in a strong position to challenge her opponent.

The Congressional Leadership Fund, a GOP super PAC aligned with House Republicans, has spent $90 million on the general-election campaign, compared to $51 million by its Democratic rival, the House Majority PAC. However, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) has outspent the National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) $64 million to $47 million.

Democratic House candidates have also outspent their Republican opponents $109 million to $60 million, thanks to the outpouring of small-donor contributions. This grassroots energy has given Democrats a significant advantage in the final stretch of the election.

While fundraising success does not guarantee victory, it does give Democrats a strong foundation to build on. Many of these challengers are taking on incumbents who have won their seats before, making it a tough road ahead. However, the momentum and energy behind these Democratic candidates could be enough to propel them to victory.

As the election approaches, both parties are starting to reallocate their funds, with some House Republicans facing an uphill battle. The NRCC and CLF are canceling ad buys and shifting dollars to other contests with better prospects, a sign that some races may be all but over.

In conclusion, the 2018 midterm elections are shaping up to be a competitive and closely contested race, with Democrats enjoying a significant financial edge. While fundraising success is no guarantee of victory, it gives Democrats a strong foundation to build on and a chance to make significant gains in the House of Representatives.

Title: Fox News' Turbulent Summer: Ailes' Departure and the Aftermath

Article:

The summer of 2016 was marked by a series of dramatic events at Fox News, as the network's co-founder, Roger Ailes, faced allegations of sexual harassment and was eventually forced to step down. The sudden departure of Ailes, who had been a dominant figure in the network's success, sent shockwaves throughout the organization. In the aftermath, the company's leadership, led by James and Lachlan Murdoch, launched an internal investigation and made significant changes to the network's leadership.

The investigation, conducted by the law firm Paul, Weiss, was prompted by allegations of sexual harassment made by former anchor Gretchen Carlson against Ailes. The investigation led to the departure of several high-ranking executives, including Ailes' closest allies. However, some of his closest deputies, including Bill Shine and Dianne Brandi, were promoted to co-presidents of Fox News, a move that raised eyebrows among some employees.

The Murdochs' decision to promote Shine and Brandi was seen as a compromise between the need to distance themselves from the past and the desire to maintain some continuity with the network's successful past. While some employees were skeptical of the move, others saw it as a sign that the Murdochs were committed to changing the culture at Fox News.

The investigation also led to the departure of several other executives, including Mark Kranz, the former chief financial officer, and several of Ailes' closest assistants. The company also announced that it would be implementing new policies and procedures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The events of the summer of 2016 marked a significant turning point for Fox News, as the network grappled with the consequences of Ailes' departure and the need to rebuild its leadership. While some employees were skeptical of the Murdochs' ability to bring about real change, others saw the summer as an opportunity for the network to re-examine its values and priorities.

Title: White Nationalists Rally Against Confederate Statue Removal in Charlottesville

Article:

Hundreds of white nationalists gathered at the University of Virginia to protest the planned removal of a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee. The group, largely composed of young white men, waved torches and chanted slogans such as "White lives matter" and "You will not replace us" as they marched through the university campus.

The rally was met with resistance from a smaller group of counter-protesters, who held a banner reading "VA Students Act Against White Supremacy" near the university's statue of Thomas Jefferson. The two groups clashed violently, with pepper spray being used and police intervening to disperse the crowd.

The rally was organized by Jason Kessler, who has previously accused the town of "anti-white hatred." Kessler described the event as an "incredible moment for white people who've had it up to here and aren't going to take it anymore."

The Southern Poverty Law Center, a civil rights organization, notes that the rally was a response to the city council's decision to remove the statue of General Lee, which is seen as a symbol of the Confederacy and its support for slavery. The organization argues that the rally was a manifestation of white nationalist sentiment, which has been energized by the election of President Donald Trump.

The rally was criticized by local residents and politicians, including Charlottesville Mayor Mike Signer, who called it a "cowardly parade of hatred, bigotry, racism, and intolerance." The mayor also expressed his disgust at the unsanctioned and despicable display of intimidation on a college campus.

The city of Charlottesville has become a focal point for white nationalists since the city council voted to remove the statue of General Lee. The city's liberal leanings and the fact that 86% of the county voted for Hillary Clinton in the last presidential election have made it a target for white nationalists.
