The rally was also marked by the use of torches, which some observers described as a reference to the Ku Klux Klan. The marchers chanted slogans such as "Blood and soil" and "One people, one nation, end immigration," which some have interpreted as a call to action against immigration and diversity.

The event was a stark reminder of the ongoing struggle against white supremacy and the importance of standing up against hate and intolerance.

Title: Trump to Address UN, Criticize North Korea and Iran in First Speech

Article:

United States President Donald Trump is set to deliver his first speech to the United Nations General Assembly, where he is expected to call for increased international pressure on North Korea over its nuclear weapons program. The speech is scheduled to take place at 10:30 am New York time (14:30 GMT) and is expected to be a significant moment in Trump's presidency.

According to White House officials, Trump will refer to Islamist militants as "losers" and criticize Iran and Venezuela during his address. The US president has previously hinted at the possibility of cutting UN funding, a move that has sparked concerns about the potential consequences for global cooperation.

In his speech, Trump is expected to urge UN member states to take action against North Korea's "destabilizing, hostile, and dangerous behavior." North Korea has responded by saying that increased sanctions and pressure will only accelerate its nuclear program. The country has conducted several missile tests this year, despite international condemnation, and conducted its sixth nuclear test earlier this month.

Trump will also express concerns about Iran in his speech, citing the country's "aggressive development of ballistic missiles" and its support for the Syrian government. The US has been a vocal critic of the 2015 nuclear deal between Iran and world powers, and Trump has previously threatened to withdraw from the agreement.

A White House official briefing reporters on Trump's speech described Iran and North Korea as a "shared menace" to the world, saying that nations cannot be bystanders to history and must confront the threats now or risk them growing stronger.

Trump met with world leaders on Monday, including a special meeting on UN reform, and held talks with Latin American leaders, where he described the situation in Venezuela as "totally unacceptable" and called it a socialist dictatorship. He warned that the US is prepared to take further action if the Venezuelan government persists.

The UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has warned that if the US withdraws from international affairs, the void left will be filled by others. The stakes are high, and the world will be watching closely as Trump delivers his speech and outlines his vision for global cooperation and security.

Title: White House Spokesperson Warns of Trump's Enduring Frustration with Attorney General Sessions

Article:

The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, has warned that President Trump's frustration with Attorney General Jeff Sessions is not abating, following a series of tweets in which the President criticized Sessions for being "VERY weak" on Hillary Clinton's supposed "crimes." Sanders made the comments during an appearance on "Fox & Friends," where she neither confirmed nor denied reports that Trump has discussed the possibility of firing Sessions.

While Sanders did not rule out the possibility of a change, she emphasized that Trump is "frustrated and disappointed" in Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the Russia meddling probe. She also stated that Trump has not been part of any conversations discussing potential replacements for Sessions.

The President's tweets, which targeted Sessions' handling of the investigation into Clinton's connections to Ukraine and his alleged stance on other Clinton controversies, sparked speculation about the possibility of Sessions' resignation or firing. However, Sessions has maintained that he intends to stay in his post, despite Trump's criticism.

The situation has raised concerns about the potential impact on the Department of Justice and the ongoing Russia investigation. If Trump were to fire Sessions, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein would be elevated to the top post on an acting basis, potentially leading to further controversy and speculation about the President's intentions.

The President's criticism of Sessions comes after the Attorney General faced backlash for his decision to recuse himself from the Russia investigation, which Trump has publicly criticized. Sessions has maintained that he made the decision to recuse himself to avoid any appearance of impropriety, but Trump has called it "very unfair" and "very weak."

The situation has also sparked concerns about the potential impact on staff morale within the administration. Newt Gingrich, a frequent Trump adviser, warned that the President's public criticism of Sessions could "rattle the whole team" and undermine morale.

Despite the ongoing tensions, Sessions has maintained that he intends to continue doing his job, stating that he is "totally confident" that he can continue to run the Department of Justice effectively.

Title: Federal Agents' Deployment in Portland and Chicago Sparks Controversy

Article:

The deployment of federal agents in Portland and Chicago has sparked controversy, with local officials and residents expressing concerns over the tactics used by the agents. The agents, who are part of the U.S. Marshals Service, were sent to the cities to protect federal property and personnel, but critics argue that they are being used to suppress peaceful protests and intimidate residents.

In Portland, the deployment has been met with anger and resistance from local residents, who have been protesting against police brutality and systemic racism. The agents have been seen detaining people without explanation, sparking concerns over their methods and motives.

In Chicago, Mayor Lori Lightfoot has rejected the idea of deploying federal agents to the city, citing concerns over their lack of accountability and the potential for harm to residents. Lightfoot has instead called for increased funding for the city's police department and for the federal government to take action on gun violence.

The deployment of federal agents in Portland and Chicago is part of a broader trend of the Trump administration's efforts to crack down on urban violence and crime. The administration has pledged to send federal agents to cities across the country to help local law enforcement agencies combat gang violence and drug trafficking.

However, critics argue that the deployment of federal agents is a thinly veiled attempt to suppress political dissent and intimidate residents, particularly communities of color. The agents' lack of accountability and transparency has also raised concerns over their methods and motives.

The controversy surrounding the deployment of federal agents in Portland and Chicago highlights the ongoing tensions between the federal government and local communities over issues of policing and public safety. As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the deployment of federal agents will be effective in addressing the root causes of urban violence or simply serve to further divide communities.

**Google's News Algorithm: A Study Raises Questions About Political Bias**

A recent study by the Computational Journalism Lab at Northwestern University has sparked debate about the political leanings of Google's news algorithm. The study, which analyzed over 200 news-related questions in November 2017, found that a significant portion of Google's Top Stories came from just 20 news sources, with three of them dominating the coverage. CNN, The New York Times, and The Washington Post accounted for 23% of all impressions counted.

The researchers, Daniel Trielli and Nicholas Diakopoulos, counted an "article impression" each time one of those links appeared, and found that 86% of Google's Top Stories came from those 20 sources. The study also showed that 62% of the impressions were from sources considered left-leaning, while only 11% were from right-leaning outlets.

Google has responded to the study, stating that its algorithms are designed to elevate news from authoritative sources and require publishers to be transparent and accountable. The company emphasizes that its algorithms do not detect political affiliations or sentiments, but rather measure factors such as relevance, timing, and authoritativeness of a source.

The study's findings have raised concerns about the potential for Google's algorithm to influence the news cycle and amplify certain perspectives over others. However, Google has launched its own "How News Works" page, which emphasizes its commitment to fostering a healthy and diverse news ecosystem.

The debate highlights the complexities of algorithmic curation and the challenges of ensuring transparency and accountability in the digital age. While the study's findings may raise questions about Google's role in shaping the news landscape, it also underscores the importance of continued research and scrutiny to ensure that online platforms remain fair and unbiased.

Title: Clinton Foundation's Impact Debated: Pros and Cons of Charity's Operations

The Clinton Foundation, established by former US President Bill Clinton and his wife Hillary, has been under scrutiny for its dealings and potential conflicts of interest. Democratic strategist James Carville, a long-time Clinton supporter, recently defended the foundation's operations on MSNBC's "Morning Joe." Carville argued that the pros of the foundation's work outweigh the cons, citing its mission to raise money from wealthy individuals and distribute it to those in need.

Carville emphasized that the foundation's efforts have a significant positive impact, stating, "What the Clinton Foundation does is it takes money from rich people and gives it to poor people. Most people think that's a pretty good idea." He acknowledged that the foundation's operations may not have been politically palatable during Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign, but maintained that it still does a lot of good.

However, co-host Joe Scarborough countered Carville's claims, calling them "BS" and suggesting that the charity could have operated independently without Bill Clinton's involvement. Scarborough argued that if the foundation is a reputable and effective charity, it can stand on its own and attract donations without relying on Bill Clinton's fundraising efforts.

The debate highlights the ongoing discussion about the Clinton Foundation's role and potential conflicts of interest. While some argue that the foundation's work has a significant positive impact, others question the potential for conflicts of interest and the perception of impropriety. Ultimately, the effectiveness and integrity of the Clinton Foundation will depend on its ability to demonstrate transparency and accountability in its operations.

Title: Michael Cohen Expresses Willingness to Cooperate with Investigations, Disavows Trump's Animosity Toward Mueller

Article:

Michael Cohen, the former lawyer and fixer for President Donald Trump, has expressed his willingness to cooperate with the ongoing investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 election and his own business dealings. In an off-camera interview with ABC News correspondent George Stephanopoulos, Cohen stated that he does not share Trump's animosity toward special prosecutor Robert Mueller and is open to cooperating with the investigation.

Cohen's comments come as he faces scrutiny from federal prosecutors in New York, who are investigating him for possible election law and financial crimes. His lawyer, Guy Petrillo, will provide guidance on any decisions he makes regarding cooperation.

When asked about his loyalty, Cohen emphasized his family's importance, stating, "My wife, my daughter, and my son have my first loyalty and always will. I put family and country first." He also expressed his commitment to not being a "punching bag" for Trump's defense strategy, saying, "I am not a villain of this story, and I will not allow others to try to depict me that way."

The investigation into Russian ties to the 2016 Trump campaign has resulted in charges against several former Trump associates, including Michael Flynn, Paul Manafort, and George Papadopoulos. Federal investigators have also been scrutinizing Cohen's business dealings, including payments to adult-film star Stormy Daniels and other women who claimed they had affairs with Trump.

In April, investigators raided Cohen's home and office, and since then, Trump's personal lawyers, Cohen's attorneys, and federal officials have been engaged in a legal battle over access to millions of documents. Cohen expressed respect for the prosecutors and the process, stating, "I would not do or say anything that might be perceived as interfering with their professional review of the evidence and the facts."

Overall, Cohen's comments suggest that he is willing to cooperate with the investigations and is committed to upholding the law, despite Trump's animosity toward Mueller.

Title: Trump's Miami Golf Resort Chosen as Site for G7 Summit, Sparking Controversy Over Conflicts of Interest

Article:

The White House has announced that President Donald Trump's golf resort in Miami, Trump National Doral, will host the 2020 G7 summit, sparking concerns over potential conflicts of interest and ethics violations. The decision has been met with criticism from both sides of the political aisle, with some calling it the most blatant example yet of Trump using his office to boost his business empire.

The Trump National Doral was chosen for its location and amenities, according to Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, who claimed that the resort will be booked "at cost" and that the president will not profit from the event. However, critics argue that the decision takes Trump's apparent conflicts of interest to a new level, as foreign dignitaries will have no choice but to spend money at his resort during the June 10-12 summit.

The decision comes as several lawsuits accuse Trump of violating the Constitution's emoluments clause, which bans the president from receiving gifts or payments from foreign governments. Trump has repeatedly accused Joe Biden's family of profiting from public office due to Hunter Biden's business activities in Ukraine while his father was vice president.

Mulvaney brushed off concerns over the decision, saying that Trump's brand is strong and that the event will not be a massive promotion for his brand. However, critics argue that the decision is a clear example of Trump using his office to benefit his business interests.

The Trump Organization did not respond to questions about Doral's finances, but the resort has been struggling since even before Trump became president. Financial disclosure reports show that revenue is barely growing, and the Trump Organization has admitted that the resort is "seriously underperforming."

The decision has been met with criticism from both sides of the political aisle, with some calling it a clear example of corruption. U.S. Sen. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut said it's "so brazen and craven" and "virtually saying, 'To heck with the rule of law.'" U.S. Rep. Jerrold Nadler of New York added that the emoluments clauses of the Constitution exist to prevent exactly this kind of corruption.

The decision has sparked a heated debate over the role of the presidency and the potential conflicts of interest that come with it. While some argue that the decision is a legitimate choice, others see it as a clear example of Trump using his office to benefit his business interests.

**Title:** Former Trump Lawyer Michael Cohen to be Released from Prison to Home Confinement Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

**Article:**

The United States Department of Justice has announced that Michael Cohen, the former lawyer and fixer for President Donald Trump, will be released from federal prison to serve the remainder of his sentence in home confinement due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Cohen, who pleaded guilty to charges including campaign finance fraud and lying to Congress, is currently serving his sentence at FCI Otisville in New York.

According to a Justice Department official and another person familiar with the matter, Cohen will remain under quarantine for 14 days before being released. Federal statistics show that 14 inmates and seven staff members at the prison have tested positive for the coronavirus.

The decision to release Cohen to home confinement comes as the federal prison system struggles to contain the spread of the virus. As of Thursday, 473 federal inmates and 279 Bureau of Prisons staff members had tested positive for the coronavirus, with 18 inmates having died since late March.

Prison advocates and congressional leaders have been pressing the Justice Department to release at-risk inmates ahead of a potential outbreak, citing the difficulty of maintaining social distancing behind bars. Attorney General William Barr had previously ordered the Bureau of Prisons to increase the use of home confinement and expedite the release of eligible high-risk inmates, but it is unclear if Cohen's release was directly related to this directive.

Cohen's release is not the only recent move by the Bureau of Prisons to address the growing concern over the spread of the virus. The agency has moved over 1,000 inmates to home confinement since March 26, and has been working to identify and isolate high-risk inmates.

While Cohen's release is seen as a significant development, it is not without controversy. A federal judge had previously denied his request for early release to home confinement, citing concerns that it was an attempt to inject himself back into the news cycle. However, the Bureau of Prisons can take action to move him to home confinement without a judicial order.

Cohen, 53, began serving his sentence last May and was scheduled to be released from prison in November 2021. His release to home confinement is seen as a significant development in the ongoing efforts to address the spread of the virus in the federal prison system.

**Trump Refuses to Endorse Ryan and McCain, Amid Growing GOP Rift**

In a surprise move, Republican nominee Donald Trump has declined to endorse the re-election campaign of House Speaker Paul Ryan, the highest-ranking member of his party in Washington. This decision comes amid growing divisions within the GOP, with Trump's controversial statements on Muslims and his treatment of the Khan family sparking widespread criticism.

In an interview with the Washington Post, Trump stated, "I like Paul, but these are horrible times for our country. We need very, very strong leadership. And I'm just not quite there yet. I'm not quite there yet." This comment was likely a reference to Ryan's comments in May, when the House speaker expressed reservations about endorsing Trump.

Trump also refused to back Senator John McCain, the party's 2008 nominee, in his bid for re-election. Both Ryan and McCain have been vocal critics of Trump's remarks, but have said they would support the Republican nominee in the general election.

Ryan's campaign responded through a spokesman, Zack Roday, stating, "Neither Speaker Ryan nor anyone on his team has ever asked for Donald Trump's endorsement. And we are confident in a victory next week regardless."

The rift between Trump and Ryan is just one of many divisions within the GOP. Other high-profile Republicans, including Chris Christie and Mitt Romney, have also spoken out against Trump's comments. The New York Times reported that mass defections by Republican politicians are now a possibility.

Meanwhile, veterans and the families of soldiers killed in war are calling on Trump to apologize for his treatment of the Khan family. Dakota Meyer, a Medal of Honor recipient, tweeted, "If @realDonaldTrump wants to be the Commander in Chief, he needs to act like one. And that can't start until he apologizes to the Khans."

The refusal to endorse Ryan and McCain comes exactly one week before Ryan faces a primary challenge from businessman Paul Nehlen, who has sought to emulate Trump's rhetoric and policies. McCain is also facing a primary challenge at the end of August from Kelli Ward, who has accused him of being "directly responsible for Isis."

The Arizona senator has described the upcoming election as "the race of my life," and has called on Trump to apologize for his comments about prisoners of war. Trump has not apologized.

**Eurozone Leaders Reach Agreement on New $96 Billion Bailout for Greece**

In a marathon overnight meeting, eurozone leaders have agreed to offer Greece a new $96 billion bailout package, pending approval by the Greek Parliament. The deal, Greece's third since 2010, requires the country to implement significant economic reforms, including pension cuts and higher taxes, as well as the sale of some government assets.

The agreement, reached after weeks of intense diplomacy, aims to secure Greece's place in the eurozone, at least for now. The country's potential exit from the currency union would have had far-reaching consequences for the entire region.

Under the deal, Greece will have to give up control of the proceeds from government sales, with the bulk earmarked for debt payments. The European Central Bank (ECB) will also assign monitors to ensure Greece's compliance with the agreement.

Greece's Parliament must approve the measures by Wednesday, and the country's banks will remain shut until the ECB is satisfied that the necessary reforms are in place. The ECB has not yet agreed to restart money flows to Greece, citing concerns over the country's ability to implement the reforms.

The agreement is not without its challenges, as Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces resistance from some European leaders over the terms of the deal. The country's economy has deteriorated sharply in recent weeks, and the government is under pressure to deliver on its promises to its citizens.

The deal is a significant step towards stabilizing Greece's economy, but it is not a guarantee of success. The country still faces significant challenges, including the need to implement the reforms and secure the approval of its parliament.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Take a Strong Stance on Abortion Rights

Article:

The 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have coalesced around an abortion rights agenda that is more far-reaching than anything past nominees have proposed, according to a recent survey by The New York Times. The survey found that the top-tier candidates, including Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg, and Bernie Sanders, want to force all private insurers to cover elective abortions and make abortion drugs available over-the-counter. Additionally, they all support repealing the Hyde Amendment, which would provide unlimited taxpayer funding for elective abortions for Medicaid recipients.

However, only one candidate, South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, is willing to sign a budget that includes the Hyde Amendment, while the other candidates dodged the question. The Hyde Amendment is attached to legislation that can be filibustered, and refusing to sign an appropriations bill that includes it would force a government shutdown.

The survey also found that only Tulsi Gabbard, Joe Sestak, and Marianne Williamson still use the phrase "safe, legal, and rare" to describe their stance on abortion, a phrase popularized by President Bill Clinton and repeated by Hillary Clinton. Other candidates prefer to call for abortion to be "affordable" or "accessible" rather than "rare."

Notably, only Joe Sestak and Tulsi Gabbard said they support restrictions after 24 weeks of pregnancy, with Gabbard also supporting restrictions in the third trimester. This is a significant departure from the stance of past Democratic presidential candidates, including Barack Obama, who said in 2008 that he supports restrictions on late-term abortions with a strict, well-defined exception for the health of the mother.

In contrast, the top-tier candidates, including Buttigieg, Warren, and Sanders, are opposed to any restrictions after 24 weeks of pregnancy. It's worth noting that the distinction between 24 weeks and 28 weeks is no longer medically relevant, as viability has moved up to 22 weeks into pregnancy.

The survey highlights the stark contrast between the 2020 Democratic presidential candidates and past nominees on the issue of abortion. While some candidates are willing to take a more nuanced approach, others are taking a strong stance in support of abortion rights.

**Tax Talks Reach Critical Point: Senate Democrats Threaten to Let Bush-Era Cuts Expire**

The debate over the Bush-era tax cuts has reached a critical point, with Senate Democrats warning that they are willing to let the cuts expire at the end of the year if Republicans do not agree to President Obama's plan to raise taxes on the wealthy. The move would send the country "over the fiscal cliff," according to some lawmakers, and could have significant economic implications.

Senator Patty Murray, the head of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, made the threat in a speech at the Brookings Institution, stating that if Republicans do not agree to a "balanced deal" that includes tax increases for the wealthy, she will continue the debate into 2013. Murray emphasized that if all the tax cuts expire, it would diminish the GOP's argument that the Democratic plan is a tax hike, as any change to the tax code would be a tax cut.

The move is seen as a strategic ploy by Democrats to gain leverage in the negotiations, as they believe that Republicans will be forced to compromise once the slate is wiped clean and the Bush tax cuts expire. Murray also hinted that Republicans may be hesitant to support new tax cuts for the rich once the middle-class tax cuts are no longer on the table.

The debate has become increasingly heated, with Republicans accusing Democrats of threatening to trigger tax hikes in 2013 and Democrats accusing Republicans of standing in the way of relief for millions of Americans. Senator Rob Portman, R-Ohio, argued that Obama's plan would hurt employment and make it harder for businesses to create jobs.

The political strategy underscores the high stakes of the debate, with both sides accusing the other of playing political hardball. The outcome of the negotiations will have significant implications for the economy and the country's fiscal future.

**Title:** Balancing National Security and Privacy: A Call for Transparency in Surveillance Programs

**Article:**

The recent revelations about the scope of domestic surveillance programs in the United States have sparked a heated debate about the balance between national security and individual privacy. Senator Al Franken, a champion of transparency and accountability, believes that the government must strike a balance between protecting Americans from terrorism and protecting their privacy.

Franken, who has been working to reform the Patriot Act and Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, argues that the lack of transparency surrounding these programs has created a lack of trust among the American public. "We can't know if our civil liberties are safe if all about surveillance is secret," he said. "We need to know who, when, and how to judge if surveillance crosses a line."

The senator is pushing for legislation that would require the federal government to annually report on the use of key authorities under the Patriot Act and Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, including the number of Americans whose information is being collected and queried. He also wants companies to be able to publicly report on the number of national security letters they receive and how many customers are affected.

Franken's proposal is not about ending the surveillance programs, but about ensuring that the government is transparent about its actions and that the public is informed about the scope of these programs. "National security laws must protect national security, but they must also protect the public trust and preserve the ability of an informed electorate to hold its government accountable," he said.

The senator's efforts are part of a broader push to update privacy laws to keep pace with modern technology. In an era where personal data is increasingly digital, it is essential to have a clear understanding of what constitutes a reasonable expectation of privacy.

As the debate continues, it is clear that striking a balance between national security and privacy will require a nuanced approach. While some may argue that secrecy is necessary to protect against threats, others will insist that transparency is essential to maintain public trust. Ultimately, it is up to Americans to decide what is reasonable and what is not.

Title: White Nationalist Protesters Return to Charlottesville, Sparking Controversy

Article:

A small group of white nationalists returned to Charlottesville, Virginia, on Saturday, sparking controversy and concern among local officials and residents. The brief, torch-lit rally was organized by Richard Spencer, a prominent figure in the far-right movement, and took place in front of a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee.

The protesters, estimated to be between 40 and 50 people, chanted slogans such as "You will not replace us" and "We will be back," as well as "The South will rise again" and "Russia is our friend." The rally was livestreamed by Spencer, who claimed that Charlottesville had become a symbol of the suppression of free speech and the destruction of historical monuments.

The event was met with criticism from local officials, including Mayor Mike Signer, who called the protesters "neo-Nazi cowards" and said that officials are exploring legal ways to prevent future events. The rally was a stark reminder of the violent clashes that occurred in Charlottesville in August, which left one woman dead and many others injured.

The statue of General Lee, which was the site of the "Unite the Right" rally in August, has been covered up while a legal challenge to its removal takes place. The US has been grappling with a national debate on whether to remove Confederate symbols from the US Civil War, due to their association with slavery.

The return of the white nationalist protesters to Charlottesville highlights the ongoing tensions and divisions in the community. While some see the removal of Confederate monuments as a necessary step towards reconciliation and a recognition of the country's dark history, others believe it is an attack on their heritage and a threat to free speech.

The controversy surrounding the rally and the ongoing debate on Confederate symbols serve as a reminder of the complex and sensitive issues surrounding American history and identity.

Title: ExxonMobil Wins Climate Change Lawsuit, But Questions Remain About Company's Accountability

Article:

In a closely watched case, a New York State Supreme Court judge has ruled in favor of ExxonMobil, finding that the oil giant did not break the law by downplaying the financial risks of climate change. The decision marks a significant setback for the New York Attorney General's Office, which had accused Exxon of misleading investors about the impact of climate regulations on its business.

Justice Barry Ostrager's ruling concluded that the attorney general's office failed to prove that ExxonMobil made any material misrepresentations that would have significantly altered the information available to investors. The judge noted that while ExxonMobil's actions may have contributed to climate change, this was not the focus of the lawsuit, which was a securities fraud case.

The New York Attorney General's Office had argued that ExxonMobil had downplayed the financial risks of climate regulations, making its assets appear more secure than they actually were. This, they claimed, had defrauded investors and affected the company's stock price. However, the court found that the state failed to prove this claim.

The decision has sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that ExxonMobil's actions have contributed to climate change and that the company should be held accountable. Attorney General Letitia James released a statement saying that the case had compelled Exxon to answer publicly for its internal decisions that misled investors. "Throughout this case, we laid out how Exxon made materially false, misleading, and confusing representations to the American people about the company's response to climate change regulations," she said.

ExxonMobil, on the other hand, celebrated the ruling, saying it "affirms the position ExxonMobil has held throughout the New York Attorney General's baseless investigation." The company claimed that it had provided accurate information on the risks of climate change and that the court agreed that the attorney general's office failed to make a case.

The ruling has implications for the growing number of climate-related lawsuits against fossil fuel companies. While ExxonMobil has won this battle, the war is far from over. Other lawsuits, including a similar case in Massachusetts, are pending, and cities and states are using "public nuisance" arguments to try to hold energy companies accountable for their role in climate change.

The case has also raised questions about the role of expert witnesses, with Justice Ostrager noting that the state's expert witnesses were "eviscerated" on cross-examination. The highest-profile witness in the case was former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who testified that ExxonMobil used two different methods to estimate the impact of climate change regulations on its business.

The ruling has sparked a heated debate about the accountability of fossil fuel companies and their role in climate change. While ExxonMobil has won this battle, the fight is far from over.

Title: Obama Proposes Budget Plan with Increased Spending and Tax Increases

Article:

President Obama has released his 2013 budget proposal, which aims to lift the automatic spending caps and increase spending on domestic programs by $37 billion. The plan also includes an additional $38 billion in defense spending, which would help fund the fight against the Islamic State and military support for NATO allies.

The president's proposal would also raise taxes on big banks and the wealthy, with the goal of generating $210 billion over the next decade. A new financial fee on highly leveraged banks would generate an additional $110 billion over the same period. The plan would also impose a one-time 14% tax on the profits that U.S. corporations have amassed overseas, which would raise an estimated $238 billion to fund improvements to roads, bridges, and other public works.

The president's budget proposal is already drawing criticism from Republicans, who are unlikely to approve the proposed tax hikes. However, the plan does include some concessions, such as a reduction in the federal deficit to $474 billion in the upcoming fiscal year, which is just 2.5% of the overall economy.

The plan also includes a provision to eliminate the sequester, which would restore funding to domestic programs that were cut in 2013. The president has also proposed a plan to match defense spending with domestic spending, which would help to strengthen the economy and improve national security.

While the president's plan is not without its flaws, it does aim to address some of the country's most pressing issues, including the need for increased spending on infrastructure and the need to address income inequality. The plan also includes a provision to eliminate the sequester, which would help to restore funding to domestic programs that were cut in 2013.

Overall, the president's budget proposal is a step in the right direction, but it is not without its challenges. The plan will require careful consideration and negotiation with Congress to ensure that it is implemented effectively.

Title: Harvard Freshman's Visa Cancellation and Detention Raises Concerns Over Immigration Procedures

Article:

A 17-year-old Palestinian student, Ismail B. Ajjawi, was detained and had his visa canceled by American immigration officials at Boston Logan International Airport last Friday night. The incident has raised concerns over the fairness and effectiveness of immigration procedures, particularly in the context of international students arriving at Harvard University.

Ajjawi, who was granted a scholarship to attend Harvard, was stopped and questioned by immigration officials along with several other international students. While the other students were allowed to leave, Ajjawi was subjected to invasive questioning and had his phone and laptop searched for five hours. He alleges that an immigration officer asked him about his religion and religious practices in Lebanon, as well as his friends' social media activity.

Ajjawi claims that he was told to sit back in his position and not move, and that the officer refused to return his phone, despite his requests. After the search, the officer questioned him about his friends' social media activity, specifically pointing out posts that oppose the US. Ajjawi maintains that he has no political posts on his timeline and that he does not engage with such content.

The incident has sparked concerns over the fairness and effectiveness of immigration procedures, particularly in the context of international students arriving at Harvard University. University officials are working to resolve the situation in time for Ajjawi to attend classes when the semester starts on September 3.

The incident highlights the importance of ensuring that immigration procedures are fair, transparent, and respectful of individual rights. It also underscores the need for clear guidelines and training for immigration officials to ensure that they are equipped to handle the complexities of international students' experiences and backgrounds.

Title: Trump's Media Critique: A Rorschach Test for the Nation

Article:

In a highly anticipated press conference, President Trump delivered a scathing critique of the media, labeling it "fake news" and accusing journalists of harboring "hatred" towards him. The event was a departure from the usual White House press conferences, with Trump's unfiltered remarks sparking both praise and criticism.

While Trump scored some points by denouncing the media's perceived bias and acknowledging the flood of leaks aimed at damaging his administration, his comments were also met with skepticism and concern. The president's claims of a "fine-tuned machine" running the administration were seen as hyperbole by many, and his criticism of specific news outlets and journalists was seen as an attempt to deflect attention from the administration's own controversies.

The media has indeed been critical of Trump's presidency, with many outlets reporting on the administration's handling of various issues, including the firing of Michael Flynn and the allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 election. However, Trump's claims of a "discredited" New York Times piece and a "fake" Wall Street Journal report were met with skepticism, as the stories were based on unnamed sources and are still under investigation.

Trump's comments about CNN's Don Lemon and the network's nightly show being stacked with anti-Trump panels were seen as a small argument, and some critics argued that the president's grievances about the media's coverage of him are misplaced. The president's supporters, on the other hand, saw his remarks as a much-needed pushback against a perceived liberal bias in the media.

Ultimately, Trump's media critique serves as a Rorschach test for the nation, with those who support him seeing it as a justified defense of his presidency and those who oppose him viewing it as a sign of a president who is "crazed" and "unhinged." As the president continues to navigate the challenges of his office, his words and actions will continue to be scrutinized by the media and the public alike.

Title: Colorado Court Rules Marijuana Use Can Still Lead to Termination, Despite State Law Protections

Article:

A recent ruling by the Colorado Court of Appeals has clarified that employees in the state can still be terminated for testing positive for marijuana, even if they are using it for medicinal purposes. The decision comes despite Colorado's laws protecting employees from being fired for engaging in lawful activities outside of the workplace.

The case involved Brandon Coats, a quadriplegic who was fired by Dish Network after testing positive for marijuana. Coats had qualified for Colorado's medical marijuana program and claimed that his employer had no evidence that he was impaired at work. However, the court ruled that federal laws prohibiting marijuana trumped the state law protecting employees from being fired for engaging in lawful activities outside of the workplace.

The court's majority opinion stated that while the purpose of the worker protection law is to keep an employer's nose out of an employee's off-site off-hours business, there is no legislative intent to extend employment protections to those engaged in activities that violate federal law.

Coats' lawyer, Michael Evans, expressed disappointment with the ruling and stated that they will take the case to the Colorado Supreme Court if necessary. While the ruling may be a setback for employees who use marijuana for medicinal purposes, it highlights the ongoing tension between state and federal laws regarding marijuana use.

Colorado is one of 20 states that has legalized marijuana for medicinal use, and the state's voters also approved the legalization of recreational marijuana in 2012. However, the federal government still considers marijuana to be an illegal drug, which can create conflicts between state and federal laws. The case highlights the need for further clarification on the legal status of marijuana use and its impact on employment.

**Title:** Virginia Governor's Race: A Battle for the Future of the State's Diverse Electorate

**Article:**

The Virginia governor's race is heating up, with Democratic candidate Terry McAuliffe and Republican candidate Ken Cuccinelli making a flurry of campaign stops across the state. Both candidates are courting the rapidly diversifying electorate, with a focus on turning out a greater-than-usual proportion of "New Virginia" voters who handed the state to President Barack Obama in 2012.

McAuliffe, the former Democratic National Committee chairman, has been making a name for himself by attending events and meetings with various ethnic and cultural groups, including the Pakistani-American Business Association, the Moroccan American Network, and the Asian-American and Pacific-Islander communities. He has also celebrated the Lunar New Year with Korean, Chinese, and Vietnamese groups in Northern Virginia and marked the Muslim holy month of Ramadan on Facebook.

Cuccinelli, the state Attorney General, has also been making inroads with diverse communities, attending meetings with the Pakistan American Business Association and the Moroccan American Network, celebrating Filipino-American culture at festivals in Richmond and Virginia Beach, and giving interviews to Indian, Korean, Moroccan, and Vietnamese-oriented media outlets.

The political logic behind these itineraries is straightforward: while Virginia has always had a sizable African-American population, the last 10 years have seen a sharp rise in other nonwhite voting groups. In the 2004 presidential race, Latino voters made up 3 percent of the Virginia electorate and Asians made up 2 percent, according to exit polls. By 2012, those numbers were 5 percent for Latinos and 3 percent for Asians – a combined 60 percent increase in those two heterogeneous groups.

Cuccinelli, who won multiple state Senate elections in a Fairfax-based district, near the epicenter of Virginia's demographic change, is no stranger to the state's transformation. He has been doing outreach work for years, attending events and meetings with various ethnic and cultural groups, and believes that his experience has given him an edge in understanding the needs and concerns of diverse communities.

The question is, will Cuccinelli's efforts be enough to help the Republican Party make inroads with the rapidly diversifying electorate? Only time will tell.

Title: Trump Pledges to Protect Thanksgiving, Amidst Controversy Over Holiday's Name and Significance

Article:

President Trump has pledged to protect Thanksgiving, a holiday celebrated in the United States on the fourth Thursday of November, from what he calls the "radical left." The president made the statement during a rally in Sunrise, Florida, where he expressed his opposition to any attempts to change the name of the holiday.

Trump claimed that some people want to rename Thanksgiving, citing the liberal website HuffPost's recent article, "How much damage are we doing with our epic Thanksgiving meal every year?" The article raised concerns about the environmental impact of traveling to family gatherings and the waste generated by the holiday. Trump also mentioned the article's suggestion to skip turkey to save animals.

However, the president's comments sparked a backlash on social media, with many using the hashtag #WhatLiberalsCallThanksgiving to mock his remarks. Some Native American Twitter users pointed out that the holiday is a painful reminder of the genocide of their ancestors and the theft of their lands.

The National Day of Mourning, a protest organized by Native Americans in New England since 1970, is held on the same day as Thanksgiving. The event is a commemoration of the arrival of European settlers and the devastating impact it had on Native American communities.

Trump's comments also drew attention to his recent pardon of two turkeys, Bread and Butter, which he wished Americans a Happy Thanksgiving. The president joked that the turkeys had received subpoenas to appear in Adam Schiff's basement, a reference to the California Democrat leading the impeachment inquiry against him.

The controversy surrounding Thanksgiving highlights the ongoing debate about the holiday's significance and the impact it has on different communities. While some see it as a celebration of gratitude and family, others view it as a painful reminder of the country's troubled past.

Title: Target Ditches Health Care Plan for Part-Time Workers, Citing Low Participation and Obamacare Options

Article:

Retail giant Target Corporation has announced that it will discontinue its health care plan for part-time workers, citing low participation rates and the availability of alternative coverage options under the Affordable Care Act (ACA). The company will provide a $500 cash payment to each affected employee to ease the transition.

According to Target, less than 10% of its part-time employees participated in the company's health care plan, and the move is intended to allow employees to explore other coverage options that may be more suitable for their needs. The company emphasized that the change is not a cost-cutting measure, but rather an effort to provide employees with more flexibility and choice.

The decision has raised questions about the impact of the ACA on employer-based health insurance, with some analysts suggesting that companies may be more likely to move health care coverage into the individual market and state-based exchanges, where individuals may be eligible for government subsidies based on income.

Target is not the only company to make changes to its health care plan in response to the ACA. In August, UPS announced that it would drop health care coverage for about 15,000 employees' spouses who are eligible for coverage from their own workplaces.

The move has sparked concerns about the potential consequences for smaller employers, who may be less able to absorb changes to the balance of sick and healthy employees. The ACA prohibits insurers from rejecting people with pre-existing conditions and from charging older consumers more than young people by more than a 3-1 ratio. Additionally, the law includes numerous taxes and fees that may be passed along to consumers in the employer-based insurance market.

Target emphasized that employees who work 20-31 hours per week will still be eligible for other benefits, including vacation, dental, disability, life insurance, and 401(k) benefits. The company also stated that it has no plans to cut hours as part of the move.

The decision has sparked debate about the impact of the ACA on employer-based health insurance, with some critics blaming any premium increases on the law. However, analysts note that the law's effects on the employer-based market are complex and influenced by many factors, including the political climate and the early problems with HealthCare.gov and the individual market.

Title: Obama's Second Term Agenda Faces Skepticism in New Hampshire

Article:

President Barack Obama's re-election campaign has been criticized for lacking a clear agenda for a second term, and even some of his most ardent supporters are struggling to paint a picture of what his second term would look like. The president's visit to New Hampshire, a crucial swing state, aimed to address these concerns and highlight his vision for the future.

The Suffolk/7News poll on Monday showed the presidential race tied at 47 percent, with voters giving the edge to Republican nominee Mitt Romney in fixing the economy. The poll also found that people are unclear about where Obama intends to lead the nation in a second term.

Obama's campaign team has outlined an agenda for a second term, which includes hiring 100,000 more teachers, boosting domestic energy production, creating more manufacturing jobs, and cutting the deficit. The president argues that his second term would be a bulwark against repeating the mistakes made by his Republican predecessors.

However, some supporters, like Cynthia Malbon of Manchester, are skeptical about the president's vision for a second term. "I don't know, I'm skeptical that anything much is going to happen. It's probably going to be worse next time around," she said.

The president's speech in Manchester focused on his economic policies, including subsidizing college tuition, increasing U.S. exports, raising taxes on the wealthy, and promoting clean energy. He emphasized that his agenda promotes "the policies that are getting us out of this mess." Unemployment has fallen from 10 percent to 7.8 percent since he took office, but the national jobless rate was 7.6 percent when he took office.

The president also took a swipe at Romney's economic plan, calling it "a sketchy deal" and warning that it would allow insurance companies to charge women more for health care coverage. He emphasized that his health care law puts women's health care choices in their hands.

The Romney campaign responded by saying that Obama's leadership has failed over the past four years and that the economic future under him would be even bleaker because he won't confront the looming "fiscal cliff" of spending cuts and tax increases pending before Congress in January.

The president's visit to New Hampshire aimed to rally supporters and address concerns about his second term agenda. However, the skepticism among some supporters and the lack of clarity about his vision for the future may make it a challenging task.

**Title:** President Obama's Speech: A Call to Action Amidst Economic Uncertainty

**Article:**

In a speech that aimed to unite and reassure, President Barack Obama accepted the Democratic nomination for a second term, emphasizing the importance of perseverance and shared responsibility in addressing the nation's ongoing economic challenges. The President's address, delivered in a more subdued tone than his 2008 speech, focused on the need for continued progress and the importance of staying the course.

Obama's speech was marked by a mix of optimism and realism, as he acknowledged the difficulties of the past four years while highlighting his administration's achievements. He emphasized the need for a "common effort" and "shared responsibility" to tackle the nation's economic and social challenges, which have been exacerbated by the ongoing global economic downturn.

The President's speech also featured a series of attacks on his Republican opponent, Mitt Romney, focusing on the latter's foreign policy inexperience and lack of specific policy proposals. Obama criticized Romney's stance on issues such as the war in Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as his views on Russia and China.

While some Democrats had urged Obama to present a more affirmative vision for his second term, the President instead opted for a more measured approach, emphasizing the need for continued progress and the importance of staying the course. The speech was met with chants of "four more years" from the crowd, indicating widespread support for the President's re-election bid.

Overall, Obama's speech aimed to strike a balance between optimism and realism, acknowledging the challenges facing the nation while emphasizing the importance of continued progress and shared responsibility.

**Title:** Senate Republicans Unveil Legislation to Address Racial Disparities in Law Enforcement

**Article:**

In a bid to address racial disparities in law enforcement, Senate Republicans have unveiled a new bill aimed at reforming police practices and improving community relations. The legislation, dubbed the JUSTICE Act, is led by Senator Tim Scott (R-SC) and backed by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY).

The bill includes several key provisions, including incentives for law enforcement agencies to ban the use of chokeholds, ramped-up data collection efforts to track officer use of force, and federal funding for training on alternatives to force. The legislation also recognizes the history of lynching in the United States and requires law enforcement agencies to report on no-knock warrants to the attorney general.

The Republican proposal comes a day after President Donald Trump signed an executive order aimed at incentivizing police departments to update their standards and practices and strengthen efforts to track officer misconduct. While the bill shares some similarities with the executive order, it differs from the sweeping legislative proposal put forward by congressional Democrats.

The JUSTICE Act does not address the issue of qualified immunity, a doctrine that largely shields officers from legal liability unless a plaintiff can show that their constitutional rights were clearly violated. The Trump administration has stated that amending qualified immunity is a "non-starter." The bill also does not end the use of "no-knock" warrants in drug cases, as the Democratic bill does, and provides new funds to police departments for training.

Senator Scott emphasized that the bill is not intended to punish officers, but rather to improve community relations and ensure that law enforcement agencies are equipped to serve and protect all citizens. "We believe the overwhelming number of officers in this nation are good people," he said at a Capitol Hill news conference.

The JUSTICE Act is the latest effort by lawmakers to address concerns about racial disparities in law enforcement, following the death of George Floyd and widespread protests across the country. While the bill is not without its limitations, it represents a step towards addressing the complex issues surrounding police reform and community relations.

Title: Amazon Eliminates Bonuses and Stock Awards for Warehouse Workers, Raises Pay to at Least $15 an Hour

Amazon.com Inc. has announced that it will eliminate monthly bonuses and stock awards for its warehouse workers and hourly employees, effective immediately. The move comes after the company pledged to raise its minimum pay to at least $15 an hour, a decision that was met with praise from politicians and activists.

According to sources familiar with Amazon's pay policies, warehouse workers were previously eligible for monthly bonuses that could total hundreds of dollars per month, as well as stock awards. However, the company has informed employees that these compensation categories will no longer be available.

Despite the elimination of bonuses and stock awards, hourly operations and customer-service workers will still see an increase in their total compensation. Amazon stated that the change will make compensation more immediate and predictable.

Workers whose pay was already above $15 per hour will receive hourly raises of $1, while some long-time employees have expressed frustration that their raises are relatively small compared to those of newly hired workers, who may receive hourly pay bumps of up to 40 percent.

David DeBoskey, an accounting professor at San Diego State University, believes that the elimination of bonuses and stock awards is a strategic move to attract new workers in a tight labor market. "In a tight labor market, when you're the leader paying $15 an hour, that's a big advantage," he said. "They probably realized people weren't applying for warehouse jobs for the stock options."

Amazon has announced plans to hire 100,000 seasonal workers for the holiday crush this year, and temporary workers will not receive stock options. The company's decision to raise its minimum pay to at least $15 an hour is seen as a move to stay competitive in the job market and attract new workers.

Title: Bipartisan Meeting on Immigration Reform to Take Place at the White House

Article:

A meeting between President Donald Trump and lawmakers from both parties is set to take place at the White House on Tuesday, aimed at finding a solution to protect hundreds of thousands of immigrants from deportation. The meeting comes as negotiations on a spending deal and the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program remain stalled.

The meeting is seen as a crucial step towards finding a bipartisan agreement on immigration reform, with some lawmakers expressing frustration over the slow progress. Republican Senator John Cornyn said that Democrats are holding the deal hostage for a DACA resolution, while Democrats argue that the White House has not been fully engaged in the negotiations.

The meeting will bring together a bipartisan group of lawmakers, including Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn, Senator Dick Durbin, and Representative Adam Kinzinger, among others. The meeting is seen as a test of whether the parties can put aside their differences and find a solution.

The meeting comes as the deadline for a spending deal approaches, with lawmakers working to pass a bill to avoid a government shutdown. The meeting is also seen as a test of whether the parties can find a way to address the issue of border security, which has been a major point of contention.

The meeting is expected to be a symbolic step towards finding a solution, with lawmakers acknowledging that the real work will come after the meeting. The meeting will also bring together lawmakers from both parties, including some who have been working on a bipartisan framework for a deal.

The meeting is seen as a crucial step towards finding a solution to the immigration crisis, which has been a major point of contention for years. The meeting is also seen as a test of whether the parties can put aside their differences and find a way to address the issue of border security.

In conclusion, the meeting between President Trump and lawmakers from both parties is a crucial step towards finding a solution to the immigration crisis. The meeting is seen as a test of whether the parties can put aside their differences and find a way to address the issue of border security.

Title: Americans Weigh in on President's Second Term: Infrastructure, Education, and Leadership Top the List

Article:

As President Obama begins his second term, Americans are eager to see him tackle the country's most pressing issues. A recent CNN poll found that nearly half of Americans consider the economy the most important issue facing the nation, followed closely by the deficit and healthcare. But what specific steps should the President take to address these concerns?

One iReporter, Cherry Davis, believes that rebuilding the nation's infrastructure is the key to getting the country back on track. She suggests a "modern New Deal" approach, focusing on updating energy, roads, and bridges to create jobs and stimulate economic growth. Davis, who has been struggling to find work in the Los Angeles job market, believes that this approach would bring the middle class back and keep the country competitive.

Another iReporter, Tyler Stocks, a rising East Carolina University student, is concerned about the rising cost of education. He relies on financial aid to fund his education, but worries about the increasing burden of student debt and the impact on his future career prospects. Stocks hopes that the President will work to make education more affordable and accessible.

Mark Ivy, a Mitt Romney supporter, believes that the President's top priority should be to show strong leadership in dealing with Congress. He argues that the President's inability to work with Congress has hindered progress on key issues and that a stronger hand is needed to get things done.

The tax structure also received attention from iReporters and commenters, with some arguing that the wealthy should pay more in taxes to address income inequality. Small business owner Egberto Willies believes that changing the tax structure is key to resolving these issues, while others argue that the current system is already too complex and burdensome.

As the President begins his second term, it's clear that Americans have a lot of opinions on what he should prioritize. Whether it's infrastructure, education, leadership, or taxes, the conversation is ongoing. What do you think should be the President's top priority? Share your thoughts below.

Title: Netanyahu's Complex: A Leader's Ambition and Obsession

Article:

Benjamin Netanyahu, the current Prime Minister of Israel, has been a subject of fascination for many, including Ari Shavit, a renowned Israeli columnist. Shavit's article provides a nuanced and complex portrait of Netanyahu, highlighting both his strengths and weaknesses. While acknowledging Netanyahu's intelligence, profound understanding of history, and sense of purpose, Shavit also notes his flaws, including deep-seated suspiciousness, emotional miserliness, and vindictiveness.

Netanyahu's ambition and sense of purpose are evident in his self-proclaimed role as the savior of the West, likening himself to Winston Churchill, the British leader who played a crucial role in defeating Nazi Germany during World War II. This self-image is rooted in his perception of Iran as the Nazi Germany of the 21st century, with Israel as the Great Britain and himself as the voice in the wilderness.

Shavit notes that Netanyahu's Churchill complex is deep, obsessive, and multidimensional, dating back to his opposition to the Oslo Accords in 1993. He has consistently viewed Democratic politicians and liberal intellectuals as weaklings, and his leadership style has been criticized for prioritizing military strength over social justice, human rights, and the rule of law.

Netanyahu's focus on the Iranian nuclear threat has been a central aspect of his premiership, with him employing his military training and diplomatic skills to make the issue a top priority for the international community. His efforts have led to a tough policy against Iran, with the United States adopting a resolute rhetoric, punitive sanctions, and military threats.

While Shavit's article provides a balanced view of Netanyahu's strengths and weaknesses, it also raises questions about the Israeli leader's motivations and priorities. Is his focus on the Iranian threat a genuine concern for national security, or is it a means to an end, driven by his own ambition and desire for greatness? Only time will tell.

**Election 2012: Romney Closes Gap with Obama Among Women, But Still Trails**

A new Associated Press-GfK poll has revealed that Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has narrowed the gap with President Barack Obama among women, but still trails the incumbent by a narrow margin. The poll shows that Romney is now favored by 47% of likely voters, while Obama is favored by 45%, a result within the poll's margin of sampling error.

The poll also indicates that Romney has gained ground with Americans on several key issues, including their confidence in his ability to handle the economy and their impressions of his understanding of their problems. However, Obama still maintains a strong lead among women on issues such as women's rights and reproductive health.

Romney's campaign has been focusing on the economy as a key issue, and the poll suggests that this message is resonating with some women. The poll shows that Romney's advantage among women on the economy has grown from 16 points to 9 points over the past month.

However, the poll also highlights the challenges Romney faces in winning over women. A majority of women, 55%, believe that Obama would make the right decisions on women's issues, compared to 41% who think Romney would.

The poll also suggests that Obama's campaign is still strong among men, with his job approval ratings among men tending to fall below his ratings among women throughout his first term. The president's campaign is working to shore up support among men, particularly unmarried men, who are more likely to vote for Romney.

The poll was conducted Oct. 19-23 by GfK Roper Public Affairs & Corporate Communications and involved landline and cellphone interviews with 1,186 adults nationwide, including 839 likely voters. The results have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points for the full sample and 4.2 points for likely voters.

**Ohio's Early Voting Enthusiasm Gap: A Tale of Two Campaigns**

As early voting kicked off in Ohio, a surprising enthusiasm gap emerged between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump on Twitter, with Clinton supporters dominating the #OHVotesEarly hashtag. According to Twitter's data, 75% of tweets using the hashtag over the past 24 hours mentioned Clinton, while only 25 mentioned Trump. This disparity is significant, and it may be a sign of a larger trend in the state.

The enthusiasm gap could be attributed to various factors, including the fact that a Clinton supporter originally tweeted the hashtag, the Clinton campaign's digital team spreading it widely, or Trump's campaign tweeting an incorrect start date for early voting. Additionally, Trump's recent comments about sexual assault may have contributed to the disparity.

A new poll by Baldwin Wallace University Community Research Institute shows Clinton surging in Ohio, beating Trump 43-34% in a four-way race and 48-37% in a head-to-head race. This is a significant turnaround from just a month ago, when most polls showed Trump winning the state handily.

The Trump campaign, however, disputes the idea that Clinton is winning the enthusiasm game in Ohio. Trump volunteers knocked on over 118,000 doors on Sunday, and the campaign is confident that they will win on Election Day.

Early voting returns in other states also show Clinton with a slight advantage. According to a report by NBC News and TargetSmart, Clinton has received more votes during the early voting period in Iowa, Virginia, Wisconsin, Michigan, and North Carolina, while Trump is leading in Georgia and Florida.

The Clinton campaign is optimistic about these results, citing increased vote-by-mail requests among key demographics such as black and Asian American voters. In Ohio, one in every six absentee ballot requests came from Cuyahoga County, which President Obama won by 38 points in 2012. The campaign believes that these states could be decided before Election Day.

While the enthusiasm gap may be a sign of a larger trend in Ohio, it remains to be seen whether Clinton can build an insurmountable lead in key states before Election Day.

Title: Trump Secures Strong Showing in New Hampshire Primary, But Democratic Field Remains Wide Open

Article:

In the New Hampshire primary, President Trump secured a strong showing, more than doubling former President Barack Obama's 2012 vote total in the state. With 87% of precincts reporting, Trump secured over 120,000 votes, a significant indication of his base's enthusiasm and support. This comes as Trump prepares to face the eventual Democratic nominee in the November election.

The Trump campaign's efforts to drive up turnout paid off, with the president's supporters showing up in force at a packed rally in Manchester, New Hampshire, on Monday. Trump himself revved up his supporters, touting his accomplishments and knocking Democrats in front of a large audience.

The Democratic primary, on the other hand, saw a strong turnout, with first and second-place finishers Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg combining for almost 140,000 votes with 87% reporting. However, the Democratic field remains wide open, with no clear frontrunner emerging.

Trump's supporters, such as Jay McDonald of North Providence, Rhode Island, expressed their unwavering support for the president, citing his accomplishments and frustration with the impeachment process. "I'm 100 percent supporting Trump," McDonald said. "Nothing's changed."

The Trump campaign also highlighted its record turnout in the Iowa caucuses, which saw about 176,000 Iowa Democrats attend their precinct caucuses, a slight uptick from 2016 but fewer than expected. The New Hampshire numbers come as the president's supporters have been fired up in recent days, following his acquittal on two articles of impeachment and a well-received State of the Union address.

Meanwhile, the Democratic field is still reeling from the fallout of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's decision to tear up Trump's speech at the end of the State of the Union and the Iowa caucus debacle that still does not have an official winner. When asked about the Democratic field outside of the president's New Hampshire rally, one of Trump's fervent supporters, Air Force Veteran Mike Grunwald, gave a frank assessment of the party's chances to unseat Trump in November.

Title: Representative Justin Amash Forms Exploratory Committee for Presidential Run

Article:

Representative Justin Amash, a 40-year-old congressman from Michigan, has announced the formation of an exploratory committee to run for the Libertarian Party's presidential nomination. Amash, known for his libertarian views, has been a vocal critic of President Donald Trump and has been a member of the Republican Party for most of his political career.

Amash's decision to explore a presidential run comes after he left the Republican Party and hit pause on his congressional reelection campaign. He has been a strong advocate for limited government and individual freedom, and has been a vocal critic of the two-party system.

Amash's potential candidacy has sparked interest among Libertarians, who see him as a strong contender for the nomination. However, some critics have questioned his commitment to the party, citing his lack of involvement in Libertarian Party events and debates.

One of Amash's main opponents is Jacob Hornberger, a founder of the Future of Freedom Foundation, who has been a dominant force in Libertarian primaries and caucuses. Hornberger has been critical of Amash's lack of involvement in Libertarian Party events and debates, and has accused him of not wanting to subject his conservative positions to scrutiny.

Despite the challenges, Amash remains a strong contender for the Libertarian Party's presidential nomination. His potential candidacy has sparked interest among Libertarians, who see him as a strong advocate for limited government and individual freedom.

The outcome of Amash's exploratory committee will be closely watched, as it could have significant implications for the 2024 presidential election.

Title: US COVID-19 Death Toll Surpasses 100,000, a Grim Milestone in the Pandemic

Article:

The United States has reached a somber milestone in the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with the death toll surpassing 100,000 as of May 27. According to data compiled by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University, the country has lost 100,047 lives to the virus. This grim milestone is a stark reminder of the devastating impact of the pandemic on American lives.

The 100,000 deaths are equivalent to the entire population of mid-sized cities like Albany, New York, or Boca Raton, Florida. It is also more American lives lost than were lost in the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and the September 11, 2001 attacks combined.

While daily cases and deaths have declined significantly since the peak in April, experts warn that rural areas may not have seen the worst of the pandemic yet. Hundreds of people in the US are still dying from COVID-19 each day, with around 7,000 deaths reported during the week ending May 26.

The US leads the world in both coronavirus cases and deaths, with nearly 1.7 million reported cases as of May 27. However, this number is likely an underestimate, given inadequate testing capacity and the number of people who develop mild illnesses and do not seek medical attention.

Despite the progress made so far, experts warn that the country's commitment to social distancing appears to be faltering as states reopen and summer weather draws people out of their homes. A top World Health Organization official warned on May 26 that "we're right in the middle of the first wave [of coronavirus cases] globally" and that "we're still very much in a phase where the disease is actually on the way up" in many parts of the world.

The 100,000 lives lost in the US serve as a painful reminder of what could have been avoided if social distancing measures had been implemented earlier. A Columbia University analysis published on May 20 estimated that 36,000 lives could have been saved if the US had broadly adopted social distancing policies a week earlier than many places did, in mid-March.

As the pandemic continues to evolve, it is crucial that individuals take steps to protect themselves and their communities by adhering to social distancing guidelines and getting vaccinated when a vaccine becomes available.

Title: Obama's Tax Hike: A Missed Opportunity or a Turning Point?

Article:

President Barack Obama's decision to increase taxes by $600 billion in December was met with fanfare, with the president claiming victory in slapping new taxes on the rich while protecting George W. Bush's cuts for everyone else. However, in retrospect, it appears more like a missed opportunity than a political or policy triumph.

The $600 billion in tax increases is a far cry from the $1.6 trillion Obama had initially sought, or even the $1 trillion-plus many Republicans were discussing in previous grand bargain talks. The president had hoped to use the tax hike as leverage to get Republicans to agree to a grand bargain, but it seems that strategy has backfired.

According to top Democrats and Republicans alike, talk of a grand bargain this time around is overhyped. The Senate's most influential Democratic leadership aide told us that the idea of a grand bargain is no longer on the radar, while an adviser to Speaker John Boehner said the window for such a deal was slammed shut by Obama's hardball tactics since the tax hike.

Another reason for the lack of progress is the rancid relationship between Obama and Republicans on the Hill. House Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) shared an anecdote about an exchange he had with Obama at a recent white-tie Gridiron dinner, where the president was seen reading his BlackBerry instead of mingling with guests. McCarthy took this as a sign that Obama is a loner who would rather lecture than engage in meaningful dialogue.

The congressman recalled Obama saying that if Republicans want entitlement reform, "You need me," which McCarthy interpreted as a sign that the president still views himself as a lecturer-in-chief rather than a collaborator. This perception has led many to believe that a grand bargain is unlikely in the near future.

While some may view Obama's tax hike as a missed opportunity, others see it as a necessary step towards fiscal responsibility. Regardless, the reality is that the president's efforts to revive a grand bargain have stalled, and it remains to be seen whether he can find a way to bridge the divide and achieve his goals.

Title: FBI Releases Additional Text Messages Between Officials, Revealing Insights into Clinton Investigation

Article:

The Justice Department has released nearly 400 pages of additional text messages between two FBI officials, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, who were removed from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into alleged collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials. The newly discovered messages provide insight into the FBI's handling of the Clinton email server investigation and raise questions about potential bias within the agency.

According to the released messages, Strzok and Page discussed the FBI's decision not to charge Hillary Clinton in the email server investigation, with Page stating that it was "awful timing" and that Attorney General Loretta Lynch's announcement was a "real profile in courage" since she knew no charges would be brought. The messages also revealed that the FBI had initially considered including a reference to President Barack Obama in its statement closing out the investigation, but ultimately omitted it.

The release of the additional messages comes as Republican lawmakers have long contended that the FBI and Mueller's team were biased against Trump, and that the communication between Strzok and Page reveals a political bias within the agency. However, FBI Director Christopher Wray has flatly rejected these claims.

The Justice Department provided the messages to congressional committees on Friday, but lawmakers are still seeking additional information about the FBI's handling of the Clinton investigation. Senator Ron Johnson, the chairman of the Senate Homeland Security Committee, has asked the FBI to provide records of communications between Strzok and Page during a five-month window and to explain the scope and scale of any other records from the Clinton investigation that have been lost.

A source on the committees receiving the texts told Fox News that it was "outrageous" that the FBI had not previously indicated that the five-month gap in the messages existed and that it was incumbent on the FBI to prove that the missing texts do not constitute "obstruction" of congressional oversight or "destruction of evidence." The source also noted that congressional investigators want to know if the Justice Department's inspector general has copies of the messages.

The release of the additional messages is the latest development in the ongoing controversy surrounding the FBI's handling of the Clinton email server investigation and the Mueller investigation.

Title: Investigative Journalist Exposes the "Smear Machine" and its Influence on News Coverage

Article:
