IPAB is designed to cap Medicare spending growth and create an incentive for providers to allocate resources wisely. While some critics have labeled it a "death panel," the reality is that it is a mechanism to keep federal health spending on a sustainable trajectory without rationing services. The board is currently vacant, and Republicans would have likely nullified it if Reid hadn't taken this step.

Halperin's comments sparked controversy when he suggested that rationing is necessary to control healthcare costs, citing the high percentage of healthcare spending on end-of-life care. However, his statement was misinterpreted as advocating for "death panels," which is not the case. IPAB is not designed to ration services, but rather to create an incentive for providers to allocate resources wisely.

The real issue is that Republicans would have likely rejected all IPAB nominees, summarily eliminating the board and leaving the country without a mechanism to control healthcare spending. This would have led to higher costs and a greater burden on the national debt. By going nuclear, Reid has given the country a chance to have a more honest and straightforward discussion about the future of healthcare spending.

Halperin's concerns about the partisan nature of the move are valid, but they do not outweigh the benefits of having a functional IPAB. The board is not a partisan issue; it is a mechanism to ensure that the country can afford healthcare for its citizens. If Republicans are concerned about the cost of healthcare, they should be advocating for a fully staffed IPAB, not trying to eliminate it.

Ultimately, the decision to go nuclear has given the country a chance to have a more honest and straightforward discussion about the future of healthcare spending. It is up to policymakers to decide how to proceed, but it is clear that IPAB is a crucial component of any plan to ensure the long-term sustainability of the healthcare system.

Title: Trump Announces Change in Residency Status, Citing Treatment by New York Leaders

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Twitter that he and his family have changed their permanent residency status to Florida. The decision comes after Trump expressed frustration with the treatment he received from New York City and state political leaders, citing the millions of dollars he pays in taxes each year.

Trump stated that while he "cherishes" New York and the people who live there, he has been treated poorly by the city and state's political leaders. He did not specify which specific issues or incidents led to his decision, but expressed his hope to stay at the White House for another five years.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio welcomed the news, with Cuomo tweeting "He's all yours, Florida." De Blasio added a tongue-in-cheek remark, saying "Don't let the door hit you on the way out or whatever."

Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, accused Trump of making the move to avoid paying taxes in New York. She tweeted, "It's no surprise that Trump is trying to avoid paying his fair share of taxes in New York. He's always been more interested in lining his own pockets than paying his fair share."

The exact reasons behind Trump's decision remain unclear, but it is likely to spark further debate about his tax practices and his relationship with the state of New York.

Title: Dr. Ben Carson Forms Exploratory Committee, Weighs Presidential Run

Article:

Dr. Ben Carson, a renowned neurosurgeon and public speaker, has announced the formation of an exploratory committee to test the waters for a potential 2016 presidential bid. As part of this process, he has released a video outlining his reasons for considering a run. In it, he expresses frustration with Washington politicians who he feels are ignoring the concerns of the American people. Carson emphasizes his passion for listening to voters and building common-sense solutions to the nation's problems.

If Dr. Carson were to run, he would likely position himself as an anti-establishment, anti-politician candidate, leveraging his strong following and reputation as a non-traditional candidate. However, some question whether he would be successful in this endeavor. Jonah Goldberg, a prominent commentator, suggests that Carson might have a greater impact as a senatorial candidate, citing his potential to do well in conservative parts of Maryland and raise money nationally.

However, Dr. Carson has not indicated any interest in running for the Senate, and it appears that his presidential aspirations are still in the exploratory stages. While it is unlikely that he would win the nomination without prior political experience, it is worth noting that many candidates have successfully run for the Senate without holding office beforehand. Elizabeth Warren, for example, defeated incumbent Sen. Scott Brown in 2012 and is now considered a serious presidential contender.

Dr. Carson's decision to explore a presidential run is a significant development in the 2016 election cycle. As he weighs his options, he would do well to consider the challenges and opportunities that come with running for office.

Title: Conway and Keilar Clash in Heated CNN Interview

Article:

In a tense and confrontational interview on CNN's The Situation Room, Kellyanne Conway, Trump's campaign manager, faced off against host Brianna Keilar over the candidate's controversial comments about sending Hillary Clinton to "jail" if he becomes president. The interview was marked by Conway's repeated attempts to downplay the significance of Trump's remarks and Keilar's persistent questioning of the campaign's strategy.

Conway defended Trump's comments as a "quip" and a joke, but Keilar pressed her on the issue, pointing out that Trump has repeatedly brought up the topic in his rallies and debates. Conway also attempted to pivot to an attack on Clinton's record, claiming she has "imperiled our national security." Keilar countered by pointing out that Trump's comments are not just about Clinton's actions, but about his own willingness to use the power of the presidency to punish his political opponents.

The interview also touched on Trump's attacks on House Speaker Paul Ryan, with Keilar pointing out that Trump has repeatedly criticized the speaker on Twitter. Conway attempted to downplay the attacks, saying Trump was simply expressing his opinions, but Keilar pressed her on the issue, saying Trump's tweets were not just opinions, but attacks.

The interview ended with Conway accusing CNN of ignoring the "substance" of Trump's campaign and refusing to discuss the issues that Americans care about. Keilar countered by pointing out that Trump's own campaign is focused on distracting from his own controversies and depressing the vote of millennial women.

The interview highlights the ongoing tensions between the Trump campaign and the media, as well as the challenges facing the campaign as it tries to regain its footing after a series of controversies.

Title: The Unrelenting Force of Time and the Urgent Need for Justice

Article:

Time, a relentless and uncaring force, has dealt a cruel blow to Loretta Lynch, the newly sworn-in 83rd Attorney General of the United States. The 167-day delay in her confirmation is a stark reminder of the challenges she faces in her new role. However, it is not just Time that has it out for Lynch; the Republican-led attack on her nomination and the recent riots in Baltimore have made her job even more daunting.

The riots, sparked by the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old African-American man, have left a trail of destruction and raised questions about the Baltimore Police Department's (BPD) handling of the situation. The fact that Gray's death was not an isolated incident, but rather a symptom of a larger problem, is a stark reminder of the ongoing struggles faced by minority communities.

The BPD's documented history of lawless violence and the lack of accountability for its officers have created an environment where brutality and extralegal actions are tolerated. The fact that the BPD's reputation is so entrenched that many Baltimoreans heard Gray's story with weary outrage rather than shock or indignation is a testament to the deep-seated issues that need to be addressed.

Attorney General Lynch's goal of improving police morale is understandable, but it is not the most pressing issue at hand. What is needed is a commitment to promoting equal justice and addressing the systemic problems that perpetuate police brutality. The fact that the BPD's reputation is so entrenched that officers are comfortable with extralegal brutality and are accustomed to wielding it is a problem that needs to be tackled head-on.

The Department of Justice needs to take a strong stance against police militarization and the "warrior cop" mentality that has become pervasive in many law enforcement agencies. The suspension of officers involved in Gray's death with pay is not enough; what is needed is a commitment to holding officers accountable for their actions and ensuring that they are held to the same standards as everyone else.

In short, what is needed is for those in power to take the concerns of minority communities seriously and to prove that they believe that an African-American life is worth no less than a cop's. Now is not the time for Lynch to focus on making law enforcement happy; now is the time for her to promote equal justice.

Title: Grassroots Activists Express Frustration with Republicans' Handling of Healthcare Repeal

Article:

Grassroots activists who were instrumental in the Tea Party movement's efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, are expressing frustration with the Republican-led Congress's inability to deliver on their campaign promises. Despite the House of Representatives passing a bill to repeal and replace the ACA, many activists feel that the Senate's version falls short of their expectations.

Jenny Beth Martin, president and co-founder of the Tea Party Patriots, said that the group's email blasts against the ACA still generate hundreds of responses from activists upset about the healthcare law. The group helped make over 100,000 phone calls to Congress during the House's vote on the bill to repeal and replace the ACA. However, Martin noted that the group is not yet on board with the Senate's version of the bill.

Grassroots activists like Pat Daugherty, who participated in the Tea Party's early days, are now expressing disappointment with Republicans in Congress. Daugherty, a retired university administrator from Athens, Georgia, said that every Republican in Congress ran on repealing the ACA, but now they seem to be having trouble delivering on that promise. "I know a lot of conservatives who are more upset with Republicans than with Democrats," she said.

David Zupan, who helped organize Tea Party groups in Ohio against the ACA, said that the law has driven up healthcare costs and forced him to shut down his technology support business. He had hoped to confront Senator Rob Portman over the recess to demand that he and his fellow Republicans push for a full repeal. However, Zupan gave up after being unable to figure out where Portman would be. "Nothing they're going to do to this bill is going to make it better," he said.

The frustration among grassroots activists highlights the challenges that Republicans face in delivering on their campaign promises. While the party has been successful in passing legislation to repeal the ACA, many activists feel that the Senate's version of the bill does not go far enough. As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether Republicans can find a way to satisfy the demands of their base while also addressing the concerns of those who are skeptical of the bill.

Title: Whistleblower's Political Ties Spark Controversy in Ukraine Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

The whistleblower at the center of the House impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump's phone call with Ukraine's president has been accused of having political ties to a Democratic operative, sparking controversy and raising questions about the legitimacy of the investigation.

According to Steve Guest, the Republican National Committee's Rapid Response Director, the whistleblower is a Democrat who had a professional tie to a 2020 Democratic candidate and coordinated with House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff's staff. Guest also claims that the whistleblower's lawyers worked for former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, and donated to Joe Biden's presidential campaign.

The whistleblower's lawyer, Mark Zaid, has denied the allegations, stating that the client had never worked for or advised a political candidate or party and had only met with presidential candidates from both parties in their roles as elected officials. However, Zaid has a history of anti-Trump sentiment and has referred to himself as a member of the "#Resistance" movement.

The controversy surrounding the whistleblower's political ties has led to a heated debate about the legitimacy of the impeachment inquiry. President Trump has tweeted about the issue, stating that the whistleblower's facts have been "so incorrect" and that the whistleblower should be "exposed and questioned properly."

The investigation has also been criticized for its lack of transparency, with some Republicans accusing the media of ignoring the whistleblower's political ties and others calling the investigation a "textbook coordinated Democrat political smear."

The controversy has also led to questions about the role of House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, who has been accused of having a close relationship with the whistleblower. Schiff has denied any wrongdoing, but has been criticized for his handling of the investigation.

The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen how the controversy surrounding the whistleblower's political ties will impact the outcome of the inquiry.

Title: The Presidential Debates: A Shift in Focus from Serious Issues to Non-Essential Topics

Article:

The recent presidential debates have sparked a heated discussion about the candidates' strategies and tactics. The Obama campaign has been accused of focusing on non-essential issues, such as Big Bird, binders, and bayonets, in an attempt to deflect attention away from the more pressing concerns of the economy, deficit, and entitlement spending.

In the first debate, Romney's statement about measuring government spending by whether it's worth borrowing money from China to pay for it was met with a response from the Obama campaign that focused on the potential cuts to public broadcasting. The move was seen as a way to distract from the tough economic issues and shift the focus to a more emotional and symbolic topic.

Similarly, during the second debate, Romney's comment about reviewing "binders full of women" in response to a question about gender pay equality was seized upon by the Obama campaign as evidence of a "war on women." The move was seen as a way to create a narrative that Romney is anti-women, rather than addressing the actual issue of pay equality.

In the third debate, Obama's response to Romney's comment about the Navy having fewer ships than at any time since 1917 was to joke about the country also having fewer horses and bayonets. The move was seen as a way to deflect attention away from the more serious issue of the Navy's capabilities and focus on a humorous anecdote.

While these tactics may have been effective in the short term, they have not been enough to distract from the fact that the economy and jobs are the top concerns for most Americans. A recent poll found that more than two-thirds of Americans name pocketbook issues like the economy and jobs as their top concerns.

In contrast, Romney's focus on the economy and jobs has resonated with voters. His five-point plan to create 12 million new jobs has been seen as a serious and comprehensive approach to addressing the country's economic woes.

As the election nears, it is clear that the next generation of voters deserves a serious discussion of serious issues, rather than political efforts to trivialize them. Whether President Obama's reelection strategy of diverting attention away from the economy and jobs is successful remains to be seen.

Title: Poll Reveals Hillary Clinton Leads Donald Trump in Head-to-Head Match-up

A recent CNN/ORC poll has revealed that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton leads likely Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump by 13 points in a head-to-head match-up. The poll, conducted from April 28 to May 1, showed Clinton leading Trump with 54% of the vote, compared to 41% for Trump.

The poll also found that Clinton has an edge on several key issues, including climate change, foreign policy, education, healthcare, the income gap between rich and poor, immigration, and terrorism. Trump, on the other hand, was seen as stronger on the economy.

Interestingly, the poll revealed that many voters are motivated by opposition to the opposing candidate rather than support for their preferred candidate. Fifty-one percent of Clinton voters said their vote was more about opposing Trump, while 48% said it was more about supporting Clinton. Similarly, 57% of Trump voters said their choice was more about opposing Clinton, while 43% said it was more about supporting Trump.

The poll also showed that Ohio Governor John Kasich, who is still in the GOP race, led Clinton by 7 points in a head-to-head match-up, 51% to 44%. Meanwhile, Senator Bernie Sanders outperformed Clinton in head-to-head match-ups against the two remaining Republicans, leading Trump by 16 points and Kasich by 4 points.

The poll also provided insight into the favorability ratings of the candidates. Clinton had a 49% favorable rating and 49% unfavorable rating, while Trump had a 41% favorable rating and 56% unfavorable rating. Sanders had a 61% favorable rating and 33% unfavorable rating, while Kasich had a 54% favorable rating and 29% unfavorable rating.

Title: Britain's Conservative Victory: A Shift in Economic Policy or a Temporary Alliance?

Article:

The recent election victory of Boris Johnson's Conservative Party in the United Kingdom has sparked a mix of reactions, with some hailing it as a triumph for Brexit and others lamenting the potential consequences for the country's economic future. While Johnson's win is undoubtedly a significant achievement, it is essential to examine the implications of his campaign promises and the potential impact on Britain's economic landscape.

Johnson's campaign focused on delivering Brexit and appealing to voters who were dissatisfied with the previous government's handling of the issue. He also made promises to increase spending on infrastructure, education, and healthcare, as well as to reduce the budget deficit. While these promises may have resonated with some voters, they also raise concerns about the potential for increased government spending and debt.

The Conservative Party's shift towards more liberal economic policies is a significant departure from its traditional stance. Johnson's campaign did not make a strong case for the benefits of limited government intervention in the economy, instead opting for a more interventionist approach. This shift may be a temporary alliance with voters who are dissatisfied with the current economic system, but it also raises questions about the party's commitment to fiscal responsibility.

The article highlights the potential consequences of Johnson's economic policies, citing the rise in debt and the potential for increased spending. It also notes that the Conservative Party's abandonment of fiscal conservatism may have a broader impact, not just in the UK but also in other countries that are watching the developments closely.

In conclusion, while Boris Johnson's election victory is a significant achievement, it is essential to examine the implications of his campaign promises and the potential impact on Britain's economic future. The shift towards more liberal economic policies may be a temporary alliance with voters, but it also raises questions about the party's commitment to fiscal responsibility and the potential consequences for the country's economic landscape.

Title: July Jobs Report: Economy Adds 162,000 Jobs, Unemployment Rate Edges Down

The latest jobs report from the federal government has added to the ongoing economic debate, with the economy adding 162,000 jobs in July and the unemployment rate dipping to 7.4%. The report, which narrowly missed analyst expectations, follows news that the economy grew by only 1.7% in the second quarter and saw a downward revision to its estimate for first-quarter growth.

The unemployment rate, based on a separate survey of households, is the lowest it has been since December 2008, with 227,000 more people employed in July compared to the previous month. However, the falling unemployment rate is not solely due to job growth, as 37,000 people left the labor force in July, contributing to the decline.

The report highlights the ongoing sluggish job growth, with 11.5 million people unemployed and 8.2 million part-time employees seeking more hours. Among the unemployed, 4.2 million have been jobless for six months or more. Over the past year, the unemployment rate has fallen 0.8%, with the count of officially unemployed persons decreasing by 1.2 million.

The jobs report is being closely watched by the Federal Reserve, which is considering when to scale back its efforts to stimulate the economy. Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke has said the central bank is watching for signs that it should reduce its monthly asset purchases, which are aimed at driving down long-term interest rates and sparking new growth.

The report is also being used as a talking point in the fiscal debate between the White House and congressional Republicans. While it may not spur immediate action in Congress, the employment report and GDP data add further urgency to the ongoing economic debate.

Title: US Vice President Reassures NATO Allies of Commitment to Defense Pact Amid Rising Tensions with Russia

Article:

In a visit to Estonia, US Vice President Mike Pence delivered a strong message of solidarity with NATO allies and the Baltic states, emphasizing the US commitment to the defense pact and its determination to confront the threats and intimidation from Moscow. Pence's trip comes amid mounting tensions between Washington and Moscow, with Russia expelling 755 US diplomats in retaliation for new sanctions legislation signed by President Trump.

Pence's speech in Estonia was a clear reaffirmation of the US commitment to NATO's Article 5, which pledges mutual defense for all member nations. The vice president emphasized that the US will continue to hold Russia accountable for its actions and called on European allies to do the same. He also reiterated the US support for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Baltic states, which became NATO members in 2004.

The visit was seen as a show of unity and strength among NATO allies, with Pence meeting with the presidents of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, as well as NATO troops from Britain, France, and the US stationed in Estonia. The alliance has deployed around 4,000 troops and military hardware in the three Baltic states and Poland to counter Russia's buildup in the region.

Pence's trip is part of a broader European tour that also takes him to Georgia and Montenegro, two other countries facing strong pressure from Russia. The vice president's message was clear: the US will not back down in the face of Russian aggression and will continue to stand with its allies in defense of freedom and democracy.

Title: Trump's First Week in Office: A Complex Dance Between the President and Congress

Article:

The first week of President Trump's term has been marked by a complex dance between the new administration and Congress. The relationship between Trump and Republicans in Congress can be likened to a shotgun marriage – an unlikely couple brought together by circumstances, trying to make things work, but with questions about whether they can pull it off.

Trump's speech to House and Senate Republicans at their retreat in Philadelphia was a mix of his usual bravado, self-deprecation, and praise for his cabinet picks. Lawmakers were generous with standing ovations and applause, but silent on a couple of touchy points. Senator Jim Risch (R-ID) described the meeting as "warm" and "optimistic," but couldn't quite put his finger on why.

The ambitious agenda laid out by Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) covers Affordable Care Act repeal-and-replace, tax reform, regulation roll-back, the debt ceiling, paying for the wall, and infrastructure. It's a huge undertaking, especially for an institution designed by America's founders to be slow and deliberative. Trump's impatience and tweeting reflexes could add more friction to GOP efforts to push these legislative priorities through Congress.

Republicans plan to use a special budget process to pass their two top priorities – Obamacare repeal and tax reform – by majority vote and without the help of Democrats. However, the issues are complicated, and views differ among Republicans about how best to address them. The agenda is often described as a "clash between reality and fantasy."

The House doesn't have to worry about the Senate's special rules and slower pace, but the new president is confronting these challenges. Trump complained that the Senate has not yet confirmed his full cabinet, saying, "They are not quick with the pen on signing these people." Trump has a businessman's understanding of how Congress works, says John Feehery, former spokesman for the longest-serving Republican speaker of the House. "They go in, they give money, they don't get what they want, they get frustrated."

Lawmakers are trying to figure out how to work with a president who is unlike any they've encountered before. As Republicans huddled at their secure hotel in Philadelphia, Trump surprised them with tweets about a voter fraud investigation. "This is going to be an unconventional presidency," said Speaker Ryan at the press conference the next morning. "I think we're going to see unconventional activities like tweets and things like that, and I think that's just something that we're all going to have to get used to."

The voter fraud tweet seemed to roll off the backs of lawmakers, and several say they just ignore the tweet eruptions and try to focus on policy. "I don't see any evidence [of widespread fraud]," said Rep. Jason Chaffetz (R-UT), chairman of the House oversight committee. His committee has no plans to investigate, "but the president has 100,000 people at the Department of Justice, [and] if he wants to do an investigation, have at it."

In another surprise, The New York Times reported that the Trump administration was apparently going to review reopening "black site" prisons and undoing restrictions on interrogations. Lawmakers put their foot down and said there would be no return to torture. The White House denied the Times story, also reported by the Associated Press, saying the leak – not from the administration – was an old memo from the transition period.

Despite the challenges, Republicans are eager to prove to Americans that they can get the job done, and to do that, they need to work with each other. As Senator Risch pointed out, "We are going to have to be patient."

Title: Perry Criticizes Clinton's Stance on Voter ID Laws, Defends Texas' Support

Article:

Rick Perry, the former governor of Texas, has launched a fresh attack on Hillary Clinton's stance on voter ID laws, accusing her of alienating voters in the Lone Star State. Perry made the comments during an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, where he defended Texas' voter ID law, which was passed in 2011 and upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court.

Perry claimed that Clinton's call for easier voter ID laws is "way outside the norm of ridiculous" and that Texas already makes it easy for residents to vote. He also took a swipe at Clinton's speech in Texas, where she criticized Perry and other Republican presidential hopefuls for their support of voter ID laws and opposition to early voting.

Clinton's rapid-response team, Correct the Record, fired back at Perry's criticisms, accusing him of trying to deny citizens the right to vote under the guise of voter fraud. They also pointed out that Perry signed a law that was intentionally written to discriminate against minority voters.

In the same interview, Perry also defended his populist tone, taking aim at Wall Street banks and saying that it's not right for them to be able to walk away from bad mistakes that Main Street has to pay for. He also expressed support for regulating Wall Street, but believes that the Dodd-Frank regulatory reforms went too far and are harming community banks.

Perry launched his second presidential campaign on Thursday with an upbeat speech in an airplane hangar outside Addison, Texas, and rode a motorcycle and addressed the crowd in blue jeans and a baseball cap at an event hosted by Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst. He also secured a big coup by signing on influential conservative activist Sam Clovis to head his Iowa operation.

The debate over voter ID laws and voter suppression continues to be a contentious issue in the 2016 presidential election, with both sides accusing each other of trying to manipulate the electoral process.

**Title:** Americans' War Skepticism Wanes as North Korea's Threat Perceptions Rise

**Article:**

A recent poll by the Chicago Council of Foreign Affairs (CCFA) reveals that 75% of Americans believe North Korea poses a critical threat to the United States, a significant increase from 55% two years ago. This growing concern comes despite President Donald Trump's historically low approval ratings, which currently stand at 38%. The poll also found that 62% of respondents are uneasy about Trump's ability to handle the North Korean crisis.

The CCFA poll highlights the complexity of the situation, as Americans are divided on the best approach to address the threat. While 76% of Americans support increased sanctions against North Korea, 68% want sanctions extended to Chinese companies that work with the country. The poll also found that a majority of Americans support military action if North Korea attacks South Korea, a shift from previous years.

The poll's findings are not surprising, given the recent developments in the region. North Korea's successful miniaturization of a nuclear warhead for missile delivery has raised concerns about the country's military capabilities. Meanwhile, the US has responded with its own missile defense tests, further escalating tensions.

The poll's results are also influenced by the US's past experiences with military intervention. The failure of the War on Terror and the invasion of Iraq have left many Americans skeptical of military action. However, the current situation in North Korea has led to a shift in public opinion, with a majority of Americans supporting military action if necessary.

The CCFA poll also highlights the challenges of diplomacy in the region. North Korea is unlikely to accept any arrangement that does not allow it to maintain its nuclear weapons. The US has taught the world that even the threat of military action can be an effective deterrent, and Pyongyang has taken note.

The poll's findings have implications for the future of the Korean Peninsula. The US's military superiority and the buffer provided by the ocean have allowed it to act in a less than rational manner, while North Korea has been a relatively rational actor. However, the current situation is unlikely to improve, and the US may be forced to consider alternative approaches.

In conclusion, the CCFA poll highlights the complexity of the situation in North Korea and the challenges of diplomacy in the region. While Americans are divided on the best approach, the poll's findings suggest that war skepticism is waning, and the US may be forced to consider more aggressive measures to address the threat.

**Title:** Trump Administration Proposes Changes to Healthcare Rules, Insurers and Republicans Welcome the Move

**Article:**

The Trump administration has proposed changes to healthcare rules, which will be published in the Federal Register on Friday, giving the public until March 7 to comment. The proposed rules aim to stabilize the individual health insurance market, which has been struggling since the Affordable Care Act (ACA) was passed.

Insurers and Republican members of Congress have welcomed the proposed changes, which are expected to be finalized in March or April. Insurers must decide by early May what kinds of health plans they will offer in 2018.

Senator Lamar Alexander, a Republican from Tennessee and chairman of the Senate health committee, described the proposals as "important first steps to rescue a collapsing Obamacare individual market."

However, some critics have expressed concerns about the potential impact of the proposed rules. Christopher W. Hansen, the president of the advocacy arm of the American Cancer Society, warned that the tighter restrictions on special enrollment periods could "cause problems for cancer patients," delaying treatment and reducing their chances of survival.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has also proposed changes that could weaken incentives for people to obtain insurance. The agency said it will accept and process tax returns even if taxpayers fail to indicate whether they had coverage, qualified for an exemption, or were paying the penalty for going without insurance.

The individual mandate, requiring most Americans to have insurance, is still in force until changed by Congress. The government can deduct the amount of any penalty from refunds that would otherwise be sent to taxpayers. However, it is unclear how it will use this authority.

The proposed rules also allow states to determine whether insurance plans have enough doctors, hospitals, and other healthcare providers to serve patients. Insurers could refuse to provide new coverage to consumers who failed to pay premiums owed in the previous year. If an insurer terminates coverage for non-payment of premiums, it could require consumers to pay all past-due premiums owed to that insurer before restarting coverage.

Additionally, insurers will be allowed to sell health plans covering a smaller share of expected costs. The administration claims this will provide consumers with "more coverage options," but acknowledges that some consumers may see increases in their deductibles and other out-of-pocket costs.

Overall, the proposed changes aim to stabilize the individual health insurance market, but some critics argue that they do not address the underlying issues and may have unintended consequences.

**Midterm Elections: Republicans Gain Slight Edge in Latest Poll**

A recent survey conducted by The Wall Street Journal, NBC News, and the Annenberg Public Policy Center has found that a slight majority of likely voters prefer a Republican-led Congress over a Democratic-led one. The poll, which surveyed 1,172 voters from October 10-16, showed that 49% of likely voters prefer a Republican-controlled Congress, while 44% prefer a Democratic-controlled one.

The survey also found that Republicans have a slight edge among all registered voters, with 45% preferring a GOP-led Congress and 43% preferring a Democratic-led one. This marks the first time in five weeks that the GOP has taken the lead, according to The Journal.

The poll also highlights a significant difference in enthusiasm levels between the two parties. Among those most interested in the election, 51% favored the Republicans, while 44% favored the Democrats. In contrast, among those less interested in the election, 52% supported the Democrats, while 37% supported the Republicans.

The findings come as pundits continue to predict that the Republicans have the best chance of taking control of the Senate. Larry Sabato, director of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, projects that the GOP could take up to eight seats, while The Washington Post and The New York Times also predict a Republican takeover.

The poll suggests that President Barack Obama's low approval ratings may be a major factor dragging down the Democrats' chances. His support among women, in particular, has dropped sharply in battleground states where Democrats are already lagging among male voters.

The survey results provide a snapshot of the current political landscape ahead of the November 4 midterm elections. While the outcome is still uncertain, the poll suggests that Republicans may have a slight edge in terms of voter preference.

Title: The Trump Presidency: A Pattern of Distraction and Deception

Article:

The release of the Mueller report has led to a flurry of reactions, with some claiming that President Trump has emerged from the cloud of scandal and is now free to act as he pleases. However, a closer examination of Trump's behavior suggests that he has simply fallen back into a familiar pattern of distraction and deception.

Trump's playbook, as outlined in the article, involves denying the facts, attacking his enemies, and changing the subject. This pattern has been evident since the release of the Barr report, with Trump and his surrogates claiming that the president has been completely exonerated, despite Mueller's explicit statement that he did not make such a judgment.

The article highlights Trump's attempts to change the subject, including his administration's decision to file a letter in a Texas court seeking to declare the Affordable Care Act unconstitutional and his increased anti-immigrant rhetoric and threats to close the US-Mexico border. These moves are seen as self-destructive and likely to harm millions of Americans.

The article argues that Trump's goal is not to find solutions to the country's problems but to generate headlines and distract from the ongoing investigations. It urges Democrats to stay focused on obtaining a full copy of the Mueller report and making its contents known to the public, rather than getting sidetracked by Trump's antics.

The article concludes that Trump's behavior is a pattern of distraction and deception, and that Democrats should not let him get away with it. It emphasizes the importance of holding the president accountable and restoring faith in American government among the public.

Title: Pelosi Faces Uphill Battle to Retain Speaker Position, Finds Unlikely Support from Republicans

Article:

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., is facing a challenging road to reclaiming the speaker's gavel in January, with a growing number of Democrats signaling they will not support her bid. However, Pelosi has found an unlikely source of support: Republicans.

At least 17 House Democrats, including incumbents and incoming members, have signed a letter pledging not to support Pelosi on the House floor, according to Fox News. This means that if all those Democrats vote against her, Pelosi would not have the necessary votes to become speaker.

To secure the position, Pelosi will first need to win a majority of the Democratic caucus in internal leadership elections and then secure an absolute majority of the House. Despite her confidence in her ability to secure the necessary votes, Pelosi is facing an increasingly tight race.

In an unexpected turn of events, some Republicans are floating the idea of offering Pelosi support in the House, believing it could help them in the long term. Republican Tom Reed said that if Pelosi were to embrace a bipartisan package of rules reforms, he could envision supporting her.

Other Republicans have also suggested backing her bid, citing the potential benefits of having her in the role. Republican strategist Chris Wilson said, "She reminds the American people why they don't like politics. She reminds them why they don't like Democrats, quite frankly. The best thing in the world for Republicans is to have her in that role."

Pelosi has dismissed the idea that she would need Republican help to win the gavel, stating that she intends to win the speakership with Democratic votes and has "overwhelming support" within her caucus.

However, some Democrats are not convinced. Rep. Tim Ryan, D-Ohio, said, "I don't think this is a done deal yet" in terms of Pelosi becoming speaker again. Ryan also expressed hope that someone would challenge Pelosi.

On the other hand, some Democrats are more supportive of Pelosi's bid. House Progressive Caucus Chairwoman Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., said, "She has the experience. She's someone who gets things done. We don't need someone with a learning curve. We need to deliver some real wins pretty quickly."

As Pelosi navigates this challenging landscape, it remains to be seen whether she will be able to secure the necessary votes to become speaker once again.

Title: Justice Department Refers Andrew McCabe's Case to Federal Prosecutors for Possible Criminal Investigation

The Justice Department's inspector general has referred the findings of its report on former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe to federal prosecutors in Washington for possible criminal investigation. The referral, which was leaked to the press, suggests that McCabe may have lied to investigators or his own boss, then-FBI Director James Comey, on four occasions, three of them under oath.

According to the inspector general's report, McCabe lacked candor with internal investigators at the agency and was not authorized to disclose to reporters the existence of an investigation into the Clinton Foundation. The referral raises the possibility that McCabe could be charged and jailed for his alleged misconduct, with Comey potentially testifying as a witness against him.

McCabe's lawyer, Michael R. Bromwich, has stated that they were advised of the referral within the past few weeks and are confident that the U.S. Attorney's Office will conclude that it should decline to prosecute. However, the referral does not necessarily mean that McCabe will be charged with a crime.

Former FBI Assistant Director Frank Figliuzzi has expressed concerns about the referral, calling it "unprecedented" and stating that the remedy for lacking candor during an internal inquiry is typically termination, not a criminal referral. Figliuzzi also noted that approving an unauthorized leak could rise to the level of criminal referral.

The referral has sparked debate and raised questions about the motivations behind the leak, with some speculating that someone is trying to discredit McCabe and others arguing that the referral is a political witch hunt. The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen whether McCabe will face criminal charges or any other consequences for his alleged misconduct.

Title: Melania Trump's Speech Raises Questions of Plagiarism Amidst Chaotic Republican National Convention

Article:

The first day of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland was marked by controversy and chaos, with Melania Trump's speech at the center of the storm. The First Lady's address, which aimed to highlight her values and those of her husband, Donald Trump, raised eyebrows when it became clear that a significant portion of the speech was lifted directly from Michelle Obama's 2008 Democratic National Convention speech.

The similarities between the two speeches are striking, with Melania Trump repeating almost verbatim Michelle Obama's words on the importance of hard work, keeping promises, and treating people with respect. The Trump campaign initially downplayed the issue, with spokesman Jason Miller stating that Melania's team of writers took notes on her life's inspirations and included fragments that reflected her own thinking.

However, the plagiarism allegations quickly gained traction, with many pointing out the striking similarities between the two speeches. The Trump campaign eventually acknowledged the issue, with campaign manager Paul Manafort attacking Hillary Clinton and claiming that the plagiarism was an attempt to "take her down."

The controversy comes as the Republican National Convention was already marred by a chaotic first day, with fights erupting on the convention floor, conspiracy theorist Alex Jones being interrupted by a comedian, and Rep. Steve King making comments about white people being better than "sub-groups." The convention also saw a focus on the Benghazi attacks, with speaker after speaker recalling the events in minute detail.

The plagiarism allegations have sparked a heated debate, with some defending Melania Trump's speech as a legitimate expression of shared values, while others see it as a clear example of intellectual property theft. The controversy has also drawn comparisons to the plagiarism scandal surrounding Joe Biden in 2008, which was used by Donald Trump to question Obama's running mate.

As the Republican National Convention continues, the focus will be on whether the Trump campaign can recover from the controversy and whether Melania Trump's speech will be remembered as a highlight of the convention or a low point.

Title: The Controversy Surrounding SeaWorld: Separating Fact from Fiction

Article:

The documentary "Blackfish" has sparked a heated debate about the ethics of keeping killer whales in captivity at SeaWorld. The film, which was purchased by CNN and aired repeatedly, presents a grim picture of the treatment of these marine mammals. According to the documentary, greedy businessmen separate baby whales from their mothers and confine them to small aquariums, leading to psychological trauma and aggression.

However, SeaWorld disputes the claims made in the documentary, stating that they have not separated whales from their mothers in 35 years and have no plans to do so again. The park's head trainer, Kelly Flaherty Clark, emphasizes that the film implies that they are doing this yesterday, which is not the case.

The documentary also claims that captive whales have droopy dorsal fins, indicating their misery. However, whale expert Ingrid Visser points out that killer whales in the wild also have collapsed dorsal fins. The film's director and other participants refused to comment, but biologist Lori Marino, who claims that all whales in captivity have a bad life, did share her thoughts.

Marino argues that the animals are not adapted to living in concrete tanks and need space and a social life. SeaWorld's head veterinarian, Chris Dold, counters that the whales are happy and that the trainers have a good relationship with them. He also points out that one whale did drown a trainer, but there is no evidence that the whale was frustrated because it lives in a tank.

The documentary also claims that captive whales die young, but Dold notes that one of their whales is 50 years old, and government research confirms that their life parameters are similar to those of whales in the wild.

The debate surrounding SeaWorld is complex and emotional, with both sides presenting valid points. While it is understandable that people may be disturbed by the idea of keeping animals in captivity, it is also important to consider the educational and conservation benefits that marine parks and zoos provide. SeaWorld, for example, has helped rescue 25,000 animals.

Ultimately, the decision to support or boycott SeaWorld is a personal one, and it is essential to separate fact from fiction and consider the nuances of the issue.

**President Trump Addresses Range of Topics in Fox News Sunday Interview**

In a recent interview with Fox News Sunday, President Trump discussed a variety of topics, including his views on CNN correspondent Jim Acosta, his appointment of acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, and his stance on recent elections, foreign policy, and more.

During the interview, Trump expressed his opinion on Acosta's behavior, stating that he was "unbelievably rude" to White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee during a recent press briefing. Trump also warned that if Acosta misbehaves, he will be removed from the press conference or have his press pass revoked.

On the topic of Whitaker, Trump claimed he was unaware of his past remarks about the Mueller investigation when he appointed him to replace Jeff Sessions at the Department of Justice. Trump stated, "I did not know that," when asked if he was aware prior to appointing Whitaker that he had argued Mueller was coming close to exceeding his authority.

The president also touched on recent elections, citing the Florida Senate race as an example. Trump claimed that he helped Republican candidate Rick Scott win the election by putting a spotlight on the election before it got down to the 12,500 votes.

In terms of foreign policy, Trump discussed his views on North Korea, stating that the country has been "very tough" because of the sanctions imposed by the US. He also expressed his support for Saudi Arabia, stating that the country has been a good ally, despite imposing heavy sanctions on a large group of individuals.

Trump also touched on his decision to end aid to Pakistan, stating that the country does not do anything for the US and that he ended the aid because of it.

Finally, Trump expressed regret for not visiting Arlington National Cemetery on Veterans Day, stating that he was extremely busy on calls for the country and had just returned from a trip to Paris.

Overall, the interview provided insight into the president's views on a range of topics, from domestic politics to foreign policy.

Title: Government Agencies' License Plate Reader Plans Raise Concerns about Gun Show Surveillance

Article:

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has released documents obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request, revealing that the Department of Justice and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) collaborated on plans to monitor gun show attendees using automatic license plate readers. The documents, dating back to 2009, show that the agencies aimed to track the license plates of cars in gun show parking lots, raising concerns about the potential invasion of privacy and targeting of law-abiding citizens.

The ACLU obtained the documents through a Freedom of Information Act request and claims that the agencies used license plate readers to collect information about law-abiding citizens attending gun shows. The organization argues that automatic license plate readers cannot distinguish between people transporting illegal guns and those transporting legal guns or no guns at all, and that mere attendance at a gun show would have been enough to have one's presence noted in a DEA database.

The DEA responded to inquiries about the document, stating that the monitoring of gun shows was merely a proposal and was never implemented. However, the ACLU had concluded, based on the information available, that gun show monitoring was underway.

The controversy surrounding the use of automatic license plate readers has sparked concerns about the government's targeting of constitutionally protected rights, such as the right to assemble. The Department of Justice's own surveys of prison inmates have shown that criminals do not obtain their firearms from gun shows, raising questions about the effectiveness of such surveillance measures.

The revelation also highlights the contrast between the government's priorities. While the ATF and DEA were interested in tracking law-abiding citizens attending gun shows, they showed little interest in tracking the thousands of weapons that were intentionally given to Mexican narco-terrorists through Operation Fast and Furious, which were used to kill hundreds of people, including U.S. federal law enforcement officers.

Title: The Complexities of Immigrant Integration: A Study on the Challenges and Opportunities

Article:

A recent study on the experiences of immigrant students in the United States has shed light on the complex challenges and opportunities that come with integrating new arrivals into the fabric of society. The research, which focused on the academic and social outcomes of immigrant students, revealed a mixed picture of both struggles and successes.

On one hand, the study found that many immigrant students face significant barriers to success, including limited English proficiency, interrupted schooling, and family instability. These challenges can lead to declining academic performance and increased risk of dropping out of school. In fact, nearly two-thirds of the students in the study exhibited declining academic performance over time.

On the other hand, the study also highlighted the importance of supportive schools, caring teachers, and informal mentorships in helping immigrant students succeed. A quarter of the students in the study sustained high academic performance over the five-year period, and 11% showed significant improvement. These students tended to be enrolled in supportive schools, have caring teachers, and develop informal mentorships with coaches, counselors, or ministers.

The study also explored the experiences of the Tsarnaev brothers, who immigrated to the United States at a young age and struggled to adjust. While their case is unique, it highlights the importance of providing a scaffold of support for immigrant students, including academic, psychological, and social services.

The research suggests that the second generation of immigrant students, those born in the United States to immigrant parents, tend to assimilate and excel more than the "1.5 generation," those who immigrate in or before their early teens. This finding underscores the importance of providing targeted support to immigrant students, particularly those who arrive during their high school years.

The study's findings have implications for educators, policymakers, and society as a whole. As the United States continues to experience significant population growth driven by immigration, it is essential to develop effective strategies for integrating immigrant students into the fabric of society. One successful model is the Internationals Network for Public Schools, which focuses on students' distinct needs and develops authentic connections with their families.

Ultimately, the study's findings underscore the importance of empathy, understanding, and support for immigrant students. As Emma Lazarus wrote, "Give me your tired, your poor, / Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free, / The wretched refuse of your teeming shore." By providing a scaffold of support, we can help immigrant students succeed and thrive in their new home.

**Title:** Shellie Zimmerman Pleads Guilty to Misdemeanor Perjury, Receives One-Year Probation

**Article:**

Shellie Zimmerman, the wife of George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer acquitted in the killing of Trayvon Martin, has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor perjury charge for lying at her husband's bond hearing. As part of the plea deal, Shellie Zimmerman was sentenced to one year of probation and 100 hours of community service.

In April 2012, Shellie Zimmerman testified before Judge Kenneth Lester, stating that the couple had little funds. However, it was later revealed that George Zimmerman had collected over $100,000 in donations through the internet, which Shellie Zimmerman failed to disclose. The couple had discussed the money transfers in code to hide the funds, according to recordings of jail calls released by the Florida State Attorney's Office.

The investigation revealed that Shellie Zimmerman transferred over $74,000 to her personal account and nearly $50,000 to an account held by Zimmerman's sister. The taped phone calls showed that the couple discussed paying off bills, including American Express and Sam's Club, using code words such as "$10, $20, and $100" to mask the true amount.

Judge Lester ruled that Shellie Zimmerman had testified untruthfully about their finances, and she was later arrested and jailed briefly in Seminole County before posting a $1,000 bond. George Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder and manslaughter in July 2013.

As part of her probation, Shellie Zimmerman must abide by several conditions, including not possessing, carrying, or owning a firearm, reporting regularly to a probation officer, paying $263 in court fees and fines, and paying the state of Florida $50 per month as a cost of supervision. Her probation can be revoked if she violates the law, associates with anyone engaged in criminal activity, or uses any drugs not prescribed by a doctor.

**Title:** US Extends Social Distancing Guidelines for 30 More Days to Combat COVID-19

**Article:**

The United States has extended its social distancing guidelines for an additional 30 days, aiming to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus. The decision was announced by President Trump on Sunday, following a news conference in the Rose Garden. The guidelines, initially set to expire on Monday, will now continue until April 30.

Under the recommendations, Americans are urged to avoid gatherings of more than 10 people, restrict non-essential travel, and maintain a safe distance from others to reduce the risk of transmission. The President emphasized the importance of adhering to these guidelines, stating, "The better you do, the faster this whole nightmare will end."

The decision to prolong the social distancing guidelines comes as models suggest the worst days of the pandemic could be yet to come, with some estimates predicting up to 200,000 deaths in the United States if containment efforts are not maintained. Dr. Anthony Fauci and Dr. Deborah Birx, members of the White House's coronavirus task force, pointed to these models, which indicate that millions of Americans could become infected if social distancing measures are not followed.

While some experts have expressed concerns about the potential for a prolonged pandemic, Dr. Birx expressed optimism, stating, "We can do better than what the predictions are." The hope is that the actual case load and death toll will be lower than predicted.

The extension of the social distancing guidelines comes as coronavirus cases in the United States continue to rise, with over 2,000 deaths reported. State and local officials are bracing for shortages of medical equipment and supplies, with some predicting critical supplies like ventilators could be overwhelmed in the coming weeks.

In a separate development, President Trump raised concerns about the rapid use of medical supplies, suggesting that medical professionals might be "hoarding" masks and ventilators. However, there is no evidence to support this claim.

The administration has also highlighted the progress made in testing, with over 894,000 tests conducted nationally as of Saturday. The pace of testing has accelerated in recent weeks, with federal officials working to increase testing capacity and availability.

The extension of the social distancing guidelines is a crucial step in the fight against COVID-19, as the country navigates the ongoing pandemic.

Title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly Truck Attack in New York City

Article:

A deadly truck attack in New York City has left eight people dead and a dozen more injured, with the Islamic State claiming responsibility for the attack. The militant group described the accused attacker, Sayfullo Saipov, as "one of the caliphate soldiers" in its weekly newspaper, Al-Naba.

Saipov, a 29-year-old Uzbek immigrant, was charged with acting in support of Islamic State after plowing a rented pickup truck down a popular riverside bike trail, crushing pedestrians and cyclists. The criminal complaint against him states that Saipov was inspired by Islamic State propaganda videos on his cellphone and felt good about what he had done.

The attack occurred on Tuesday afternoon, just blocks from the site of the World Trade Center, where some 2,600 people were killed in the 9/11 attacks. The victims included five Argentine tourists, a Belgian woman, a New Yorker, and a New Jersey man.

Saipov was taken to Bellevue Hospital after being shot in the abdomen by a police officer before his arrest. U.S. President Donald Trump has called for Saipov to receive the death penalty, tweeting that the attacker was a "degenerate animal" who killed and wounded "the wonderful people on the West Side" of Lower Manhattan.

In a separate development, the Islamic State's self-proclaimed caliphate appeared to be on the verge of defeat, with Syrian government forces seizing its last major city on one side of the border and Iraqi troops taking its last big town on the other. The group's leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, is believed to be hiding in the desert near the frontier, and regional officials fear it will reconstitute itself as a guerrilla force capable of waging attacks without territory to defend.

Saipov's sister, who spoke to a reporter from the Uzbek capital Tashkent, believes her brother may have been brainwashed and appealed to Trump to ensure he receives a fair trial. She said she spoke with her brother the day before the attack and he was in a good mood.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has located another Uzbek man, Mukhammadzoir Kadirov, 32, who is wanted for questioning as a person of interest in the attack.

**Title:** Bill Gates Warns of Future Epidemics: A Call to Action for Global Preparedness

**Article:**

In a recent article published in the New England Journal of Medicine, Bill Gates, a renowned businessman and philanthropist, sounded the alarm about the potential for future epidemics to spread more rapidly and widely than Ebola. Gates emphasized the importance of learning from past experiences, such as the Spanish influenza epidemic of 1918-1919 and the ongoing human immunodeficiency virus pandemic, to prepare for the possibility of a major epidemic in the next 20 years.

Gates highlighted the need for a comprehensive plan to manage and coordinate responses to future epidemics, likening it to preparing for war. He stressed that the world is still lacking in its ability to respond to epidemics, with significant gaps in global preparedness and response systems. Gates called for a rigorous study of the cost of building a global warning and response system and a plan for contributions from various countries.

However, not everyone agrees with Gates' assessment. Emmanuel d'Harcourt, senior health director of the International Rescue Committee, believes that local preparedness and response are the key to preventing major epidemics. According to d'Harcourt, local communities are often the first to respond to disasters, including epidemics, and having a robust local response system in place can prevent the spread of disease.

The ongoing Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone and Guinea serves as a reminder of the importance of preparedness and response. The World Health Organization reported that cases continue to rise in Guinea, a year after the outbreak began. While the global response to Ebola was unprecedented, it is clear that more work needs to be done to prepare for future epidemics.

In conclusion, Bill Gates' warning serves as a call to action for governments, organizations, and individuals to prioritize global preparedness and response to epidemics. While there are differing opinions on the best approach, it is clear that a comprehensive plan is necessary to mitigate the impact of future epidemics.

Title: The Media's Biased Coverage of the Presidential Election: A Threat to Objectivity?

Article:

The current presidential election has sparked a frenzy of media coverage, with many outlets dedicating extensive resources to scrutinizing the candidates' personal lives and attributes. While some may argue that this level of scrutiny is necessary to inform voters, others believe it has crossed the line into bias and sensationalism.

The New York Times, a respected newspaper, has been accused of taking a particularly aggressive stance against Donald Trump, with some of its columnists labeling him as "puerile," "sophomoric," and "bigoted." While Trump's opponents may have legitimate concerns about his qualifications and temperament, others argue that this kind of language is excessive and unfair.

The media's fixation on Trump's personal life and business dealings has also led some to question the objectivity of their reporting. Rather than focusing on the issues and policies that matter most to voters, many outlets seem more interested in sensational headlines and gotcha moments.

Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton's campaign has been criticized for its lack of substance and conviction. While she has been praised for her experience and qualifications, some argue that she lacks the kind of bold ideas and vision that the country needs to move forward.

The media's role in shaping public opinion is crucial, and it is essential that they maintain their commitment to objectivity and fairness. Rather than taking sides or engaging in personal attacks, journalists should focus on providing voters with the information they need to make informed decisions.

Ultimately, the media's coverage of this election will have a lasting impact on the country's political landscape. As voters, it is our responsibility to demand more from our journalists and to hold them accountable for their reporting.

Title: Presidential Candidates' Vice Presidential Vetting Processes: A Look Back and Ahead

Article:

The process of selecting a running mate is a crucial part of a presidential campaign, and several candidates have taken different approaches to finding their ideal partner. In recent years, Mitt Romney, Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, and Joe Biden have all navigated the complex process of vetting potential running mates.

Romney's 2012 campaign started with a list of 80 potential candidates, which was narrowed down to five men after Condoleezza Rice declined the invitation to be vetted. Trump's process was less streamlined, but he interviewed Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa. Clinton's campaign started with 40 possible candidates, which was narrowed down to nine who underwent a vetting process, with Senator Elizabeth Warren being the only woman to advance to the final stages.

Biden's campaign has taken a different approach, with a focus on selecting a woman to address concerns about his age and critiques about the primary process. His campaign has sent out a fundraising appeal asking supporters to "commit to standing with" him and his future female running mate. By announcing he will pick a woman, Biden aims to give his ticket a modern-day balance in a party focused on issues of racial and gender representation.

Past nominees have chosen running mates who provided geographic diversity, such as Lloyd Bentsen in 1988, or offered the promise of winning a key state, like Paul Ryan in 2012. Obama chose Biden in 2008 to ease concerns about his own relative lack of experience and help appeal to white working-class voters.

Choosing a woman as a running mate would not only provide gender balance but also add a black woman to the ticket, which could be a significant milestone. However, the memory of Kamala Harris's debate stage attack may hinder her chances.

Title: Foxconn's Wisconsin Project Hits Snag: No Factory, Fewer Jobs, and a Shift to "Technology Hub"

Article:

The highly touted Foxconn project in Wisconsin, promised to bring 13,000 blue-collar jobs and a manufacturing facility to the state, is now facing significant changes. According to Louis Woo, a high-ranking assistant to Foxconn's chairman, the company is reconsidering its plans and is likely to turn the Wisconsin facility into a "technology hub" instead.

The shift in plans means that the jobs created will likely be "knowledge" positions, rather than blue-collar jobs, contradicting the initial promises made by former Governor Scott Walker and President Donald Trump. The company had already acknowledged in November that it planned to import workers from Taiwan and China to meet its hiring goals in Wisconsin.

Foxconn's decision to pivot comes as the company struggles to remain competitive in the global marketplace. The company had originally promised to create 5,200 jobs by the end of 2020, but has since revised that number to around 1,000.

The problems with the Foxconn factory were evident from the start. Building television screens with relatively expensive American labor was always a major question mark, and it was unclear how the company would operate a massive manufacturing center in a location without a dense ecosystem of suppliers and sub-suppliers.

There were warning signs that Foxconn would struggle to follow through on its promises. The company had previously walked away from plans to invest $5 billion and create 50,000 jobs in India, Vietnam, and Brazil. Even in the United States, there were concerns about Foxconn's ability to deliver on its promises, as seen in its failed plan to invest $30 million and create 500 jobs in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania.

The Foxconn deal was always problematic, with Wisconsin's Legislative Fiscal Bureau estimating it would take the state until 2043 to recoup the $3 billion handout, the largest such subsidy in Wisconsin history. Even if all 13,000 promised jobs went to Wisconsinites, the tab would be more than $230,000 per job created.

The deal also raises concerns about eminent domain, as Foxconn will receive over 1,000 acres of land for free, with the logic being that the subsequent increase in land value will pay for itself eventually in the form of higher property taxes.

The failure of the Foxconn deal serves as a warning to future politicians considering similar schemes. It is clear that the promises made by Foxconn, Walker, and Trump were overly optimistic, and the project's struggles are a reminder of the importance of careful consideration and due diligence when making large-scale economic deals.

**Pet Adoption Surges Amid Pandemic, Pet Supplies See Boost**

As the world grapples with the challenges of the coronavirus pandemic, an unexpected trend has emerged: a surge in pet adoption. In the New York City area, shelters are reporting a significant increase in applications, with some even running out of cats and dogs. This phenomenon is not limited to the Big Apple, as shelters across the United States are seeing a similar trend.

According to Muddy Paws Rescue and Best Friends Animal Society, shelters they work with are experiencing a 10-fold increase in applications over the past two weeks. This surge is attributed to people seeking companionship and comfort during the pandemic. "For the moment, we don't have any dogs left to match with foster volunteers," said Anna Lai, marketing director at Muddy Paws. "Which is a great problem to have."

The demand for pets has also led to a boost in pet supplies. Shares of Chewy Inc., an online pet retailer, have risen 7% this year, with delivery times pushed back to between seven and 10 days due to increased volume. PetMed Express Inc., an animal pharmaceutical company, is also up more than 7%, while Freshpet Inc. shares are down 2.3% compared to the S&P 500 Index's 23% decline.

The trend extends beyond New York, with the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals reporting a 70% increase in animals going into foster care in Los Angeles. Best Friends, a national animal welfare organization, has also seen a surge in foster applications across the country.

While the surge in pet adoption is a welcome development, rescue organizations are concerned about the potential for a reverse trend once the pandemic subsides. "We're doing whatever we can to empty all of our shelter facilities," said Lisa LaFontaine, CEO of the Humane Rescue Alliance. "We don't know what's going to happen when the economic wave starts hitting."

For some, the pandemic has provided an opportunity to adopt a pet. Tom Drescher and his wife, Becky Nolin, recently brought home Goldie, a 10-year-old mixed breed, and are enjoying the companionship. "It occurred to us it would be a good time to adopt a dog because we'd have the time and bandwidth to help it settle in," said Drescher. "It's been a blast for us so far – we've been thrilled to have her."

Title: FBI Investigation and WikiLeaks Release Intensify Election Uncertainty

The presidential race has taken a dramatic turn as federal investigators begin searching through newly discovered emails belonging to Hillary Clinton's top aide, Huma Abedin. The emails were found on the laptop of Abedin's estranged husband, Anthony Weiner, who is currently under investigation for allegedly sexting an underage girl. While officials have obtained a warrant to search the emails, it is unlikely the review will be completed by Election Day.

The news has sent shockwaves through the campaign, with the presidential race now tightening dramatically in the last few days. The gap between the two candidates has narrowed, with both sides vying for key swing states where the election will likely be decided.

Clinton addressed supporters at a rally in Kent, Ohio, Monday, sounding defiant about the email controversy. "I'm sure a lot of you may be asking what this new email story is about and why in the world the FBI would decide to jump into an election with no evidence of wrongdoing with just days to go? That's a good question," she said. "First of all, for those of you who are concerned about my use of personal email, I understand. As I said, I'm not making excuses, I understand and I regret it. They should look at them. And I'm sure they will reach the same conclusion they did when they looked at my emails for the last year. There is no case here."

Meanwhile, Trump kept his focus on Clinton's latest controversy, saying, "Thank you, Anthony. I never liked you, Anthony, but thank you very much. The Clinton crime spree ends on Nov. 8. It's going to end on Nov. 8."

The investigation and potential releases from WikiLeaks could bring more problems for Clinton in the days ahead. The organization has already caused issues for Democratic operatives, including the recent revelation that former analyst Donna Brazile had leaked a question from one of the debates in the Democratic primary to the Clinton campaign. The last week before the election could be as unpredictable as the entire campaign has been so far this year.

**Senate Democrats Elect Chuck Schumer as New Minority Leader**

Washington D.C. - In a move aimed at revitalizing the party's message and appeal, Senate Democrats have elected Chuck Schumer as their new minority leader. The New York Senator, known for his energetic and outgoing personality, will succeed Harry Reid, who opted to retire rather than run for re-election.

Schumer, who turns 66 next week, emphasized the need for the party to learn from its recent electoral defeats and focus on a stronger economic message that addresses the concerns of the middle class and those struggling to join it. He emphasized the importance of unity and avoiding divisions within the party.

"We need to be the party that speaks to and works on behalf of all Americans," Schumer said. "We need a bigger, bolder, sharper-edged economic message that focuses on helping middle-class Americans do better."

Schumer also expressed a willingness to find common ground with President-elect Donald Trump, noting that his campaign's economic message was closer to the Democratic Party's stance than that of the Republican leadership.

The new minority leader will lead a expanded Democratic leadership team, which includes former presidential candidate Bernie Sanders as outreach chairman, Tammy Baldwin as Democratic Conference secretary, and moderate Joe Manchin as vice chair of the Democratic Policy and Communications Committee.

Schumer's appointment marks a significant change in leadership style, as he is known for his more outgoing and telegenic personality compared to his predecessor, Harry Reid. Eric Herzik, chairman of the political science department at the University of Nevada, Reno, noted that Schumer's energy and upbeat attitude may help him negotiate with Republicans.

Schumer's background includes a long history of public service, having served in the House of Representatives for 18 years and sponsoring several notable bills, including the Omnibus Crime Bill and the Violence Against Women Act. He was also a key player in the "gang of eight" senators who crafted a bipartisan immigration reform bill in 2013.

As minority leader, Schumer will face off against Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who was re-elected to the top leadership spot by his GOP colleagues on Wednesday.

Title: Record Number of Voters Register for Midterm Elections Amid High Stakes and Polarization

Article:

As the 2018 midterm elections approach, the United States is witnessing a surge in voter registration, with over 800,000 people signing up to cast their ballots in September alone. This marks a significant increase from the 154,500 registered voters in 2014, according to the organization Nonprofit Vote. The uptick in political engagement comes as the country prepares to head to the polls on November 6, with the outcome set to determine which party controls Congress and potentially change the course of President Donald Trump's presidency.

The elections are seen as a referendum on Trump's presidency, with 60% of Americans saying their vote will be an expression of opposition to or support for the president, according to a Pew Research Center survey. The Senate map is more favorable to Republicans, who are hoping to expand their narrow 51-49 seat majority by toppling several red-state Democratic incumbents.

Several states are reporting record numbers of voters registering to cast their ballots in November. California, for instance, has seen an increase of about 1.5 million registered voters compared to the 2014 midterms, while Texas has reported an 11% rise in registered voters. The Lone Star State is home to a key Senate race between Democrat Beto O'Rourke and Republican Ted Cruz.

The surge in voter registration has been driven by a combination of factors, including the polarization of politics and the increasing importance of the midterm elections. Politicians, celebrities, and other public figures have escalated their calls on voters to register as deadlines come to a close in states that could prove influential in November.

While it remains to be seen how many of those who registered will show up at the polls, experts say the increased engagement is a positive sign for democracy. "It's still going to be well short of a presidential election," said Michael McDonald, an associate professor of political science at the University of Florida. "It's not that it's going to revolutionize turnout, but it's a good sign that people are paying attention."

The surge in voter registration has also been driven by the efforts of celebrities like Taylor Swift, Rihanna, and other public figures who have used their platforms to encourage people to register and vote. According to Vote.org, Swift's rare political statement led to a spike in voter registrations that topped 65,000 in just 24 hours.

Raven Brooks, the COO of Vote.org, said celebrities are particularly persuasive in motivating young voters to the polls. "We've been seeing an incredible spike in voter registration just in terms of numbers," he said. "It's definitely being driven by younger voters."

Title: Missouri Senate Candidates Debate Health Care, Foreign Policy, and More
