The move comes after Attorney General William Barr refused to turn over the unredacted report by a Tuesday deadline, citing concerns about protecting grand jury information and intelligence-gathering sources.

The committee voted 24-17 along party lines, with Democrats in favor and Republicans opposed. Nadler has not yet exercised the authority to issue subpoenas, but has expressed frustration with Barr's decision to redact parts of the report.

The subpoenas would seek the full report and underlying evidence, as well as documents and testimony from former Trump aides Steve Bannon, Donald McGahn, Reince Priebus, Hope Hicks, and Ann Donaldson. The committee has already sent requests for documents to 81 people, agencies, and entities as part of its investigation into obstruction and corruption.

Nadler has stated that he will work with Barr "for a short period of time" to try to obtain the full report and underlying materials, but will go to court if necessary. The potential battle between the executive and legislative branches could end up being resolved by the federal judiciary.

Representative Doug Collins, the committee's top Republican, criticized the move, calling it "reckless," "irresponsible," and "disingenuous." The Justice Department has declined to comment on the matter.

The move is the latest development in the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election and potential obstruction of justice by the Trump administration. The House Intelligence Committee is also seeking an interview with and documents from a top organizer on Trump's inaugural committee, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The controversy surrounding the Mueller report has sparked a heated debate about the role of Congress and the Justice Department in the investigation. While some have praised Barr's decision to release a summary of the report, others have criticized the redactions and called for the full report to be made public.

**G20 Summit Protests in Hamburg: Thousands Gather, Violence Erupts**

Thousands of protesters gathered in Hamburg, Germany, on the second day of the G20 summit, with some setting cars on fire and attempting to block leaders' delegations from entering the convention center. The city's police force brought in reinforcements from other cities to quell the situation, resulting in the arrest of at least 45 demonstrators and the temporary detention of 15 others.

The protests turned violent, with police using water cannons to disperse the crowds and 160 officers injured, including three who were hospitalized. Eleven protesters were also severely injured, with 14 treated by the fire department and transported to hospitals. The reason for the protesters climbing the wall remains unclear.

German Interior Senator Andy Grote expressed concern over the violence, stating that the potential for criminal energy and violence was "shocking." The city's police department tweeted that all leaders had safely entered the convention center, despite the chaos outside.

German Justice Minister Heiko Maas condemned the violent protests, saying that they were a disservice to the peaceful demonstrators who had gathered. "These extremist criminals don't belong in the streets, but in court," he said.

The G20 summit, which began on Thursday, aims to address issues such as international terrorism and climate change. The leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, US President Donald Trump, and Russian President Vladimir Putin, are meeting to discuss these topics.

Trump arrived in Hamburg earlier on Thursday, following his speech in Warsaw, where he called for defending Western values and rallying against "dire threats" to civilizations. He met privately with Merkel, discussing issues such as North Korea, the Middle East, and the G20 agenda.

The G20 summit is expected to continue on Friday, with Trump set to meet with Putin for about 35 minutes.

**Senate Seats Up for Grabs in 2016: A Shift in Favor of Democrats?**

The 2016 election cycle is shaping up to be a different story for the Republican Party, according to political analyst Charlie Cook. While the party had an easy ride in the 2014 midterm elections, winning seven Democratic Senate seats in states that former presidential candidate Mitt Romney won handily in 2012, the tables may turn in 2016.

This time around, Republicans will have to defend 24 seats, while Democrats will only have 10 seats up for re-election. Moreover, all 10 Democratic seats are in states that President Barack Obama won in 2012, whereas seven Republican-held seats are in states that Obama won as well. These states include Florida, Illinois, Iowa, New Hampshire, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin.

One potential silver lining for Republicans is that the Senate seats up for re-election in blue states were not won by Obama by margins as wide as the red states won by Romney in 2014. For instance, the reddest state with a Democratic senator up for re-election in 2014 was West Virginia, which Romney won by 27 points. In contrast, the bluest state up for re-election with a Republican senator is Illinois, which Obama won by 17 points.

Another factor working in the GOP's favor is that not all states with Republican senators up for re-election that were won by Obama in 2012 are necessarily competitive. For example, it is unlikely that Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley will lose in Iowa, even though Obama won the Hawkeye State by 6 points in 2012. The competitiveness of the other states will depend on who the Democratic challengers are.

The Democrats, on the other hand, have three open seats with two in deep blue states, while the Republicans have two open seats, with only one considered competitive. If Democrats want to reclaim the majority in the Senate, they will need to pick up four seats if a Democrat wins the presidential election, and five if they don't.

Title: Democratic Presidential Primary: Warren and Biden Neck and Neck in Latest Poll

Article:

A new national poll conducted by Quinnipiac University has revealed a close race between Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and former Vice President Joe Biden for the Democratic presidential nomination. The survey, which was conducted from October 11-13, showed Warren standing at 30% support among Democratic voters and independents who lean towards the party, while Biden trailed closely behind at 27%.

This is the third consecutive poll in which Warren has edged out Biden, according to Quinnipiac University Polling Analyst Tim Malloy. "Her candidacy clearly has staying power going into the debate," Malloy emphasized.

The poll also showed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont at 11%, South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg at 8%, and Senator Kamala Harris of California at 4%. Other candidates in the shrinking field of contenders registered at 2% or less.

In contrast, a Fox News poll released last week indicated Biden at 32%, with Warren 10 points behind at 22%, and Sanders at 17%. No other candidate cracked double digits in the Fox News survey.

The debate, set to take place on Tuesday at Otterbein University in Westerville, Ohio, will feature 12 candidates, including Warren, Biden, Sanders, and others. While national primary horserace polls have grabbed attention, the battle for the nomination is a fight for the states and their delegates.

In New Hampshire, a new poll showed a three-way tie at the top, with Warren, Biden, and Sanders each receiving 25% support among likely Democratic primary voters. Buttigieg stood at 9%, and Harris at 5%, with no one else in the field topping 2%.

In the Republican presidential contest, President Trump remained the overwhelming favorite against three extreme long-shot primary challengers, but his support has deteriorated from 88% a month ago to 71% in the survey.

Title: Capitol Hill Divided: ObamaCare Repeal Efforts Spark Debate

Article:

The battle lines have been drawn on Capitol Hill as the debate over ObamaCare's fate continues to unfold. President Obama and Vice President-elect Mike Pence met with their respective congressional allies to discuss strategy for the repeal push. While Obama urged Democrats to "fight" for the Affordable Care Act's survival, Pence assured Republicans that the Trump administration will make the law's demise its "first order of business."

Pence emphasized that the repeal process will be a "two-track approach," with the incoming Trump administration using executive powers and congressional leaders drafting and passing legislation. He also stated that the White House team is already working on a series of executive actions. Sources suggest that Republicans hope to have a repeal bill on Trump's desk by February 20, just a month after the inauguration.

However, the repeal effort has sparked concerns among some Republicans, who worry that ending ObamaCare without a replacement plan could result in millions of Americans losing their health insurance. House Speaker Paul Ryan acknowledged that Republicans have "plenty of plans" but did not provide specifics.

Meanwhile, Obama and fellow Democrats are urging caution, warning that repealing ObamaCare without a replacement plan would be a "disaster" and lead to chaos in the healthcare system. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer blasted Republicans for their repeal-replace agenda, stating that they have no idea what to put in place of ObamaCare.

The debate comes as the 115th Congress begins its work, with Senate Republicans taking the first step towards repealing ObamaCare by introducing a resolution to begin the process for repeal legislation. The resolution calls for two House and two Senate committees to send over a legislative plan by January 27.

While the repeal effort is underway, Trump has provided few specifics on how he would revamp the nation's healthcare system, mentioning only that he would rely more on tax credits to help people afford coverage. The debate is expected to continue as the new administration and Congress work to shape the future of healthcare in the United States.

Title: House Investigators Scrutinize Trump's Statements to Mueller in Russia Probe

Article:

The House of Representatives is investigating whether President Donald Trump lied to special counsel Robert Mueller during the Russia probe, with a lawyer for the House Judiciary Committee requesting files from the special counsel's inquiry. The inquiry is focused on alleged abuse of power by Trump in US-Ukraine relations, and lawmakers are scrutinizing his statements to Mueller on WikiLeaks.

The House Judiciary Committee has already seen most of the Mueller report, including some redacted parts, but certain grand jury materials have remained secret. The committee is seeking access to the classified grand jury materials, which were granted by a judge in October, but the Department of Justice appealed the decision. The latest hearing was held to determine whether the appeal should temporarily block the previous grant of access.

Doug Letter, representing the House Judiciary Committee, told the federal appeals court that the impeachment inquiry is investigating not only the Ukraine matter but also whether Trump lied to Mueller during the course of the probe into Russian meddling in the 2016 election. Letter requested the redacted parts of the Mueller report and the full transcripts related to those portions.

Trump did not testify in the Mueller investigation, but he did submit written responses to some questions from the Mueller team. During Mueller's testimony before Congress in July, he was asked whether Trump's incomplete written responses showed he was not always telling the truth. Mueller replied, "I would say, generally." It is unclear what exactly Mueller meant by his response, but Letter believes it means the president "had been untruthful in some of his answers."

The investigation is also looking into whether Trump lied about contacts with WikiLeaks and knowledge that they were going to publish hacked Democratic emails. Letter added that evidence from the recent trial of Trump adviser Roger Stone strengthened lawmakers' argument for obtaining the secret material. Stone, who was convicted last week of lying to Congress about his work with WikiLeaks, had several calls with Trump during the 2016 election.

The president has said he did not know of any contact between his campaign and WikiLeaks and that he did not discuss WikiLeaks with Stone. The lawyer for the Department of Justice argued that the impeachment inquiry is not a judicial proceeding and thus it is not legal for lawmakers to view classified grand jury material. However, there is a precedent for granting access to grand jury materials, as seen in the impeachment proceedings against President Richard Nixon.

The appeals panel is now considering the matter, and Trump has tweeted that he would "strongly consider" testifying to the impeachment inquiry "in order to get Congress focused again." As he did with the Mueller report, Trump has dismissed the impeachment probe as a "witch hunt." This week, eight individuals are due to testify before House lawmakers as part of the impeachment proceedings, including Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, a Ukraine expert on the National Security Council who listened in on Trump's July call with Ukraine's President Zelensky, which sparked a whistleblower complaint that eventually led to the start of the impeachment inquiry.

**Super Tuesday: The Sequel**

The Democratic primary season has reached a turning point, with former Vice President Joe Biden solidifying his lead in the race to take on Donald Trump in November. Six states held primary contests, with Biden emerging victorious in Mississippi, Missouri, and Michigan. While results from Washington, Idaho, and North Dakota are still pending, Bernie Sanders will be hoping to make up ground in those states.

The results from Tuesday's contests paint a clear picture: Biden has consolidated his lead, and Sanders is falling further behind. According to exit polls, Biden won key demographics such as white voters, union voters, and college graduates, who were crucial to his victory in 2016. This time around, Biden carried these groups by significant margins, further extending his lead.

The ease of Biden's victory in Michigan, a state that was a surprise win for Sanders four years ago, raises questions about whether Sanders' 2016 performance was more a reflection of Hillary Clinton's weakness rather than his own strength. The Vermont senator's failure to improve on his 2016 performance has narrowed his path to the Democratic nomination.

Biden's strengths were on full display in Mississippi, where he dominated the black vote, winning 86-11. This is a crucial demographic, as the common refrain that a Democrat can't win the nomination without the support of black voters seems to be an ironclad rule.

While Sanders performed well with the youth vote, ages 17-29, this demographic only accounted for 12.5% of the electorate in the three states, not enough to save his campaign. The epitaph for his campaign may be that it was premised on the passion of new young voters who simply did not show up in sufficient numbers at the polling booths.

Biden's pitch to Sanders' supporters, made on Tuesday night, acknowledged the common goal of defeating Trump and hinted at his attempt to court their vote. As the primary season unfolds, Biden's campaign will need to find ways to improve his standing with young voters, a crucial demographic in the general election.

Title: Americans Flee High-Tax States, Red States Gain Population

Article:

A recent report by the American Legislative Exchange Council suggests that over the past decade, approximately 3.5 million Americans have relocated from high-tax states like California and those in the Northeast to low-tax states like Texas and Arizona. This trend is expected to accelerate, according to co-authors Arthur Laffer and Stephen Moore, who attribute the shift to the Republican Party's tax bill, which caps the deduction for state and local taxes (SALT).

The report estimates that California and New York will lose around 800,000 residents over the next three years, roughly double the number lost in the previous three years. Connecticut, New Jersey, and Minnesota are expected to lose around 500,000 people in the same period. Laffer and Moore note that as the migration accelerates, it will raise real-estate values in low-tax states and hurt them in high-tax states.

The SALT cap, which limits the deduction for state and local taxes to $10,000 per family, will disproportionately affect high-earning individuals in states with high income taxes, such as California, New York, Minnesota, and New Jersey. According to Laffer and Moore, 90% of taxpayers are unaffected by the change, but high earners in these states will bear more costs of their state government.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo's office estimates that the elimination of full SALT deductibility will cost the state $14.3 billion. Cuomo has criticized the tax bill, calling it an "economic missile." In contrast, low-tax states like Florida, Nevada, Texas, and Washington, which impose no tax on earned income, are expected to continue attracting residents.

Since 2007, low-tax states like Texas and Florida have gained 1.4 million and 850,000 residents, respectively, from elsewhere in the U.S., while high-tax states like California and New York have lost more than 2.2 million residents. Texas Governor Greg Abbott has even extended an invitation to residents of high-tax New Jersey to move to the Lone Star State, touting his administration's tax cut of $4 billion.

The report highlights the ongoing trend of Americans seeking more affordable and tax-friendly environments, which is likely to continue as the SALT cap takes effect.

Title: Christ Church in Alexandria Removes Plaques Honoring George Washington and Robert E. Lee

Article:

The Christ Church in Alexandria, Virginia, has announced that it will remove two memorial plaques honoring George Washington and Robert E. Lee, citing concerns that the presence of the plaques makes some visitors feel unsafe or unwelcome. The decision was made after a unanimous vote by the church's vestry, with the plaques expected to be removed by next summer.

The plaques, which were erected in 1870, were a bit of a sensation at the time, earning mentions in newspapers from Massachusetts to San Francisco. They were paid for by subscription from citizens of Alexandria and were intended to honor the two famous parishioners. However, church leaders say that the memorials have become a source of controversy, with some visitors feeling uncomfortable or unwelcome due to the presence of the plaques.

The church's leadership acknowledged that the decision was not taken lightly, but said that the plaques are relics of another era and have no place in a church that proclaims its motto as "All are welcome - no exceptions." The church's rector, Rev. Noelle York-Simmons, said in an email that the decision was made after a long debate and that the plaques will be relocated to a new spot in the church, where they will be accompanied by additional context and information about the lives of Washington and Lee.

The decision to remove the plaques is not without controversy, with some supporters praising the church for taking a "courageous" stand and others comparing the church's leaders to the Taliban or Islamic State. The church's Facebook page has become a battleground, with some users expressing outrage and others expressing support for the decision.

The controversy surrounding the plaques is not new, with recent years seeing increased scrutiny of Lee monuments and memorials. In Charlottesville, Virginia, violence broke out this year surrounding a Lee statue that the city is trying to remove. In Lexington, Virginia, a church Lee attended in his later years voted to change its name from R.E. Lee Memorial Church to Grace Episcopal Church.

The Christ Church in Alexandria is not the only institution to grapple with the legacy of Washington and Lee. The Washington National Cathedral removed a stained-glass window featuring Lee's image, and Pohick Church, where Washington was a regular attendee, has no plans to remove his name or image.

The decision to remove the plaques is seen as a step towards acknowledging the complex and often fraught history of the United States, with the church's leadership acknowledging that the country is still grappling with the legacy of slavery and the subsequent disenfranchisement of people of color.

Title: Obama Adjusts Economic Timeline, Says Middle Class Struggles Predate Financial Crisis

Article:

In a recent speech in Green Bay, Wisconsin, President Barack Obama seemed to adjust his timeline for turning around the economy, stating that the middle class was struggling long before the financial crisis hit. This comment comes as the Labor Department prepares to release the October jobs report, which could have significant implications for the president's re-election campaign.

Obama's remarks mark a departure from his previous statements, made in 2009, when he said that if he didn't turn the economy around within three years, it would be a "one-term proposition." However, the president has consistently maintained that his efforts to revitalize the economy will take more time and that he needs additional time to complete his goals.

Some economists have questioned the accuracy of the recent jobs report, which showed the unemployment rate dipping below 8 percent. The report is the last major economic survey to be released before Election Day, and its findings could have a significant impact on the outcome of the election.

The president's opponents, including Republican challenger Mitt Romney, have criticized his economic policies and claimed that he has failed to deliver on his promises. Romney's campaign has argued that the former Massachusetts governor is the only one offering "real change" and that Obama's policies have only led to more of the same.

The two candidates have been campaigning extensively in key battleground states, with Obama visiting Wisconsin, Nevada, and Colorado, while Romney made a three-stop swing through Virginia. The Romney campaign has also announced plans to expand its reach into Pennsylvania, a state that has traditionally backed Democratic presidential candidates.

While the president's remarks may be seen as an attempt to adjust his timeline for turning around the economy, they also highlight the ongoing challenges faced by the middle class and the need for continued economic growth and job creation.

Title: The Arms Trade Treaty: Separating Fact from Fiction

Article:

The United Nations Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) has been a topic of controversy for some time, with proponents and opponents debating its potential impact on Second Amendment rights. The treaty aims to regulate the international trade in conventional arms, with the goal of reducing the diversion of weapons to the illicit market and preventing human rights violations.

While some argue that the treaty will not infringe on American gun owners' rights, others are skeptical. The Obama administration has stated that it will not accept any treaty that compromises the Second Amendment, but critics point out that the treaty's language is broad and vague, leaving room for interpretation.

The treaty's backers claim that it will help prevent violence, terrorism, and intra-state conflicts, but opponents argue that it is a flawed and ineffective solution. The logistics of implementing the treaty are also a concern, as it would require countries to adapt their national laws and regulations to comply with the treaty's obligations.

The Obama administration's interest in the treaty is also a point of contention. Critics argue that the administration's track record on gun control and its willingness to work with dictatorial regimes like Iran raise concerns about its commitment to protecting Second Amendment rights.

In conclusion, while the Arms Trade Treaty has the potential to regulate the international arms trade and prevent the diversion of weapons to the illicit market, its impact on Second Amendment rights remains unclear. Americans should be cautious and carefully consider the treaty's language and the Obama administration's track record before making a decision.

**Title:** San Francisco Police Department Memo Reveals Instructive to Avoid Body-Worn Cameras During Raid on Journalist's Home

**Article:**

A recent memo obtained by the San Francisco Police Department (SFPD) has shed light on the department's decision to instruct officers not to use body-worn cameras during a high-profile raid on journalist Bryan Carmody's home last year. The memo, obtained through a public records request, reveals that Lieutenant Pilar Torres instructed officers to refrain from using their body-worn cameras during the operation, citing concerns that the video footage could compromise the "confidential investigation."

The decision to avoid using body-worn cameras has raised concerns among press freedom advocates, who argue that the technology is designed to increase police transparency and accountability. Katie Townsend, legal director for the Reporters Committee, stated, "The fact that officers were instructed not to use their bodycams during an illegal raid of a journalist's home is deeply troubling."

The SFPD raided Carmody's home in May 2019, seizing computers, cameras, and phones, and conducting a separate search of his office. The raid was sparked by Carmody's refusal to reveal the source of a leaked police report concerning the death of Jeff Adachi, a longtime San Francisco public defender. The search warrants were later deemed illegal under California's "shield law," which protects journalists' confidential sources and materials.

The incident sparked widespread outrage, particularly among journalists and press freedom advocates. The Reporters Committee has called for an investigation into the raid and has urged a California court to return Carmody's seized materials. The Reporters Committee, along with a coalition of 60 media organizations, has also sued to unseal Carmody's arrest and search warrant records.

The SFPD has declined to provide additional information about the memo, citing pending administrative investigations. The FBI's involvement in the raid has also raised concerns, with the agency questioning Carmody about his source. The Reporters Committee has pursued records related to the FBI's presence during the raid, including an FBI document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit, which revealed that FBI agents knew Carmody was a journalist when they questioned him. It is unclear whether the FBI followed Justice Department guidelines requiring authorization from the attorney general before questioning a member of the news media.

The Reporters Committee regularly advocates for press freedom and the newsgathering rights of journalists. The organization has filed friend-of-the-court briefs and represents journalists and news organizations pro bono in court cases involving First Amendment freedoms and access to public information.

**Conservative Activists Charlie Kirk and Candace Owens Targeted by Antifa in Philadelphia**

In a shocking incident, Turning Point USA founder Charlie Kirk and Communications Director Candace Owens were harassed and attacked by Antifa members in a Philadelphia cafe on August 6, 2018. The incident has sparked concerns about the growing tensions between conservative activists and left-wing groups.

According to eyewitness accounts, Kirk and Owens were peacefully enjoying breakfast when Antifa members surrounded the cafe, using bullhorns and causing a disturbance. When they left the establishment, they were met with hissing, chanting, and screaming. Kirk was even doused with water, prompting police intervention for safety reasons.

The incident has sparked a heated debate about the safety of conservative activists and the role of Antifa in promoting violence. Kirk and Owens have taken to social media to share their account of the incident, with Kirk tweeting that conservatives are not safe and that Rep. Maxine Waters' comments have emboldened these types of attacks.

The incident has also raised questions about the role of social media platforms in policing hate speech. While Twitter has not taken action against the accounts of those involved, some have criticized the platform for not doing enough to address hate speech and promote a safe and respectful online environment.

Kirk and Owens spoke about the incident on the Hannity show, discussing the growing tensions between conservative activists and left-wing groups. The incident serves as a stark reminder of the need for respectful dialogue and peaceful coexistence in a society where differences of opinion are inevitable.

Title: President Obama Nominates Jeh Johnson as Next Secretary of Homeland Security

Article:

President Barack Obama has announced his intention to nominate Jeh Johnson, a former Pentagon attorney, as the next Secretary of Homeland Security. Johnson, who served as general counsel for the Defense Department during Obama's first term, will be introduced by the President at a ceremony on Friday. If confirmed by the Senate, Johnson would replace Janet Napolitano, who left the administration to run the University of California education system.

Johnson's background and qualifications make him a strong candidate for the position. As general counsel for the Defense Department, he provided "sound judgment" and "prior legal review and approval of every military operation approved by the President and Secretary of Defense." He also played a key role in repealing the "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy, which banned openly gay servicemembers, and provided legal guidance on the use of unmanned drones against terrorism suspects overseas and military commissions to try suspects.

Johnson's experience in cybersecurity is also notable, and he worked closely with Homeland Security officials during his time at the Pentagon. His nomination has been praised by some, including Elisa Massimino, president of Human Rights First, who said Johnson "grappled with the challenges of protecting national security while respecting human rights and upholding American ideals" during his time at the Pentagon.

However, not everyone is pleased with the nomination. Senator Jeff Sessions, R-Ala., criticized Obama for nominating a "loyalist and fundraiser" to lead what he called a "mismanaged" department. Sessions argued that the department needs a proven manager with strong relevant law enforcement experience, recognized independence, and integrity to restore it to its full capability.

Johnson's nomination is expected to be met with scrutiny during his Senate confirmation hearing, where he will face questions on his views on the war on terrorism, his approach to cybersecurity, and his experience in law enforcement.

**Budget Battles: A Cycle of Dysfunction**

The ongoing budget battles between the US Congress and the President have become a recurring phenomenon, with each new round of negotiations seeming to worsen the situation. The latest standoff has led to concerns about a potential government shutdown and a possible default on the national debt.

According to Julian Zelizer, a historian and journalist, the budget process is broken, and the country is too focused on scrambling out of each specific budget battle to address the underlying dynamics driving the process. He notes that the partisan strategy of using the budget as a way to handcuff Democratic presidents has been a major factor in the current impasse.

Zelizer points out that the tactic of threatening to veto a debt limit increase has become the new normal, and some Republicans are outraged. He believes that it's a good time to talk about reforming the budget process, citing the need for a more constructive approach.

The article highlights the historical context of budget battles, dating back to the 1960s and 1970s, when conservative Southern Democrats and Midwestern Republicans used the budget to force Democratic presidents to accept spending cuts. Since 2010, a growing number of Republicans have been willing to use aggressive tactics to force Democratic presidents to make concessions.

The article also notes that the 24-hour news media has contributed to the perpetuation of the budget wars, providing a platform for politicians to grandstand and gain attention. This has led to a normalization of extreme tactics, such as threatening to shut down the government or default on the national debt.

While some Republicans, like Senator John McCain, have expressed frustration with their colleagues' approach, others, like Senator Ted Cruz, have been willing to use extreme measures to achieve their goals. The article concludes that budget reform is possible, citing historical examples of Congress overhauling the budget process in the past.

Title: Intelligence Agencies Warn of ISIS Cells in the United States

Article:

The United States is facing a growing concern as former CIA agent Bob Baer warns that Islamic State (ISIS) cells are already present in the country. Baer, a seasoned intelligence expert, shared his concerns with CNN, stating that people working in intelligence-gathering are "very alarmed" about the situation. According to Baer, some ISIS members have entered the country by crossing the Mexican border, while others are American citizens who have returned from Syria.

Intelligence agencies are aware of some suspected ISIS members and are working to gather evidence to apprehend them, but Baer believes there may be more that they are not aware of. The Islamic State, which has taken over large portions of Syria and Iraq, has been making headlines with its brutal tactics and threats against Western countries.

In recent weeks, ISIS has released videos showing the beheadings of American journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff, with the group threatening to strike back against the United States if airstrikes against them continue. Baer believes that the killings are a direct response to the U.S. military's efforts to hinder ISIS's operations in Iraq.

As the situation continues to unfold, intelligence agencies are working to stay ahead of the threat. Baer warns that with ISIS continuing to be hurt by American attacks, they will likely continue to target Western captives. "I think there'll be more," he said.

The presence of ISIS cells in the United States highlights the need for continued vigilance and cooperation between intelligence agencies and law enforcement to prevent and disrupt terrorist plots. As the situation evolves, it is crucial that the public remains informed and vigilant to help prevent further attacks.

**Vaccine Against New Coronavirus Shows Promise in Early-Stage Trials**

A vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and Oxford University against the new coronavirus has shown an immune response in early-stage clinical trials, according to data published on Monday. The vaccine, called AZD1222, has been hailed as a leading candidate in the global race to halt the pandemic, which has claimed over 600,000 lives.

The vaccine, which has been described by the World Health Organization's chief scientist as the leading candidate, prompted no serious side effects and elicited antibody and T-cell immune responses in the trial participants. The strongest response was seen in those who received two doses, according to the trial results published in The Lancet medical journal.

The vaccine is still in the early stages of development, and researchers caution that more work is needed to confirm its effectiveness. The trial included 1,077 healthy adults aged 18-55 years with no history of COVID-19. Researchers said the vaccine caused minor side effects more frequently than a control group, but some of these could be reduced by taking the painkiller paracetamol.

AstraZeneca has signed agreements with governments around the world to supply the vaccine should it prove effective and gain regulatory approval. The company has said it will not seek to profit from the vaccine during the pandemic.

The vaccine is being developed by Oxford University and licensed to AstraZeneca, which has put it into large-scale, late-stage trials to test its efficacy. The company has signed deals to produce and supply over 2 billion doses of the shot, with 300 million doses earmarked for the United States.

While the results are promising, researchers emphasize that more work is needed to determine the vaccine's effectiveness and the optimal dosing strategy. The trial results showed a stronger immune response in 10 people given an extra dose of the vaccine after 28 days, echoing a trial in pigs. Oxford's Dr. Sarah Gilbert said the early-stage trial could not determine whether one or two doses would be needed to provide immunity.

AstraZeneca's biopharma chief, Mene Pangalos, said the company is leaning towards a two-dose strategy for later-stage trials and does not want to risk a single or lower dose that might not work. The antibody levels generated were "in the region" of those seen in convalescent patients, he said.

The vaccine's development is a collaborative effort between AstraZeneca and Oxford University, with the British government providing funding. The vaccine is expected to be available by the end of the year, pending the outcome of the late-stage trials.

**Trump's Economic Speech: A Mix of Substance and Slogans**

In a highly anticipated speech, Donald Trump addressed the Republican National Convention in Detroit, presenting a mix of policy prescriptions aimed at uniting Republicans and reassuring mainstream Republicans. The billionaire-turned-politician delivered a policy agenda that included sharp digs at Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and a call for "only great and well-crafted trade deals where we as a country for once benefit."

Trump's speech was seen as a reset and contrast speech, blending conservative economic theory with a mix of Trump populism. The speech aimed to solidify the Republican base while pushing back on the notion that he lacks substance and is all bluster and personality.

The speech touched on several key issues, including taxes, regulation, and trade. Trump proposed reducing the business tax rate from 35% to 15%, allowing parents to fully deduct the average cost of child-care spending from their taxes, and imposing tariffs against countries that "cheat by unfairly subsidizing their goods." His tax plan would raise more revenue than his earlier proposal, which had been forecast to cost $10 trillion over a decade.

However, some economists have raised concerns about the plan, citing a big loophole for the wealthy in Trump's proposal for "pass-through" income. This is a way for professionals to be paid as a consultant and claim income as pass-through business income. Trump proposes a 15% pass-through rate, significantly lower than the top federal rate of 33%. Roughly 70% of pass-through tax reductions accrue to the top 1% of taxpayers, making it a tax deal that tilts towards the well-off.

Trump also spoke about infrastructure, saying that his administration would "build the next generation of roads, bridges, railways, tunnels, seaports, and airports." However, some critics argue that his vision is stuck in the past, focusing on reviving American steel rather than embracing the future.

Overall, Trump's speech presented a mix of substance and slogans, aiming to unite Republicans and reassure mainstream Republicans. While some economists have raised concerns about the plan, it remains to be seen how it will be received by the American public.

Title: Sequestration's Impact on Jobs: A Surprisingly Low Toll

Article:

A recent government audit conducted by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) has revealed that the much-feared sequestration, which took effect in 2013, had a surprisingly low impact on jobs. According to the report, only one employee was laid off as a direct result of the budget cuts, specifically at the U.S. Parole Commission, which eliminated one position.

Senator Tom Coburn, an Oklahoma Republican, has hailed the findings as a vindication of his earlier warnings that the dire consequences of sequestration were overblown. "Despite relentless warnings about the dire consequences of sequestration's budget cuts, it appears sequestration resulted in only one layoff," he said. "While that's good news for federal employees and other workers, it is devastating to the credibility of Washington politicians and administration officials who spent months – and millions of dollars – engaging in a coordinated multi-agency cabinet-level public relations campaign to scare the American people."

The sequestration, which reduced spending at nearly every federal department and agency, was a major topic of discussion in Washington a year ago. President Obama and Democrats on Capitol Hill warned of devastating impacts on government services and the economy, while Congress passed legislation to mitigate some of the effects. However, the GAO report reveals that most agencies and departments were able to cope with the cuts, with only 15 of the 22 surveyed departments and agencies furloughing employees.

The report also highlights the various measures taken by agencies to adapt to the budget cuts. NASA, for instance, slowed down the development of a program that would have allowed the U.S. to stop relying on Russia for trips to the International Space Station. However, the agency did not furlough any employees. Similarly, many agencies used leftover savings or cut other programs to absorb the cuts.

The GAO report provides a detailed account of the measures taken by agencies to cope with the sequestration. Nearly every agency or department affected by sequestration canceled or limited bonuses, cut travel and training, and limited overtime. Nearly half of agencies and departments also offered employees early retirement or bonus payments to encourage them to leave early. Despite these measures, most agencies and departments were able to avoid furloughing or cutting jobs altogether.

The report's findings have sparked a renewed debate about the effectiveness of the sequestration and the impact of budget cuts on government services. While some have hailed the report as a vindication of their earlier warnings, others have criticized the report for not providing a comprehensive picture of the effects of sequestration. As the debate continues, the report's findings offer a nuanced look at the impact of sequestration on jobs and government services.

Title: Analyst Makes Case for Al Gore as Democratic Presidential Candidate

Article:

A recent article by Sean Illing, a political theorist for Salon, has sparked a buzz about Al Gore's potential candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination. Illing argues that Gore, a former vice president and Nobel laureate, is the only viable alternative to Hillary Clinton and Joe Biden, citing 10 reasons why he believes Gore could bridge the gap between the party's establishment and progressive wings.

According to Illing, Gore's political life may seem distant, but his activism and business savvy have kept him in the public eye. The freedom from having to run for office has also done wonders for his image. While Gore has denied any interest in running, rumors have circulated for about a year, and some have even joked about the idea on social media.

Gore has been busy with climate-related initiatives, including a concert to promote climate action, "Live Earth - Road to Paris," scheduled for September 19. When asked about Hillary Clinton's potential presidential bid, Gore declined to comment, saying it was "too early" to weigh in.

The proposal has garnered attention from various conservative outlets, including Powerline, Newsbusters, and PJ Media, which have quipped about the idea and summarized the trend as "Anybody but Hillary!" While Gore's potential candidacy is still speculative, the idea has sparked a lively discussion about the Democratic party's options for the 2024 presidential election.

Title: Federal Government Takes Action Against University of Vermont Medical Center Over Alleged Forced Abortions

Article:

The Trump administration has taken steps to address concerns over alleged forced abortions at the University of Vermont Medical Center (UVMC), a hospital that receives federal funds. The move comes after a nurse claimed that her supervisors forced her to participate in an abortion against her will.

According to the American Center for Law & Justice (ACLJ), the nurse, who wishes to remain anonymous, filed a complaint in May 2018, alleging that UVMC broke the law by forcing her to assist in an elective abortion despite her objections. The nurse claimed that she was told she was assisting a miscarriage, but was later informed that it was an abortion.

The ACLJ, which is representing the nurse, says that the Trump administration, through the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), is the first to enforce the federal law, the Church Amendment, passed by Congress in 1973. The amendment prohibits hospitals that receive federal funds from discriminating against medical professionals who refuse to participate in certain medical procedures, including abortions.

HHS has given UVMC 30 days to change its policies, which the ACLJ claims are in violation of the Church Amendment. The medical center's policy, which dates back to 2017, allows for elective abortions, or "abortions for abortion's sake," according to Sekulow.

The ACLJ claims that the former CEO of Planned Parenthood New England, who became the chairman of the Board of Trustees at UVMC, has an "animus" against pro-life nurses, medical professionals, and doctors. UVMC, however, maintains that it has "robust, formal protections" in place to safeguard employees' religious, ethical, and cultural beliefs, as well as patients' rights to access safe and legal abortion.

The medical center also claims that it does not discriminate against employees who opt out of procedures they object to, including termination of pregnancy. However, the ACLJ argues that UVMC is ignoring the nurse's rights by saying it will accommodate her objections, but only if it can do so.

The controversy highlights the ongoing debate over reproductive rights and the role of religious beliefs in healthcare. While some argue that healthcare providers should be allowed to opt out of certain procedures based on their beliefs, others argue that this could lead to discrimination against patients who need access to those services. The Trump administration's move to enforce the Church Amendment is seen as a step towards protecting the rights of medical professionals who object to certain procedures, while critics argue that it could restrict access to healthcare services.

Title: Pompeo to Meet with Russian Foreign Minister Amid Ongoing Tensions Over Venezuela

Article:

United States Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is set to meet with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov on Monday in Finland, amidst ongoing tensions over Russia's role in propping up Venezuelan dictator Nicolas Maduro. The meeting comes as the international community continues to pressure Maduro to step down and allow for a democratic transition in the crisis-ridden country.

In a press conference on his plane ahead of the meeting, Pompeo reiterated the US position on the situation in Venezuela, stating that it is only a matter of time until Maduro is gone. "We're trying to make sure the Venezuelan people get the elected democracy they deserve. That's our mission," he said. "The United States is ready to assist."

Pompeo also highlighted the deteriorating situation on the ground in Venezuela, noting that while Maduro managed to maintain control over the military in some regards, many military personnel have defected and a senior intelligence officer has departed. He emphasized that Maduro understands that his time is limited and is searching for leverage before making his departure.

According to Pompeo and other administration officials, Maduro was convinced by the Russians to stay in the country after being ready to leave permanently for Cuba late last week. The US has been critical of Russia's continued support for Maduro, with White House National Security Advisor John Bolton tweeting that the US will not tolerate foreign military interference in the Western Hemisphere and that there will be costs for those who further Maduro's usurpation and repression.

During his time in Finland, Pompeo will also give a speech on Arctic policy and meet with leaders from the Arctic Council. The meeting with Lavrov is seen as an opportunity for the US to reiterate its concerns over Russia's actions in Venezuela and to discuss other regional issues.

Title: Obama and Romney Prepare for Final Debate, Jabs Intensify

Article:

As the presidential campaign enters its final stretch, President Barack Obama and his challenger, Mitt Romney, are gearing up for their third and final debate on Monday. The stakes are high, with the polls tightening and the debates taking on an outsize importance.

In a rare moment of levity, the two candidates traded jokes at the Al Smith dinner on Thursday night, but the tone turned more pointed today as they prepared for the debate. Obama poked fun at Romney's shifting positions, dubbing it "Romnesia." The president's campaign is focusing on his record on foreign policy, an area where he has traditionally polled better.

Romney, meanwhile, is looking to capitalize on his strong performance in the second debate and is expected to continue criticizing the president's handling of the Benghazi attack and the war in Afghanistan. The Obama campaign is countering by highlighting Romney's lack of a clear plan to end the war in Afghanistan and his failure to outline a strategy to combat terrorism.

The debates have taken on an increased importance this year, with both candidates' performances having a significant impact on the polls. Following the first debate, Romney saw a sustained bounce in the polls, drawing him close to Obama or putting him ahead of the president nationally. The Obama campaign was bolstered by fresh polls showing him with healthy leads in key swing states.

The debates have also had an impact on fundraising, with Obama having his best day ever following the second debate. The candidates' biggest contributors have also been revealed, with Hollywood director Jeffrey Katzenberg giving Obama $2.5 million and Sheldon Adelson, a major supporter of Romney, contributing $34.2 million.

As the debate approaches, both candidates are preparing intensively, with Obama spending the weekend at Camp David and Romney holding a fundraiser and debate prep in Boca Raton. The stakes are high, and the debates are expected to be a crucial factor in determining the outcome of the election.

Title: Clinton's Immigration Record Under Scrutiny Amidst Controversy Over Driver's Licenses

Article:

Hillary Rodham Clinton's stance on immigration has come under renewed scrutiny after former New York Governor Eliot Spitzer revealed that he was instructed to cancel a proposal to issue driver's licenses to illegal immigrants in 2007 to help her presidential campaign. The revelation has sparked disappointment and skepticism among Hispanic advocacy groups, who are questioning Clinton's commitment to the immigrant community.

According to Spitzer, the Clinton campaign called him in 2007 and asked him to drop the proposal, which was seen as a way to address the concerns of the Hispanic community. At the time, Clinton was a junior senator from New York and struggled to answer whether she supported the policy or not during a debate. The proposal was eventually dropped, and Clinton has since reversed her stance, now saying she would support issuing licenses to illegal immigrants.

Hispanic-rights advocates are expressing dismay at Clinton's record, citing her past reluctance to take a clear stance on the issue. "Dreamers and Latinos are truly disappointed that Hillary Clinton would throw the immigrant community under the bus, especially since she has criticized others for doing the same," said Carlos Vargas, co-director of the Dream Action Coalition, a group of illegal immigrant "Dreamers."

Clinton's opponents, including Senator Bernie Sanders and Senator Elizabeth Warren, have taken a consistent stance on Hispanic-rights issues throughout their careers, taking unpopular stands even when they weren't popular. Clinton's opponents argue that her reversal on the driver's license issue raises questions about her commitment to the Hispanic community.

The issue of licenses for illegal immigrants was a hot topic in 2007, coming just a few years after the 9/11 attacks, when hijackers used valid licenses to board the planes they used to carry out the attacks. The debate has continued to simmer, with both parties experimenting with legalization and other pro-immigrant bills, only to back off when they believe the politics have become too difficult.

Clinton's supporters argue that her stance on immigration has evolved over time, and that she has taken a more progressive approach in her current campaign. However, her opponents are skeptical, citing her past reluctance to take a clear stance on the issue. As the Democratic primary heats up, Clinton's record on immigration will continue to be scrutinized, and her commitment to the Hispanic community will be put to the test.

Title: Sanders Endorses Democratic Opponent of Wasserman Schultz in Florida Primary

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, Senator Bernie Sanders has endorsed Tim Canova, the Democratic opponent of Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, in Florida's 23rd congressional district. Sanders, who has been critical of Wasserman Schultz's performance as head of the DNC, stated that he favors Canova's views, which are closer to his own, over those of Wasserman Schultz.

Canova, a law professor at Nova Southeastern University, has been a vocal critic of Wasserman Schultz, accusing her of ignoring the economic issues in her home district and making the problems worse through her votes in the House of Representatives. He has also expressed doubt that Wasserman Schultz can heal the intra-party rifts created during the primary.

Sanders' endorsement of Canova is seen as a blow to Wasserman Schultz, who has been a strong supporter of Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. Sanders' campaign has long been critical of Wasserman Schultz's performance as head of the DNC, claiming that the committee has favored Clinton's campaign through its rules and procedures.

Wasserman Schultz has responded to Sanders' endorsement by stating that she will remain neutral in the Democratic presidential race and will continue to work with Sanders for Democratic victories in the fall. However, Sanders has stated that if he is elected president, he would not reappoint Wasserman Schultz as head of the DNC.

The endorsement has sparked a heated debate within the Democratic Party, with some seeing it as a necessary step towards reforming the party's nomination process, while others view it as a personal attack on Wasserman Schultz. The controversy highlights the deep divisions within the party and the challenges it faces in the upcoming election.

In a statement, Canova expressed his gratitude to Sanders for his endorsement, stating that he is proud to be part of a campaign that is backed by the people, not big corporations. He also emphasized his commitment to greater regulation of Wall Street and his opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.

The endorsement has significant implications for the Democratic Party, as it highlights the divisions within the party and the challenges it faces in the upcoming election. It remains to be seen how the party will respond to this controversy and whether it will have a lasting impact on the election.

Title: Nikki Haley Takes Aim at Trump, West, and Sessions at Annual Al Smith Dinner

Article:

Former US Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley brought her sharp wit and humor to the annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner in New York City, poking fun at President Donald Trump, Kanye West, and Attorney General Jeff Sessions. The event, which has become a tradition for politicians to roast each other, saw Haley, a potential presidential candidate, take aim at her fellow politicians and current events.

Haley, who was invited to the dinner to "spice things up" after a "choir boy" appearance by House Speaker Paul Ryan last year, did not hold back. She joked about Elizabeth Warren's recent DNA test, saying, "I get it. You wanted an Indian woman, but Elizabeth Warren failed her DNA test." She also poked fun at Trump, saying he called her to offer advice on her remarks, telling her to "just brag about my accomplishments" and that it "really killed at the U.N."

Haley also took a swipe at West, saying, "Oh wait, that could really happen" in reference to a fake news report that said he had been sworn in as her replacement at the UN. She also joked about Sessions, saying she saw him earlier that day looking for a job on LinkedIn.

In addition to her lighthearted jabs, Haley used the platform to offer her thoughts on the current state of US politics, saying that the "toxic political environment" has led politicians to describe their opponents as enemies or evil. She emphasized that this is not the case, stating, "In America, our political opponents are not evil."

The dinner, which raised almost $4 million for Catholic children's charities, was hosted by Cardinal Timothy Dolan and featured a high-powered crowd of over 700 people, including Gov. Andrew Cuomo, Mayor Bill de Blasio, and former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger.

Overall, Haley's appearance at the Al Smith dinner was a hit, showcasing her quick wit and humor, as well as her ability to tackle serious issues and poke fun at herself and others.

**Vice President Pence Visits Migrant Shelters, Criticizes CNN Coverage**

Vice President Mike Pence visited migrant shelters in the McAllen, Texas, area on Friday, sparking a Twitter exchange with CNN over the network's coverage of his trip. Pence took to social media to express his disappointment with CNN's reporting, calling it "dishonest."

Pence's tweet claimed that the network showed a biased view of the situation, focusing on a large group of male migrants who were not showering, while ignoring the treatment of families and children. He also defended U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents from comparisons to concentration camps made by some Democrats.

In a statement, Pence said that the crisis at the southern border is real and overwhelming, and that the agency is working to provide compassionate care to vulnerable families. He also accused Democrats in Congress of refusing to fund additional bed space, leading to overcrowding in facilities.

CNN, on the other hand, reported on the visit, showing footage of a large group of men in a temporary holding area, who were shouting "no shower!" to cameras. The network also aired an interview with Pence, which was part of the Anderson Cooper 360 program.

The controversy highlights the ongoing debate over the treatment of migrants at the U.S.-Mexico border, with both sides accusing each other of misrepresenting the situation.

Title: The Double Standard in Political Investigations: A Critical Examination

Article:

The recent debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton has sparked a heated discussion about the role of the Justice Department in investigating political figures. Trump's promise to instruct the attorney general to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate Clinton's email scandal has been met with outrage from some pundits, who claim it is a threat to the rule of law and a sign of Trump's authoritarian tendencies. However, a closer examination of the situation reveals a more nuanced picture.

Clinton's own actions, including her deletion of 33,000 emails and her use of a private server, have been widely criticized. Trump's promise to investigate her is not a new development, but rather a continuation of the ongoing investigation into her actions. It is important to note that Trump has not threatened to send Clinton to prison, but rather to investigate her and hold her accountable for her actions.

Furthermore, the outrage over Trump's promise to investigate Clinton ignores the fact that she has been treated differently by the Justice Department than others who have been accused of similar actions. For example, Jeffrey Hurant, the CEO of Rentboy.com, was forced to plead guilty to federal charges and forfeit $10 million in revenue, despite the fact that there was no evidence of human trafficking or nonconsensual activity.

Clinton's own words also raise questions about her commitment to transparency and accountability. She has called for a special prosecutor to investigate trade deals between the United States and other countries, but has not specified whether this prosecutor would target American businesses or foreign governments. This lack of clarity has led some to question her motives and whether she is truly committed to transparency and accountability.

In conclusion, while Trump's promise to investigate Clinton may be seen as a threat to the rule of law by some, it is important to consider the context and the actions of both parties. The real outrage should be focused on the double standard that exists in the Justice Department, where some individuals are treated more harshly than others for similar actions.

Title: Judge Rules Philadelphia's Safe Injection Site Does Not Violate Federal Drug Laws

Article:

A Philadelphia-based nonprofit, Safehouse, has been given the green light to move forward with its plan to open a safe injection site, a medically supervised facility where individuals can inject intravenous opioids with clean syringes and access social services. The decision comes after a judge ruled that the site does not violate federal drug laws, specifically the "crackhouse statute," which prohibits the operation of facilities for the purpose of drug use or distribution.

The Justice Department had argued that Safehouse's plan would violate the statute, but Judge Gerald Austin McHugh disagreed, stating that the site intends to "reduce drug use, not facilitate it." McHugh noted that the proposed site aligns with harm reduction strategies endorsed by Congress, which aim to reduce the transmission of diseases and overdoses among drug users.

The Justice Department has repeatedly used the "crackhouse statute" to try to block or delay proposed safe injection sites around the country. However, many cities and states have already implemented harm reduction strategies, such as needle exchanges, which are legal under federal law. The Trump administration has expressed concerns that safe injection sites would destroy neighborhoods and attract drug dealers, but advocates argue that these sites can help save lives and reduce the spread of diseases.

Safehouse's plan is to provide a safe and sterile environment for individuals to inject intravenous opioids, with medical personnel on hand to prevent overdoses and provide social services. The site would not supply drugs, but rather offer a harm reduction strategy to help individuals struggling with addiction.

The decision is a significant step forward for Safehouse, which has been working to open a site in Philadelphia's Kensington neighborhood, one of the city's largest open-air drug markets. The organization's president, Ronda Goldfein, stated that the decision is a crucial step towards reducing the city's opioid crisis, which has claimed the lives of about three people per day.

The ruling is also a significant victory for advocates of harm reduction strategies, who argue that these approaches can help reduce the transmission of diseases and overdoses among drug users. While the Trump administration has expressed concerns about the potential negative impacts of safe injection sites, many cities and states are moving forward with their own plans to implement these strategies.

**Title:** Uncovering the Truth Behind the DNC Hack and Antifa: A Tale of Media Bias and Government Bureaucracy

**Article:**

The 2016 Democratic National Committee (DNC) hack and the subsequent investigation have been shrouded in controversy, with many questions still unanswered. The FBI's conclusion that Russia was responsible for the hack, based on a private cybersecurity firm's findings, has been met with skepticism by some. Meanwhile, the media has been criticized for its biased reporting and failure to scrutinize the government's handling of the investigation.

The DNC's decision to outsource the investigation to a private firm raises eyebrows, as it is rare for the victim of a crime to hire a private investigator whose findings later become the basis of government conclusions. WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has consistently maintained that the Russians did not provide him with the leaked documents, which has not been proven or disproven.

The FBI's handling of the investigation has also been called into question. Former FBI Director James Comey's actions during the 2016 election have been scrutinized, with some questioning his impartiality. Comey's decision to announce that Hillary Clinton would not face charges, despite not having interviewed her, has been criticized as unusual. Additionally, his admission to leaking his own notes to the media to prompt the appointment of a special counsel has raised concerns about his motives.

The media's portrayal of Antifa, a group known for its violent tactics, has also been criticized. While some have praised their efforts to confront white supremacists, others have noted that their methods are often violent and fascistic. The FBI and Department of Homeland Security had previously warned the Obama administration that Antifa was a domestic terrorist organization, but local police departments have been accused of being slow to respond to their violent activities.

The controversy surrounding the DNC hack and Antifa highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of these events. The government's handling of the investigation has been criticized for its lack of transparency and potential bias, while the media has been accused of perpetuating a narrative that is not supported by the facts. As the truth behind these events continues to unfold, it is essential to remain vigilant and critical of those in power.

**Secret Service Agents' Behavior Raises Concerns After Investigation into White House Incident**

A recent report by the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general has shed light on an incident involving two Secret Service agents who were allegedly impaired by alcohol when they disrupted an investigation into an unattended package outside the White House. The agents, Marc Connolly and George Ogilvie, had spent five hours at an Irish bar and restaurant less than a mile from the White House, celebrating a colleague's retirement, before driving into the scene of the investigation.

According to the report, Ogilvie bought 14 drinks in three hours, while Connolly claimed to have consumed fewer than three drinks all night. The report concluded that both agents were likely impaired by alcohol, and their behavior was described as "unacceptable" by the Secret Service's director.

The incident is the latest in a series of embarrassments for the Secret Service, whose main job is to protect the U.S. president. The inspector general's office is investigating two more Secret Service incidents in March alone, including allegations of misconduct and potential retaliation.

The report's findings have sparked concerns about the Secret Service's "dysfunctional environment" and the need for a "major cultural overhaul" to restore the agency to its former stature. The report noted that the watch commander felt it would be a "career killer" to administer a field sobriety test to a higher-ranking agent, highlighting concerns about potential retaliation for reporting misconduct.

The Secret Service has placed Connolly and Ogilvie on administrative leave and will propose disciplinary actions once the agency reviews the supporting information behind the inspector general's report. Connolly has notified the Secret Service that he plans to retire.

The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of the Secret Service's mission and the need for accountability and professionalism in its agents.

Title: China's Industrial Development Strategies: A Complex Web of Partnerships and Technology Transfer

Article:

China's rapid industrial development has been marked by a complex web of partnerships and technology transfer agreements between Chinese companies and foreign partners. While some have praised China's efforts to build its domestic industries, others have raised concerns about the tactics used by Chinese companies to acquire sensitive technology and intellectual property from foreign partners.

In the renewable energy sector, China's aggressive industrial policies have led to the growth of its wind and solar industries. In 2005, Beijing mandated that 70 percent of wind turbines installed in China had to be manufactured domestically, leading to a surge in foreign companies setting up manufacturing facilities in the country. Similarly, the government required that solar panels used in its first big municipal solar project be at least 80 percent made in China, prompting companies to produce panels in the country.

Chinese state-controlled enterprises have also heavily subsidized the manufacture of solar panels, mostly for export. As a result, Chinese companies now produce most of the world's solar panels. The same pattern has been observed in the wind turbine industry, where China is now the world's biggest market.

Some critics have raised concerns that similar tactics are being used in the automotive industry. After opening up to foreign auto companies, Chinese officials held a competition among global automakers to form joint ventures with Chinese state-owned partners. The competition included a detailed review of each company's offer to transfer technology to the joint venture.

While some have praised China's efforts to build its domestic industries, others have expressed concerns about the potential risks of technology transfer and intellectual property theft. The Obama administration questioned China's wind turbine policy as a violation of World Trade Organization rules, and China eventually withdrew the policy. However, by then, Chinese state-controlled enterprises had already begun assembling turbines using the same suppliers.

The Trump administration has also expressed concerns about the potential risks of technology transfer in the automotive industry. As China continues to grow its industries, it is essential to strike a balance between promoting economic cooperation and protecting intellectual property rights.

Title: FCC Chairman Weighs Options on Internet Regulation Amid Presidential Support for Net Neutrality

Article:

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is facing a critical decision on internet regulation, with Chairman Tom Wheeler considering a "hybrid" approach that would regulate the relationships between content companies and internet service providers, while leaving consumer-side issues unaddressed. However, President Obama's recent statement calling for full net neutrality has added a new layer of complexity to the debate.

In response to the President's statement, Wheeler emphasized the shared goal of maintaining an open internet platform, where no players are favored over others, and no content is blocked or degraded. However, the FCC is hesitant to reclassify internet providers as "common carriers," which would give the government the power to ensure equal treatment of all internet traffic. Industry groups argue that this would stifle innovation and entrepreneurship, while the FCC is concerned about the potential impact on consumer privacy, universal service, and the ability of federal agencies to protect consumers.

The FCC is taking a cautious approach, seeking to ensure that any rule changes are legally sound and beneficial to consumers. The Commission's 2010 Open Internet Rules were struck down by the D.C. Circuit Court due to lack of authority, and reclassifying broadband providers as common carriers would require the FCC to prove that this change would benefit consumers and the internet as a whole. Wheeler wants to take the time to examine the issue and ensure that any approach taken can withstand legal challenges.

The debate highlights the delicate balance between promoting an open internet and ensuring consumer protection. While President Obama's statement has added momentum to the push for net neutrality, the FCC must carefully consider the potential consequences of any regulatory changes. The agency's decision will have significant implications for the future of the internet, and it remains to be seen how the FCC will navigate this complex issue.

Title: G7 Foreign Ministers Seek to Send Clear Message to Russia on Syria

Article:

The Group of Seven (G7) foreign ministers, led by US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, are set to meet in Italy to discuss the recent developments in Syria, particularly the gas attack that left scores dead. The meeting aims to send a "clear and coordinated message" to Russia, urging it to end its support for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

The meeting comes after the US launched airstrikes on a Syrian air base in response to the gas attack, which received broad support from Europe. Italian Foreign Minister Angelino Alfano, who is hosting the meeting, noted that the airstrikes contributed to a "renewed harmony" between the US and its partners.

However, despite the renewed cooperation, there is no indication that Russia is willing to change its stance on the Assad regime. Russia and Iran have issued a joint statement warning that they will "respond with force" to any aggression, including the recent airstrikes.

US National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster has called on Russia to re-evaluate its support for Assad, stating that Russia will have to decide whether it wants to continue backing a "murderous regime." The meeting between Tillerson and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov is expected to be a key moment in the diplomatic efforts.

The G7 foreign ministers will also discuss the broader implications of the crisis in Syria and the need for a unified international response. The meeting is seen as an opportunity for the US and its allies to send a strong message to Russia and other stakeholders in the region, emphasizing the importance of finding a peaceful solution to the conflict.

In the meantime, the international community remains divided on the best course of action in Syria. While some countries have condemned the gas attack and supported the US airstrikes, others have called for restraint and a diplomatic solution. The G7 meeting is expected to be a crucial step towards finding a way forward in this complex and challenging situation.

Title: Election Results: A Global Perspective on the US Presidential Candidates

The outcome of the US presidential election has sparked widespread interest and concern around the world. As the world watches the United States navigate this critical moment, many are left wondering what the implications will be for global politics and international relations. Two prominent experts, Vijay Prashad and Medea Benjamin, share their insights on the matter.

In an interview, Vijay Prashad, a professor and author, highlighted the stark differences between the two major presidential candidates. While Donald Trump's rhetoric has been criticized for its divisive and nationalist tone, Hillary Clinton's record on foreign policy has raised concerns about her willingness to engage in military interventionism.

Prashad noted that Trump's association with white nationalists has raised concerns about his potential presidency. "If the Republican Party can see someone like Ted Cruz as normal and rational, then God help us if the Republicans are in charge of things," he said. However, he also emphasized that Trump's unpredictability makes it difficult to predict what he would do once in office.

On the other hand, Prashad criticized Hillary Clinton's role in the Libyan intervention, which he believes demonstrates a "profound dangerous tendency to go into wars overseas, damn the consequences." This, he believes, raises concerns about her willingness to engage in military interventionism.

Medea Benjamin, a human rights activist and co-founder of CodePink, echoed Prashad's concerns. "Whoever wins the presidency, there will be a hawk in the White House," she said. This sentiment highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of the candidates' positions on foreign policy and national security.

As the world watches the US presidential election unfold, it is clear that the stakes are high. The outcome will have far-reaching implications for global politics, international relations, and the future of the world.

Title: The Minimum Wage Debate: A Complex Issue with No Easy Answers

Article:

The debate surrounding the federal minimum wage has been a contentious one, with Democrats pushing for an increase and Republicans largely opposing it. The issue has been thrust into the spotlight, with many politicians being forced to take a stance. However, it appears that Republicans are struggling to discuss the topic without sounding either callous or clueless.

Governors Scott Walker and Chris Christie are two notable examples of Republicans who have faced criticism for their views on the minimum wage. During a speech at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, Christie stated that he is "tired of hearing about the minimum wage" and that it is not a priority for many Americans. He argued that parents aspire to a better life for their children, not just a higher minimum wage.

While it is true that many parents do aspire to a better life for their children, it is also important to acknowledge that a lack of upward mobility and limited economic opportunities can make the minimum wage a vital lifeline for many individuals. In a socially stratified America, measures to redistribute wealth and opportunity, such as increased education funding and public works projects, could help address these issues.

Governor Walker, who is facing a tough reelection battle in Wisconsin, has also faced criticism for his stance on the minimum wage. His administration rejected a proposal to raise the state's minimum wage, citing that $7.25 an hour is a living wage. However, MIT calculates that a single parent would need to earn $21.17 an hour to make a living wage in the state capital of Madison. Walker has instead focused on helping Wisconsinites secure higher-paying jobs, rather than raising the minimum wage.

The Republican Party's inability to discuss the minimum wage without botching basic facts or seeming insensitive has been a major point of contention. The idea that minimum wage hikes do not kill job growth and that most minimum wage earners are not high school students who just need a "starter wage" is a common misconception. However, the callousness caucus will not hear any of it.
