Many of these same companies have been advertising on VK, a Russian social media platform known for its permissive stance on hate groups and white supremacists.

VK, which has been described as a haven for white supremacists and neo-Nazis, has been criticized for its lack of action against hate speech. The platform has been linked to several hate groups, including the National Socialist Movement and the Ku Klux Klan, which still maintain an active presence on the website. Additionally, VK has been accused of complying with Russian laws against "gay propaganda," which prohibit content that is considered supportive of same-sex relationships.

Despite the concerns about hate speech on VK, several companies that have joined the Facebook boycott have continued to advertise on the Russian platform. These companies include Starbucks, Ford, Unilever, Colgate, Vans, The North Face, and Patagonia, among others. In fact, Colgate ran a promotion on VK just two days after announcing its pause in advertising on Facebook.

Coca-Cola and Pepsi, two companies that have been criticized for their advertising on VK, have not responded to inquiries about whether they will stop marketing on the platform. However, Starbucks stated that its temporary pause in advertising applies to all social media platforms.

The Anti-Defamation League (ADL) has described VK as an "international hub for white supremacists" and noted that the platform provides an open forum for extremist content. While VK has taken some steps to crack down on hate groups, including removing a page for a popular "Miss Hitler Contest" last year, organizations like the National Socialist Movement and the Ku Klux Klan still maintain an active presence on the website.

The controversy surrounding VK's permissive stance on hate speech and the continued advertising by companies that have joined the Facebook boycott highlights the complexities of addressing hate speech on social media. While some companies are taking steps to address the issue, others seem to be turning a blind eye to the problem.

Title: US Death Toll from COVID-19 Surpasses 9/11 Attacks, Highlighting Widespread Impact on Society

Article:

The United States has reached a somber milestone in its fight against the coronavirus pandemic, with the death toll surpassing 3,100, exceeding the number of victims of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. While the two events are distinct in many ways, the slow-moving toll of COVID-19 promises to have a profound impact on American society, similar to the far-reaching effects of the 9/11 attacks.

The 3,100 deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the US are a stark reminder of the virus's devastating consequences. The number of confirmed cases continues to rise rapidly, indicating that many more people will likely succumb to the disease in the coming weeks and months. The economic toll of the pandemic is also significant, with over 3 million people filing for unemployment due to the shuttering of non-essential businesses across the country.

The impact of the 9/11 attacks was felt far beyond its initial death toll. Thousands of people were injured, and thousands more died from diseases caused by exposure to toxic substances in the aftermath of the World Trade Center's collapse. The economic impact was equally severe, with New York City's economy losing 143,000 jobs and $2.8 billion in wages in the three months following the attack, according to a 2004 New York Times report.

Similarly, the effects of the coronavirus will be far-reaching. An estimated 160,000 people have been infected with the virus in the US, resulting in over 20,000 hospitalizations and placing an unprecedented strain on the nation's healthcare system. The economic stimulus package passed by Congress, worth $2.2 trillion, is a testament to the pandemic's significant impact on the economy.

As the US continues to navigate the challenges posed by COVID-19, it is essential to acknowledge the devastating consequences of the virus and the need for continued efforts to combat its spread.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's Approval Ratings Soar Amidst Sandy Relief Efforts

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's approval ratings have seen a significant surge in recent days, according to three separate surveys conducted over the past 24 hours. The polls suggest that Christie's job performance has received a boost, particularly among Democrats, following his response to the devastating Superstorm Sandy.

The Quinnipiac University survey released Tuesday morning found that 72% of Garden State voters give Christie a thumbs up on his job performance, a 16-point jump since before the storm struck the state in late October. The Fairleigh Dickinson University survey conducted earlier Monday reported a 77% approval rating, a 21-point spike since late October. The Rutgers-Eagleton survey showed a 67% favorable impression of Christie, a 19-point increase.

Christie announced his bid for re-election on Monday, citing the need to continue leading the state through the rebuilding and restoration process. He emphasized that he is committed to staying in office to see the state through the recovery efforts.

The polls suggest that Christie has a strong lead over potential Democratic challengers in hypothetical 2013 general election matchups. According to the Rutgers-Eagleton poll, 59% of registered voters support Christie's re-election, while 32% oppose it.

The Quinnipiac University Polling Institute director, Maurice Carroll, noted that Christie's approval ratings have seen a significant boost across party lines, with even Democrats giving him high marks for his response to the storm. "The Gov gets sky-high marks from the cities, the Shore, from every corner of the state," Carroll said.

Christie's approval ratings have been a topic of discussion in recent weeks, particularly among Republicans, who had criticized him for his appearance with President Barack Obama during the storm's aftermath and his praise of the federal government's assistance to New Jersey. However, according to the Quinnipiac poll, the vast majority of New Jersey voters, including two-thirds of Republicans, believe the criticism of Christie is "nonsense."

The news of Christie's re-election bid was widely expected, and much of the electoral speculation now focuses on which Democrat will challenge him next fall. Potential challengers include Newark Mayor Cory Booker, State Sen. Richard Codey, State Sen. Barbara Buono, and Assembly member Lou Greenwald.

The Quinnipiac University poll was conducted November 19-25, with 1,664 New Jersey registered voters questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.4 percentage points. The Rutgers-Eagleton poll was conducted November 14-17, with 1,108 New Jersey registered voters questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

Title: Congress Divided on Presidential Powers as Senate Votes on Border Emergency Declaration

Article:

The US Congress is at a crossroads as it debates the scope of presidential powers, with the Senate set to vote on Thursday on President Trump's border emergency declaration. The move has sparked a heated debate between Democrats and Republicans, with each side accusing the other of playing politics.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi has stated that the House will not take up a new Senate GOP bill aimed at limiting presidential powers under the 1976 National Emergencies Act. According to Pelosi, the bill is an attempt by Republicans to give President Trump a "pass" and allow him to continue exercising broad executive powers.

Senator Mike Lee's bill would limit a president's powers under the Emergencies Act in the future, but it would not apply retroactively to President Trump's recent border emergency declaration or to the over two dozen emergencies still in effect from previous presidents. Democrats argue that the bill is a political ploy to allow Republicans to vote for Trump's wall declaration and then claim they are concerned about presidential powers.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that Republicans do not question Trump's powers, but have concerns about his decision to redirect funds from the Pentagon to build the border wall. McConnell believes that the 1976 Emergencies Act was a necessary measure to give the Executive Branch strong powers to respond to emergencies, but acknowledges that some of his colleagues have concerns about the breadth of those powers.

Senator Charles E. Schumer, the Democratic leader, has accused Republicans of being hypocritical, pointing out that they have complained about an overbearing Executive Branch for years but are now willing to give Trump broad powers. Schumer has also noted that Democrats have supported border fencing in the past and are not opposed to the concept of border security.

The vote on Thursday will be a test of the political will of both parties, with the outcome uncertain. While the House has already passed a resolution to overturn the border emergency declaration, it is unclear whether enough Republicans will join Democrats to override a potential Trump veto. The debate highlights the ongoing tensions between the two parties over the balance of power between the legislative and executive branches.

Title: Vice Presidential Debate Falls Flat: Moderation Issues Mar the Discussion

The highly anticipated vice presidential debate between Tim Kaine and Mike Pence failed to deliver on its promise, with moderator Elaine Quijano struggling to keep the conversation on track. The debate meandered, with the candidates often speaking past each other and refusing to engage with each other's answers.

Quijano's performance was criticized by many, including CNN senior political commentator David Axelrod, who tweeted that she seemed intent on running through her questions, even when significant exchanges were happening. The moderator's inability to adapt to the direction of the conversation and stop the candidates from talking over each other was particularly notable.

One of the most egregious examples of this came when Quijano switched topics just as Kaine was pressing Pence to explain his stance on six different issues. Instead of allowing the discussion to continue, she moved on to the next topic, leaving the audience without a clear understanding of Pence's position.

Other critics, such as Newsweek managing editor Kenneth Li, questioned why Quijano changed the topic at the best moment, allowing the candidates to avoid answering the question. At times, Quijano seemed powerless to stop the candidates from bickering with each other, and was forced to reprimand them for speaking over each other.

While Quijano faced an extremely challenging task, given the limited time and the candidates' differing styles, her performance served as a reminder that debates require moderators who can be fluid and adapt to the direction of the conversation. Despite the challenges, Quijano's performance was widely criticized, and the debate ultimately fell flat, failing to provide the kind of in-depth discussion that voters were hoping for.

Title: Senate Republicans and Democrats Engage in Protracted Negotiations Over Nominations

Article:

The US Senate is facing a prolonged standoff over the confirmation of several nominations, with Republicans and Democrats at odds over the pace of debate and the use of the filibuster. The stalemate has led to a situation where the chamber's schedule is being slowed down, with some Republicans choosing to leave town for the weekend rather than participate in the negotiations.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has placed several nominations on the floor, but Republicans have been refusing to grant unanimous consent to shorten debate periods and bring the nominations to a vote. This has resulted in a backlog of nominations, with some still awaiting confirmation.

Senator John Cornyn, the Senate GOP Whip, has stated that it is up to individual senators whether they choose to stay in Washington over the weekend to vote on the remaining nominations. However, it appears that many Republicans may not be willing to do so, with some expressing frustration over the changes to the filibuster rules.

The impasse has led to a situation where the Senate is not functioning at its usual pace, with some lawmakers choosing to leave town early. However, it is worth noting that the Democratic Party has more than 51 members, and at least one Republican senator will need to be present to execute the objection process.

The standoff is seen by some as a tantrum by Republicans, who are unhappy with the changes to the filibuster rules. However, others see it as a necessary step to ensure that the Senate is functioning effectively and efficiently. The situation is likely to continue until a resolution is reached, with both parties needing to find a way to work together to move forward.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Health Care Reform Law, Political Implications Loom

Article:

The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has sparked a mix of reactions from both sides of the political aisle. President Barack Obama hailed the ruling as a victory for the American people, while his opponent, presumptive Republican nominee Mitt Romney, vowed to repeal the law if elected.

In a 5-4 ruling, the Supreme Court deemed the individual mandate, which requires Americans to purchase health insurance or face a penalty, as a valid tax. This decision has significant implications for the upcoming presidential election, with both sides likely to use the issue as a campaign talking point.

Obama emphasized that his decision to push for the ACA was not driven by politics, but by a desire to improve the lives of Americans. "I didn't do this because it was good politics," he said. "I did it because I believed it was good for the country. I did it because I believed it was good for the American people."

Romney, on the other hand, has repeatedly vowed to repeal the law, calling it a "job-killing" measure. "What the court did not do on its last day in session, I will do on my first day if elected president of the United States, and that is, I will act to repeal Obamacare," he said.

The decision has also drawn attention to the similarities between the ACA and the health care law passed during Romney's tenure as governor of Massachusetts. Obama pointed out that even Romney supported a similar individual mandate during his time in office, saying, "Even though I knew it wouldn't be politically popular, and resisted the idea when I ran for this office, we ultimately included a provision in the Affordable Care Act that people who can afford to buy health insurance should take the responsibility to do so."

The Supreme Court's ruling has also sparked debate about the constitutionality of the individual mandate. While some argue that it is a tax, others see it as an overreach of government power. Political analysts predict that Republicans will continue to use the issue as a campaign talking point, arguing that the law introduces a massive tax on the American public.

Despite the controversy, Obama's administration has vowed to continue implementing the law. "The highest court in the land has now spoken," Obama said. "We will continue to implement this law." The decision is likely to remain a contentious issue in the coming months, with both sides vying for public opinion and votes.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Kennedy's Decision on DOMA Sparks Debate on Marriage Definition

Article:

In a recent decision, Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy struck down the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defined marriage as a union between a man and a woman for federal purposes. The decision has sparked a heated debate on the definition of marriage and the role of the federal government in recognizing and regulating it.

Justice Kennedy's majority opinion argued that DOMA inflicts an "injury and indignity" on gay couples, denying them an "essential part of the liberty protected by the Fifth Amendment." The decision also claimed that the law was motivated by a "bare congressional desire to harm a politically unpopular group." This stance has been met with criticism from those who argue that the federal government has a legitimate interest in defining marriage for purposes of administering federal policy and benefits.

Ed Whelan, of the Ethics and Public Policy Center, points out that the federal government has numerous programs that require a definition of marriage, such as the Internal Revenue Code and immigration laws. For example, under the Internal Revenue Code, a person who is legally separated from their spouse but not yet divorced is treated as unmarried, while under immigration laws, a marriage entered into for the purpose of gaining an immigrant's admission will be disregarded even if it remains valid under state law.

Justice Antonin Scalia, in his dissent, noted that DOMA serves a rather obvious purpose. If a gay couple marries in a state where gay marriage is recognized and then moves to a state where it is not recognized, the federal government would need to defer to the law of the state where they currently reside. DOMA settles this question by providing a clear definition of marriage for federal purposes.

The debate surrounding DOMA highlights the complexities and nuances of the issue, with different perspectives on the role of the federal government in recognizing and regulating marriage. While some see the decision as a step towards greater equality and acceptance, others argue that it undermines the traditional definition of marriage and the rights of those who hold different beliefs.

**New Article:**

New Developments Emerge in Trump Jr.'s Meeting with Russian Lawyer

A recent interview with Donald Trump Jr. on Fox News has shed new light on a controversial meeting between the Trump campaign and a Russian lawyer during the 2016 presidential election. The meeting, which took place at Trump Tower, involved Trump Jr., his father's campaign manager Paul Manafort, and his son-in-law Jared Kushner, as well as Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya.

According to Trump Jr., the meeting was arranged by a British tabloid reporter named Rob Goldstone, who works as an agent representing Emin Agalarov, a Moscow pop star with ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin. The meeting was reportedly brief and yielded no useful information.

However, U.S. officials are now investigating the role of Rinat Akhmetshin, a Washington-based lobbyist who is considered a Russian intelligence operative. Akhmetshin attended the meeting and has denied any wrongdoing, stating that he was drafted into the Soviet Army and served from 1986 to 1988, but denied having any spy training.

Akhmetshin's attendance at the meeting has raised concerns about the potential involvement of the Kremlin in the Trump campaign. U.S. officials are examining whether Veselnitskaya was sent to meet with Trump Jr. on direct orders from the Kremlin, and whether the meeting was part of a larger effort to exert influence over the Trump campaign.

The meeting has also sparked questions about the Trump campaign's denials of any contact between the campaign and Russians with a political agenda. Trump Jr. has acknowledged meeting Veselnitskaya, but did not disclose Akhmetshin's attendance.

The investigation is ongoing, and U.S. officials are working to understand the full context of the meeting and whether it was part of a larger effort to influence the 2016 election.

Title: Trump and Mattis Engage in Heated Exchange Over Leadership and Policy

Article:

In a recent Twitter exchange, President Trump and former Defense Secretary James Mattis engaged in a heated debate over their differing views on leadership and policy. The exchange began when Mattis criticized Trump for "militarizing" the federal response to nationwide protests over police brutality, calling the president the "first president in my lifetime who does not try to unite the American people."

Trump responded by calling Mattis an "overrated" military leader whom he "relished firing." The president also took aim at Mattis's leadership style, saying he was more focused on personal public relations than military prowess. Trump also claimed that Mattis was given the nickname "Mad Dog" in the military, which Mattis himself had previously denied.

Mattis served as Defense Secretary for two years before resigning in January 2019, citing disagreements with Trump over the administration's policy in Syria. Trump, however, maintained that Mattis was fired, stating that he asked for his letter of resignation and felt "great" about it.

White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany also weighed in on the exchange, calling Mattis's statement a "self-promotional stunt" and saying that Trump is the "law and order President that has restored peace to our nation's streets." McEnany also tweeted that Mattis's words were "small" compared to Trump's "strong action."

The exchange highlights the ongoing tensions between Trump and Mattis, who was previously praised by the president as a hero. The debate also underscores the deep divisions within the country over issues such as policing and protest, as well as the challenges of effective leadership and communication.

Title: The Case for Broader Opinion Diversity in Mainstream Media

The recent debate surrounding the hiring and firing of conservative journalist Kevin Williamson at The Atlantic has sparked a discussion about the role of intellectual diversity in mainstream publications. Eric Levitz, a writer for New York magazine, has argued that liberal and conservative perspectives are not equally valuable, and that the former are more deserving of representation. However, this stance raises important questions about the value of intellectual diversity and the role of opinion journalism in shaping public discourse.

Levitz's argument is that conservative opinions are often irrelevant to the current political landscape and that socialist perspectives have yet to be fully explored. He suggests that mainstream publications should prioritize hiring writers who advocate for socialist views, citing the ongoing debate between left-liberals and socialists on issues such as the means of production.

However, this perspective overlooks the importance of showcasing a range of opinions on the right, including those that may not align with the current political climate. As Ross Douthat, a New York Times columnist, notes, there are many conservatives who dissent from liberal and leftist orthodoxy and have valuable insights to share.

The debate surrounding Williamson's firing highlights the challenges of navigating the complexities of intellectual diversity. While it is true that some conservative opinions may be extreme or offensive, it is also important to recognize that even bad or extreme arguments can contain kernels of truth or contribute to the public's awareness of important issues.

In an era of increasing polarization, it is more crucial than ever to provide a platform for a wide range of opinions and perspectives. This means not only including conservative voices but also recognizing the value of dissenting opinions from both the left and the right.

Ultimately, the goal of opinion journalism is to facilitate a nuanced and informed public discourse, rather than to promote a particular ideology or agenda. By embracing intellectual diversity and providing a platform for a wide range of perspectives, mainstream publications can help to foster a more informed and engaged citizenry.

Title: Ottawa Gunman's Actions Linked to Radicalization, Authorities Say

A recent shooting in Ottawa has left one soldier dead and another injured, with authorities attributing the gunman's actions to his radicalization. The suspect, Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, 32, was killed in a gun battle with authorities. His mother, Susan Bibeau, expressed condolences to the family of the victim and apologized for the pain and chaos caused by her son's actions.

According to authorities, Zehaf-Bibeau was a Canadian citizen who may have also held Libyan citizenship. He had applied for a passport and was being investigated for his application. His email address was found on the computer of a man arrested on a terrorism charge.

Police Commissioner Bob Paulson stated that while they still don't know the full extent of Zehaf-Bibeau's motivation, his actions were linked to his radicalization. There is no evidence that he was linked to Martin Rouleau-Couture, the man who ran over two Canadian soldiers on Monday.

Zehaf-Bibeau had a criminal record in multiple provinces and was described as a "fairly recent convert to Islam" who had a history of small-time criminal activity. He had also expressed a desire to travel to Syria and had applied for a passport.

The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are working to determine the full extent of Zehaf-Bibeau's motivations and connections. The incident has raised concerns about the potential for radicalization and the need for vigilance in monitoring individuals who may be at risk of being influenced by extremist ideologies.

In related news, Ottawa police have ruled out the possibility of a second shooter, and the incident is not yet linked to the previous day's attack in which two soldiers were run down in a car. The incident has sparked concerns about the potential for further attacks and the need for increased security measures to prevent them.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Disputes Claim of ISIS Fighters Crossing US-Mexico Border

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson has disputed claims made by Representative Duncan Hunter that ISIS fighters have crossed the US-Mexico border. Hunter, a California Republican, claimed on Fox News that he had learned from Border Patrol officers that at least 10 ISIS fighters had been caught trying to cross the border, with dozens more evading capture.

However, Johnson, appearing on CNN's "Situation Room," said that these claims are not supported by credible, specific intelligence. He emphasized the importance of being responsible in what information is shared with the public, so as not to create unnecessary fear and anxiety.

A Homeland Security spokeswoman also called Hunter's statement "categorically false." Johnson stated that his department is vigilant in monitoring the border for suspicious individuals and has no specific intelligence indicating that ISIS is planning to enter the US through the southern border.

Hunter's spokesman, Joe Kasper, stood by the congressman's comments, citing a high-level source who informed him that DHS is actively discouraging any talk of ISIS on the border. Kasper also expressed skepticism about the department's statement, suggesting that it may be a case of the "left hand not knowing what the right hand is doing."

The debate highlights the ongoing concerns about border security and the challenges of monitoring and tracking potential threats. While some lawmakers and officials may have differing opinions on the issue, it is essential to rely on credible sources and evidence-based information to inform the public and guide policy decisions.

Title: Clinton Foundation to Continue Accepting Foreign Donations, But with Restrictions

Article:

The Bill, Hillary, and Chelsea Clinton Foundation has announced that it will continue to accept donations from foreign governments, despite Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. The foundation's board has decided to limit donations to six countries: Australia, Canada, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, and the UK. These countries have supported or have supported Clinton Foundation programs on health, poverty, and climate change.

The new policy, set to be released Thursday, allows these countries to continue making donations to the foundation, but prohibits other nations from making large donations. However, these countries will still be able to participate in the Clinton Global Initiative, a subsidiary of the foundation where companies, nonprofit groups, and government officials work on solutions to global problems.

The decision to continue accepting foreign donations has raised questions about whether Hillary Clinton, if elected president, will prioritize the interests of the United States or the Clinton Foundation. Critics have pointed to her use of a personal email server during her time as Secretary of State, which she has acknowledged was a mistake. They argue that this raises concerns about her ability to balance her personal and professional interests.

Additionally, some have questioned the Clinton Foundation's acceptance of donations from countries with questionable human rights records. For example, Saudi Arabia, which has been criticized for its treatment of women, has donated millions to the foundation. While Hillary Clinton has been an advocate for women's rights, her acceptance of these donations has raised eyebrows.

The debate surrounding the Clinton Foundation's foreign donations is likely to continue as the presidential election approaches. While the foundation's new policy may provide some clarity, it remains to be seen whether Hillary Clinton's actions as president will align with her campaign promises and the interests of the American people.
